romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">Lā ʾilāha ʾillā Llāh, Muḥammadur rasūlu Llāh</i></span>"<br/>"There is no god but <a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">God</a>; <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> is the messenger of God."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a <p><b>Saudi Arabia</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[d]</a></sup> officially the <b>Kingdom of Saudi Arabia</b> (<b>KSA</b>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[e]</a></sup> is a country on the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>. It has a land area of about 2,150,000 km<sup>2</sup> (830,000 sq mi), making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Asian_countries_by_area" title="List of Asian countries by area">fifth-largest country</a> in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, the second-largest in the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a>, and the largest in Western Asia. It is bordered by the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a> to the west; <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a> to the north; the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a> to the east; <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a> to the southeast; and <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> to the south. <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a> is an island country off the east coast. The <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Aqaba" title="Gulf of Aqaba">Gulf of Aqaba</a> in the northwest separates Saudi Arabia from <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>. Saudi Arabia is the only country with a coastline along both the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf, and most of its terrain consists of arid desert, lowland, steppe, and mountains. Its capital and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="List of cities and towns in Saudi Arabia">largest city</a> is <a href="/wiki/Riyadh" title="Riyadh">Riyadh</a>. The country is home to <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>, the two <a href="/wiki/Holiest_sites_in_Islam" title="Holiest sites in Islam">holiest cities</a> in Islam.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">Pre-Islamic Arabia</a>, the territory that constitutes modern-day Saudi Arabia, was the site of several ancient cultures and civilizations; the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Saudi_Arabia#Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="History of Saudi Arabia">prehistory of Saudi Arabia</a> shows some of the earliest traces of human activity in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[16]</a></sup> The world's second-largest religion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-landscape_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-landscape-22">[17]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, emerged in what is now Saudi Arabia. In the early 7th century, the Islamic prophet <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> united the population of <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> and created a single Islamic religious polity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33-23">[18]</a></sup> Following his death in 632, his followers rapidly expanded the territory under Muslim rule beyond Arabia, <a href="/wiki/Early_Muslim_conquests" title="Early Muslim conquests">conquering huge and unprecedented swathes of territory</a> (from the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> in the west to parts of <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a> in the east) in a matter of decades. Arab dynasties originating from modern-day Saudi Arabia founded the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun</a> (632–661), <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad</a> (661–750), <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid</a> (750–1517), and <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimid</a> (909–1171) caliphates, as well as numerous other dynasties in Asia, Africa, and Europe.
</p><p>The area of modern-day Saudi Arabia formerly consisted of mainly four distinct historical regions: <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Najd" title="Najd">Najd</a>, and parts of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Eastern Arabia</a> (Al-Ahsa) and <a href="/wiki/South_Arabia" title="South Arabia">South Arabia</a> (<a href="/wiki/%27Asir_Province" title="'Asir Province">'Asir</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[19]</a></sup> The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia was founded in 1932 by King Abdulaziz (known as <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Saud" title="Ibn Saud">Ibn Saud</a> in the West). He united the four regions into a single state through a series of conquests beginning in 1902 with the capture of Riyadh, the ancestral home of his family, the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">House of Saud</a>. Saudi Arabia has since been an <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy" title="Absolute monarchy">absolute monarchy</a>, where political decisions are made on the basis of consultation among the <a href="/wiki/King_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="King of Saudi Arabia">King</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia">Council of Ministers</a>, and the country’s traditional elites that oversee a highly authoritarian regime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HT2003:_14_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-HT2003:_14-26">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[22]</a></sup> The ultraconservative <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabi</a> religious movement within <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a> has been described as a "predominant feature of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Culture of Saudi Arabia">Saudi culture</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HT2003:_14_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-HT2003:_14-26">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-28">[23]</a></sup> although the power of the religious establishment has been significantly eroded in the 2010s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-29">[24]</a></sup> In its <a href="/wiki/Basic_Law_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Basic Law of Saudi Arabia">Basic Law</a>, Saudi Arabia continues to define itself as a sovereign Arab <a href="/wiki/Islamic_state" title="Islamic state">Islamic state</a> with Islam as its official religion, <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> as its official language, and Riyadh as its capital.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">Petroleum</a> was discovered on 3 March 1938 and followed up by several other finds in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Province,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia">Eastern Province</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[26]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia has since become the world's second-largest oil producer (behind the US) and the world's largest oil exporter, controlling the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves#Countries" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">second-largest oil reserves</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">fourth-largest gas reserves</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[27]</a></sup> The kingdom is categorized as a <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy" title="World Bank high-income economy">World Bank high-income economy</a> and is the only Arab country to be part of the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> major economies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[29]</a></sup> The state has attracted criticism for a variety of reasons, including its <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian%E2%80%93led_intervention_in_Yemen" title="Saudi Arabian–led intervention in Yemen">role in the Yemeni Civil War</a>, <a href="/wiki/State-sponsored_terrorism#Saudi_Arabia" title="State-sponsored terrorism">alleged sponsorship of Islamic terrorism</a> and its <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Human rights in Saudi Arabia">poor human rights record</a>, which has been characterized by the excessive and often extrajudicial <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia">use of capital punishment</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[30]</a></sup> failure to adopt adequate measures against <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Human trafficking in Saudi Arabia">human trafficking</a>, state-sponsored <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Freedom of religion in Saudi Arabia">discrimination against religious minorities</a> and <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Irreligion in Saudi Arabia">atheists</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[32]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Antisemitism in Saudi Arabia">antisemitism</a>, and its strict interpretation of <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia is considered both a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle</a> power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_United_States_and_the_Great_Powers_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_United_States_and_the_Great_Powers-40">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[36]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Economy of Saudi Arabia">Saudi economy</a> is the largest in the Middle East; the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">eighteenth-largest economy by nominal GDP</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">seventeenth-largest by PPP</a>. As a country with a very high <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNDR2014_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNDR2014-42">[37]</a></sup> it offers <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Education in Saudi Arabia">a tuition-free university education</a>, no personal income tax,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[38]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Health care in Saudi Arabia">a free universal health care system</a>. Saudi Arabia is home to the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_immigrant_population" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by immigrant population">third-largest immigrant population</a>. It also has one of the world's youngest populations, with approximately 50 per cent of its population of 34.2 million being under 25 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[39]</a></sup> In addition to being a member of the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Cooperation_Council" title="Gulf Cooperation Council">Gulf Cooperation Council</a>, Saudi Arabia is an active and founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_Air_Carriers_Organization" title="Arab Air Carriers Organization">Arab Air Carriers Organization</a> and <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">House of Saud</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_(etymology)" title="Arab (etymology)">Arab (etymology)</a></div>
<p>Following the amalgamation of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz" title="Kingdom of Hejaz">Kingdom of Hejaz</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nejd" title="Nejd">Nejd</a>, the new state was named <i>al-Mamlakah al-ʿArabīyah as-Suʿūdīyah</i> (a transliteration of <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">المملكة العربية السعودية</span></span> in <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>) by royal decree on 23 September 1932 by its founder, <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Saud" title="Ibn Saud">Abdulaziz bin Saud</a>. Although this is normally translated as "the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia" in English,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia-45">[40]</a></sup> it literally means "the Saudi Arab kingdom",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[41]</a></sup> or "the Arab Saudi Kingdom".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Safran1988_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-Safran1988-47">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>The word "Saudi" is derived from the element <i>as-Saʿūdīyah</i> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> name of the country, which is a type of adjective known as a <a href="/wiki/Nisba_(onomastics)" title="Nisba (onomastics)">nisba</a>, formed from the dynastic name of the Saudi royal family, the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">Al Saud</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">آل سعود</span>). Its inclusion expresses the view that the country is the personal possession of the royal family.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kamrava_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kamrava-49">[44]</a></sup> <i>Al Saud</i> is an <a href="/wiki/Arabic_name" title="Arabic name">Arabic name</a> formed by adding the word <i>Al</i>, meaning "family of" or "House of",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[45]</a></sup> to the personal name of an ancestor. In the case of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al_Saud" title="Al Saud">Al Saud</a>, this is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saud_ibn_Muhammad_ibn_Muqrin" title="Saud ibn Muhammad ibn Muqrin">Saud ibn Muhammad ibn Muqrin</a>, the father of the dynasty's 18th-century founder, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Saud" title="Muhammad bin Saud">Muhammad bin Saud</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="History of Saudi Arabia">History of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">Pre-Islamic Arabia</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2560" data-file-width="1712" decoding="async" height="284" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg/190px-Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg/285px-Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg/380px-Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg 2x" width="190"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Anthropomorphic stela (4th millennium BC), sandstone, 57x27 cm, from El-Maakir-Qaryat al-Kaafa (<a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="National Museum of Saudi Arabia">National Museum of Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riyadh" title="Riyadh">Riyadh</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>There is evidence that human habitation in the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> dates back to about 125,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[47]</a></sup> A 2011 study found that the first modern humans to spread east across Asia left Africa about 75,000 years ago across the <a href="/wiki/Bab-el-Mandeb" title="Bab-el-Mandeb">Bab-el-Mandeb</a> connecting the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a> and Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[48]</a></sup> The Arabian peninsula is regarded as a central figure in the understanding of hominin evolution and dispersals. Arabia underwent an extreme environmental fluctuation in the <a href="/wiki/Quaternary" title="Quaternary">Quaternary</a> that led to profound evolutionary and demographic changes. Arabia has a rich <a href="/wiki/Lower_Paleolithic" title="Lower Paleolithic">Lower Paleolithic</a> record, and the quantity of <a href="/wiki/Oldowan" title="Oldowan">Oldowan</a>-like sites in the region indicate a significant role that Arabia had played in the early hominin colonization of Eurasia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> period, prominent cultures such as <a href="/wiki/Al-Magar" title="Al-Magar">Al-Magar</a>, whose centre lay in modern-day southwestern Najd flourished. Al-Magar could be considered a "Neolithic Revolution" in human knowledge and handicraft skills.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[50]</a></sup> The culture is characterized as being one of the world's first to involve the widespread domestication of animals, particularly the horse, during the Neolithic period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[52]</a></sup> Aside from horses, animals such as sheep, goats, dogs, in particular of the <a href="/wiki/Saluki" title="Saluki">Saluki</a> breed, ostriches, falcons and fish were discovered in the form of stone statues and rock engravings. Al-Magar statues were made from local stone, and it seems that the statues were fixed in a central building that might have had a significant role in the social and religious life of the inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2017, hunting scenes showing images of the most likely domesticated dogs, resembling the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canaan_dog" title="Canaan dog">Canaan dog</a>, wearing leashes were discovered in Shuwaymis, a hilly region of northwestern Saudi Arabia. These rock engravings date back more than 8,000 years, making them the earliest depictions of dogs in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the end of the 4th millennium BC, Arabia entered the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> after witnessing drastic transformations; metals were widely used, and the period was characterized by its 2 m high burials which were simultaneously followed by the existence of numerous temples, that included many free-standing sculptures originally painted with red colours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2021, archaeologists announced that a 350,000-year-old <a href="/wiki/Acheulean" title="Acheulean">Acheulean</a> site named An Nasim in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%E1%B8%A4a%CA%BCil_Province" title="Ḥaʼil Province">Hail region</a> could be the oldest human habitation site in northern Saudi Arabia. The site was first discovered in 2015 using remote sensing and palaeohydrological modelling. It contains paleolake deposits related with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_Pleistocene" title="Middle Pleistocene">Middle Pleistocene</a> materials. 354 artefacts, hand axes and stone tools, flakes discovered by researchers provided information about tool-making traditions of the earliest living man inhabited South-West Asia. Besides, <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> artefacts are similar to material remains uncovered at the <a href="/wiki/Acheulean" title="Acheulean">Acheulean</a> sites in the <a href="/wiki/An_Nafud" title="An Nafud">Nefud Desert</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Islamic">Pre-Islamic</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4032" data-file-width="3024" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg/170px-Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg/255px-Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg/340px-Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The "Worshipping Servant" statue (2500 BC), above one metre (3 ft 3 in) in height, is much taller than any possible Mesopotamian or Harappan models. Photo courtesy of the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Korea" title="National Museum of Korea">National Museum of Korea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180-65">[60]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The earliest sedentary culture in Saudi Arabia dates back to the <a href="/wiki/Ubaid_period" title="Ubaid period">Ubaid period</a>, upon discovering various pottery sherds at <a href="/wiki/Dosariyah" title="Dosariyah">Dosariyah</a>. Initial analysis of the discovery concluded that the eastern province of Saudi Arabia was the homeland of the earliest settlers of <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, and by extension, the likely origin of the <a href="/wiki/Sumer" title="Sumer">Sumerians</a>. However, experts such as <a href="/wiki/Joan_Oates" title="Joan Oates">Joan Oates</a> had the opportunity to see the Ubaid period sherds in eastern Arabia and consequently conclude that the sherds date to the last two phases of the Ubaid period (period three and four), while a handful of examples could be classified roughly as either Ubaid 3 or Ubaid 2. Thus, the idea that colonists from Saudi Arabia had emigrated to southern Mesopotamia and founded the region's first sedentary culture was abandoned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>Climatic change and the onset of aridity may have brought about the end of this phase of settlement, as little archaeological evidence exists from the succeeding millennium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[62]</a></sup> The settlement of the region picks up again in the period of <a href="/wiki/Dilmun" title="Dilmun">Dilmun</a> in the early 3rd millennium. Known records from <a href="/wiki/Uruk" title="Uruk">Uruk</a> refer to a place called <a href="/wiki/Dilmun" title="Dilmun">Dilmun</a>, associated on several occasions with copper, and in later periods it was a source of imported woods in southern Mesopotamia. A number of scholars have suggested that Dilmun originally designated the eastern province of Saudi Arabia, notably linked with the major Dilmunite settlements of Umm an-Nussi and Umm ar-Ramadh in the interior and Tarout on the coast. It is likely that <a href="/wiki/Tarout_Island" title="Tarout Island">Tarout Island</a> was the main port and the capital of Dilmun.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180_65-1"><a href="#cite_note-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180-65">[60]</a></sup> Mesopotamian inscribed clay tablets suggests that, in the early period of Dilmun, a form of hierarchical organized political structure existed. In 1966, an earthwork in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tarout" title="Tarout">Tarout</a> exposed an ancient burial field that yielded a large, impressive statue dating to the Dilmunite period (mid 3rd millennium BC). The statue was locally made under the strong Mesopotamian influence on the artistic principle of Dilmun.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180_65-2"><a href="#cite_note-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180-65">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 2200 BC, the centre of Dilmun shifted for unknown reasons from Tarout and the Saudi Arabian mainland to the island of Bahrain, and a highly developed settlement emerged there, where a laborious temple complex and thousands of burial mounds dating to this period were discovered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180_65-3"><a href="#cite_note-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180-65">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Qasr_al_Farid.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1875" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Qasr_al_Farid.JPG/220px-Qasr_al_Farid.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Qasr_al_Farid.JPG/330px-Qasr_al_Farid.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Qasr_al_Farid.JPG/440px-Qasr_al_Farid.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Qasr_al_Farid.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Qaṣr Al-Farīd</i>, the largest of the 131 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_cut_architecture" title="Rock cut architecture">rock-cut</a> monumental tombs built from the 1st century BC to the 1st century AD, with their elaborately ornamented façades, at the extensive ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nabatean" title="Nabatean">Nabatean</a> archaeological site of <a href="/wiki/Hegra_(Mada%27in_Salih)" title="Hegra (Mada'in Salih)">Hegra</a> located in the area of <a href="/wiki/Al-%27Ula" title="Al-'Ula">Al-'Ula</a> within <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al_Madinah_Region" title="Al Madinah Region">Al Madinah Region</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a>. A UNESCO <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> since 2008.</div></div></div>
<p>By the late Bronze Age, a historically recorded people and land (Midian and the Midianites) in the north-western portion of Saudi Arabia are well-documented in the Bible. Centred in <a href="/wiki/Tabuk,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Tabuk, Saudi Arabia">Tabouk</a>, it stretched from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wadi_Arabah" title="Wadi Arabah">Wadi Arabah</a> in the north to the area of al-Wejh in the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[63]</a></sup> The capital of Midian was Qurayyah,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArnoldStrawn2016_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-ArnoldStrawn2016-69">[64]</a></sup> it consists of a large fortified citadel encompassing 35 hectares and below it lies a walled settlement of 15 hectares. The city hosted as many as 10 to 12 thousand inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coogan2001_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coogan2001-70">[65]</a></sup> The Midianites were depicted in two major events in the Bible that recount Israel's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Midian_war" title="Midian war">two wars</a> with Midian, somewhere in the early 11th century BC. Politically, the Midianites were described as having a decentralized structure headed by five kings (Evi, Rekem, Tsur, Hur, and Reba), the names appears to be toponyms of important Midianite settlements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[66]</a></sup> It is common to view that Midian designated a confederation of tribes, the sedentary element settled in the Hijaz while its nomadic affiliates pastured, and sometimes pillaged as far away land as Palestine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Midian_p._163_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-Midian_p._163-72">[67]</a></sup> The nomadic Midianites were one of the earliest exploiters of the domestication of camels that enabled them to navigate through the harsh terrains of the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Midian_p._163_72-1"><a href="#cite_note-Midian_p._163-72">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4032" data-file-width="3024" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg/170px-Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg/255px-Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg/340px-Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Colossal statue from <a href="/wiki/Al-%27Ula" title="Al-'Ula">Al-'Ula</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> (6th–4th century BC), it followed the standardized artistic sculpting of the <a href="/wiki/Lihyan" title="Lihyan">Lihyanite</a> kingdom. The original statue was painted with white. (<a href="/wiki/Louvre" title="Louvre">Louvre Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[68]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>At the end of the 7th century BC, an emerging kingdom appeared in the historical theatre of north-western Arabia. It started as a Sheikdom of Dedan, which developed into the Kingdom of Lihyan tribe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lihyan_p._192_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lihyan_p._192-74">[69]</a></sup> The earliest attestation of state regality, King of Lihyan, was in the mid-sixth century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[70]</a></sup> The second stage of the kingdom saw the transformation of Dedan from a mere city-state of which only influence they exerted was inside their city walls, to a kingdom that encompasses much wider domain that marked the pinnacle of Lihyan civilization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lihyan_p._192_74-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lihyan_p._192-74">[69]</a></sup> The third state occurred during the early 3rd century BC with bursting economic activity between the south and north that made Lihyan acquire large influence suitable to its strategic position on the caravan road.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lihyan was a powerful and highly organized ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabian" title="Arabian">Arabian</a> kingdom that played a vital cultural and economic role in the north-western region of the Arabian Peninsula.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[72]</a></sup> The Lihyanites ruled over a large domain from <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Yathrib</a> in the south and parts of the Levant in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[73]</a></sup> In antiquity, Gulf of Aqaba used to be called Gulf of Lihyan. A testimony to the extensive influence that Lihyan acquired.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HiltonHilton1996_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-HiltonHilton1996-79">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Lihyanites fell into the hands of the <a href="/wiki/Nabataeans" title="Nabataeans">Nabataeans</a> around 65 BC upon their seizure of Hegra then marching to <a href="/wiki/Tayma" title="Tayma">Tayma</a>, and to their capital Dedan in 9 BC. The Nabataeans ruled large portions of north Arabia until their domain was annexed by the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>, which renamed it <a href="/wiki/Arabia_Petraea" title="Arabia Petraea">Arabia Petraea</a>, and remained under the rule of the Romans until 630.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[75]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages_and_rise_of_Islam">Middle Ages and rise of Islam</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Caliphate" title="Caliphate">Caliphate</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Umayyad750ADloc.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="902" data-file-width="1481" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Umayyad750ADloc.png/220px-Umayyad750ADloc.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Umayyad750ADloc.png/330px-Umayyad750ADloc.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Umayyad750ADloc.png/440px-Umayyad750ADloc.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Umayyad750ADloc.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>At its greatest extent, the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a> (661–750) covered 11,100,000 km<sup>2</sup> (4,300,000 sq mi)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[76]</a></sup> and 62 million people (29 per cent of the world's population),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blankinship_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blankinship-82">[77]</a></sup> making it one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">largest empires in history</a> in both area and proportion of the world's population. It was also larger than any previous empire in history.</div></div></div>
<p>Shortly before the advent of Islam, apart from urban trading settlements (such as Mecca and Medina), much of what was to become Saudi Arabia was populated by nomadic pastoral tribal societies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[78]</a></sup> The Islamic prophet Muhammad was born in Mecca in about 571 <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>. In the early 7th century, Muhammad united the <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">various tribes of the peninsula</a> and created a single Islamic religious polity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33-23">[18]</a></sup> Following his death in 632, his followers rapidly expanded the territory under Muslim rule beyond Arabia, conquering huge and unprecedented swathes of territory (from the Iberian Peninsula in the west to parts of Central and South Asia in the east) in a matter of decades. Arabia soon became a more politically peripheral region of the Muslim world as the focus shifted to the vast and newly conquered lands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33_23-2"><a href="#cite_note-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33-23">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab" title="Arab">Arabs</a> originating from modern-day Saudi Arabia, the <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> in particular, founded the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun</a> (632–661), <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad</a> (661–750), <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid</a> (750–1517), and the <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimid</a> (909–1171) caliphates. From the 10th century to the early 20th century, Mecca and Medina were under the control of a local Arab ruler known as the <a href="/wiki/Sharif_of_Mecca" title="Sharif of Mecca">Sharif of Mecca</a>, but at most times the Sharif owed allegiance to the ruler of one of the major Islamic empires based in Baghdad, Cairo or Istanbul. Most of the remainder of what became Saudi Arabia reverted to traditional tribal rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[80]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="760" data-file-width="506" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg/170px-Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg/255px-Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg/340px-Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Badr" title="Battle of Badr">Battle of Badr</a>, 13 March 624 CE</div></div></div>
<p>For much of the 10th century, the <a href="/wiki/Isma%27ilism" title="Isma'ilism">Isma'ili</a>-Shi'ite <a href="/wiki/Qarmatians" title="Qarmatians">Qarmatians</a> were the most powerful force in the Persian Gulf. In 930, the Qarmatians pillaged Mecca, outraging the Muslim world, particularly with their theft of the <a href="/wiki/Black_Stone" title="Black Stone">Black Stone</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[81]</a></sup> In 1077–1078, an Arab Sheikh named <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_bin_Ali_Al_Uyuni" title="Abdullah bin Ali Al Uyuni">Abdullah bin Ali Al Uyuni</a> defeated the Qarmatians in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Bahrain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al-Ahsa_Oasis" title="Al-Ahsa Oasis">al-Hasa</a> with the help of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Seljuq_Empire" title="Great Seljuq Empire">Great Seljuq Empire</a> and founded the <a href="/wiki/Uyunid_dynasty" title="Uyunid dynasty">Uyunid dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[83]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Uyunid_Emirate" title="Uyunid Emirate">Uyunid Emirate</a> later underwent expansion with its territory stretching from Najd to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrian_desert" title="Syrian desert">Syrian desert</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Safa_Khulusi_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-Safa_Khulusi-89">[84]</a></sup> They were overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/Usfurids" title="Usfurids">Usfurids</a> in 1253.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[85]</a></sup> Usfurid rule was weakened after Persian rulers of <a href="/wiki/Ormus" title="Ormus">Hormuz</a> captured Bahrain and <a href="/wiki/Qatif" title="Qatif">Qatif</a> in 1320.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[86]</a></sup> The vassals of Ormuz, the Shia <a href="/wiki/Jarwanid_dynasty" title="Jarwanid dynasty">Jarwanid dynasty</a> came to rule eastern Arabia in the 14th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JuanCole_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-JuanCole-92">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[88]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jabrids" title="Jabrids">Jabrids</a> took control of the region after overthrowing the Jarwanids in the 15th century and clashed with Hormuz for more than two decades over the region for its economic revenues, until finally agreeing to pay <a href="/wiki/Tribute" title="Tribute">tribute</a> in 1507.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JuanCole_92-1"><a href="#cite_note-JuanCole-92">[87]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al-Muntafiq" title="Al-Muntafiq">Al-Muntafiq</a> tribe later took over the region and came under <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> suzerainty. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bani_Khalid" title="Bani Khalid">Bani Khalid</a> tribe later revolted against them in the 17th century and took control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[89]</a></sup> Their rule extended from Iraq to Oman at its height and they too came under Ottoman suzerainty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_Hejaz">Ottoman Hejaz</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_era_in_the_history_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Ottoman era in the history of Saudi Arabia">Ottoman era in the history of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<p>In the 16th century, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottomans" title="Ottomans">Ottomans</a> added the Red Sea and Persian Gulf coast (the Hejaz, <a href="/wiki/%27Asir_Province" title="'Asir Province">Asir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Al-Ahsa</a>) to the Empire and claimed <a href="/wiki/Suzerainty" title="Suzerainty">suzerainty</a> over the interior. One reason was to <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_naval_expeditions_in_the_Indian_Ocean" title="Ottoman naval expeditions in the Indian Ocean">thwart Portuguese attempts</a> to attack the Red Sea (hence the Hejaz) and the Indian Ocean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bernstein_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bernstein-97">[92]</a></sup> The Ottoman degree of control over these lands varied over the next four centuries with the fluctuating strength or weakness of the Empire's central authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBowen200768_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBowen200768-99">[94]</a></sup> These changes contributed to later uncertainties, such as the <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Ma%27an" title="Occupation of Ma'an">dispute with Transjordan over the inclusion of the sanjak of Ma'an</a>, including the cities of <a href="/wiki/Ma%27an" title="Ma'an">Ma'an</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aqaba" title="Aqaba">Aqaba</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foundation_of_the_Saud_dynasty">Foundation of the Saud dynasty</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Unification of Saudi Arabia">Unification of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arabia,_Egypt,_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4926" data-file-width="5784" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg/220px-Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg/330px-Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg/440px-Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Arabia,_Egypt,_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Atlas map of Arabia and the wider region in 1883</div></div></div>
<p>The emergence of what was to become the Saudi royal family, known as the Al Saud, began in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nejd" title="Nejd">Nejd</a> in central Arabia in February 1727,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[96]</a></sup> when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Saud" title="Muhammad bin Saud">Muhammad bin Saud</a>, founder of the dynasty, joined forces with the religious leader <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Abd_al-Wahhab" title="Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab">Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBowen200769–70_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBowen200769–70-102">[97]</a></sup> founder of the Wahhabi movement, a strict puritanical form of Sunni Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[98]</a></sup> This alliance formed in the 18th century provided the ideological impetus to Saudi expansion and remains the basis of Saudi Arabian dynastic rule today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1727, the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Diriyah" title="Emirate of Diriyah">Emirate of Diriyah</a> established in the area around Riyadh rapidly expanded and briefly controlled most of the present-day territory of Saudi Arabia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[100]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wahhabi_sack_of_Karbala" title="Wahhabi sack of Karbala">sacking Karbala</a> in 1802, and <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_early_Islamic_heritage_sites_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Destruction of early Islamic heritage sites in Saudi Arabia">capturing Mecca</a> in 1803. In 1818, it was destroyed by the Ottoman viceroy of Egypt, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt" title="Muhammad Ali of Egypt">Mohammed Ali Pasha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[101]</a></sup> The much smaller <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Nejd" title="Emirate of Nejd">Emirate of Nejd</a> was established in 1824. Throughout the rest of the 19th century, the Al Saud contested control of the interior of what was to become Saudi Arabia with another Arabian ruling family, the <a href="/wiki/Rashidi_dynasty" title="Rashidi dynasty">Al Rashid</a>, who ruled the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Jabal_Shammar" title="Emirate of Jabal Shammar">Emirate of Jabal Shammar</a>. By 1891, the Al Rashid were victorious and the Al Saud were driven into exile in Kuwait.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-1"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ibn_Saud_(kuwait_1910).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1299" decoding="async" height="271" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg/220px-Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg/330px-Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg/440px-Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ibn_Saud_(kuwait_1910).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ibn_Saud" title="Ibn Saud">Abdulaziz Ibn Saud</a>, the founding father and first king of Saudi Arabia</div></div></div>
<p>At the beginning of the 20th century, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> continued to control or have a suzerainty over most of the peninsula. Subject to this suzerainty, Arabia was ruled by a patchwork of tribal rulers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Murphy_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-Murphy-107">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[103]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Sharif_of_Mecca" title="Sharif of Mecca">Sharif of Mecca</a> having pre-eminence and ruling the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hejaz_Vilayet" title="Hejaz Vilayet">Hejaz</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[104]</a></sup> In 1902, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abdul_Rahman_bin_Faisal" title="Abdul Rahman bin Faisal">Abdul Rahman</a>'s son, Abdul Aziz—later to be known as <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Saud" title="Ibn Saud">Ibn Saud</a>—recaptured control of Riyadh bringing the Al Saud back to Nejd, creating the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Nejd_and_Hasa" title="Emirate of Nejd and Hasa">third "Saudi state"</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-2"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup> Ibn Saud gained the support of the <a href="/wiki/Ikhwan" title="Ikhwan">Ikhwan</a>, a tribal army inspired by Wahhabism and led by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Faisal_Al-Dawish" title="Faisal Al-Dawish">Faisal Al-Dawish</a>, and which had grown quickly after its foundation in 1912.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[105]</a></sup> With the aid of the Ikhwan, Ibn Saud captured Al-Ahsa from the Ottomans in 1913.
</p><p>In 1916, with the encouragement and support of Britain (which was fighting the Ottomans in <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>), the Sharif of Mecca, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hussein_bin_Ali,_Sharif_of_Mecca" title="Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca">Hussein bin Ali</a>, led a <a href="/wiki/Arab_Revolt" title="Arab Revolt">pan-Arab revolt</a> against the Ottoman Empire to create a united Arab state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[106]</a></sup> Although the Arab Revolt of 1916 to 1918 failed in its objective, <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">the Allied</a> victory in World War I resulted in the end of Ottoman suzerainty and control in Arabia and Hussein bin Ali became <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz" title="Kingdom of Hejaz">King of Hejaz</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ibn Saud avoided involvement in the Arab Revolt, and instead continued his struggle with the Al Rashid. Following the latter's final defeat, he took the title <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Nejd" title="Sultanate of Nejd">Sultan of Nejd</a> in 1921. With the help of the Ikhwan, the Kingdom of Hejaz was conquered in 1924–25, and on 10 January 1926, Ibn Saud declared himself King of Hejaz.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[108]</a></sup> For the next five years, he administered the two parts of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz_and_Nejd" title="Kingdom of Hejaz and Nejd">his dual kingdom</a> as separate units.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-3"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the conquest of the Hejaz, the Ikhwan leadership's objective switched to expansion of the Wahhabist realm into the British protectorates of Transjordan, Iraq and Kuwait, and began raiding those territories. This met with Ibn Saud's opposition, as he recognized the danger of a direct conflict with the British. At the same time, the Ikhwan became disenchanted with Ibn Saud's domestic policies which appeared to favour modernization and the increase in the number of non-Muslim foreigners in the country. As a result, they turned against Ibn Saud and, after a two-year struggle, were defeated in 1929 at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sabilla" title="Battle of Sabilla">Battle of Sabilla</a>, where their leaders were massacred.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[109]</a></sup> On 23 September 1932, the two <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz_and_Nejd" title="Kingdom of Hejaz and Nejd">kingdoms of the Hejaz and Nejd</a> were united as the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-4"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup> and that date is now a national holiday called <a href="/wiki/Saudi_National_Day" title="Saudi National Day">Saudi National Day</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[110]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-unification">Post-unification</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Modern_history_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Modern history of Saudi Arabia">Modern history of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1179" data-file-width="1010" decoding="async" height="257" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg/220px-Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg/330px-Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg/440px-Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Political map of Saudi Arabia</div></div></div>
<p>The new kingdom was reliant on limited agriculture and pilgrimage revenues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[111]</a></sup> In 1938, vast reserves of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">oil</a> were discovered in the Al-Ahsa region along the coast of the Persian Gulf, and full-scale development of the oil fields began in 1941 under the US-controlled <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Aramco" title="Saudi Aramco">Aramco (Arabian American Oil Company)</a>. Oil provided Saudi Arabia with economic prosperity and substantial political leverage internationally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-5"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>Cultural life rapidly developed, primarily in the Hejaz, which was the centre for newspapers and radio. However, the large influx of <a href="/wiki/Foreign_workers_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Foreign workers in Saudi Arabia">foreign workers in Saudi Arabia</a> in the oil industry increased the pre-existing propensity for <a href="/wiki/Xenophobia" title="Xenophobia">xenophobia</a>. At the same time, the government became increasingly wasteful and extravagant. By the 1950s this had led to large governmental deficits and excessive foreign borrowing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-6"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1953, <a href="/wiki/Saud_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Saud of Saudi Arabia">Saud of Saudi Arabia</a> succeeded as the king of Saudi Arabia, on his father's death, until 1964 when he was deposed in favour of his half brother <a href="/wiki/Faisal_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Faisal of Saudi Arabia">Faisal of Saudi Arabia</a>, after an intense rivalry, fuelled by doubts in the royal family over Saud's competence. In 1972, Saudi Arabia gained a 20 per cent control in Aramco, thereby decreasing US control over Saudi oil.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>In 1973, Saudi Arabia led an <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">oil boycott</a> against the Western countries that supported Israel in the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a> against Egypt and Syria, leading to the quadrupling of oil prices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-7"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup> In 1975, Faisal was assassinated by his nephew, Prince <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Faisal_bin_Musaid" title="Faisal bin Musaid">Faisal bin Musaid</a> and was succeeded by his half-brother <a href="/wiki/Khalid_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Khalid of Saudi Arabia">King Khalid</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Al-Rasheed_136-137_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Rasheed_136-137-117">[112]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 1976, Saudi Arabia had become the largest oil producer in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[113]</a></sup> Khalid's reign saw economic and social development progress at an extremely rapid rate, transforming the infrastructure and educational system of the country;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-8"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup> in foreign policy, close ties with the US were developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Al-Rasheed_136-137_117-1"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Rasheed_136-137-117">[112]</a></sup> In 1979, two events occurred which greatly concerned the government,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[114]</a></sup> and had a long-term influence on Saudi foreign and domestic policy. The first was the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">Iranian Islamic Revolution</a>. It was feared that the country's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shi%27a_Islam_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Shi'a Islam in Saudi Arabia">Shi'ite minority</a> in the Eastern Province (which is also the location of the oil fields) might rebel under the influence of their Iranian co-religionists. There were several anti-government uprisings in the region such as the <a href="/wiki/1979_Qatif_Uprising" title="1979 Qatif Uprising">1979 Qatif Uprising</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Toby_Craig_Jones_2010_218–219_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-Toby_Craig_Jones_2010_218–219-120">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>The second event was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Mosque_Seizure" title="Grand Mosque Seizure">Grand Mosque Seizure</a> in Mecca by Islamist extremists. The militants involved were in part angered by what they considered to be the corruption and un-Islamic nature of the Saudi government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Toby_Craig_Jones_2010_218–219_120-1"><a href="#cite_note-Toby_Craig_Jones_2010_218–219-120">[115]</a></sup> The government regained control of the mosque after 10 days and those captured were executed. Part of the response of the royal family was to enforce the much stricter observance of traditional religious and social norms in the country (for example, the closure of cinemas) and to give the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ulema" title="Ulema">Ulema</a> a greater role in government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hegghammer24_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hegghammer24-121">[116]</a></sup> Neither entirely succeeded as Islamism continued to grow in strength.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[117]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="1827" decoding="async" height="241" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg/220px-Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg/330px-Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg/440px-Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of Saudi Arabian administrative regions and roadways</div></div></div>
<p>In 1980, Saudi Arabia bought out the American interests in Aramco.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[118]</a></sup> King Khalid died of a heart attack in June 1982. He was succeeded by his brother, <a href="/wiki/Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Fahd of Saudi Arabia">King Fahd</a>, who added the title "Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques" to his name in 1986 in response to considerable fundamentalist pressure to avoid the use of "majesty" in association with anything except God. Fahd continued to develop close relations with the United States and increased the purchase of American and British military equipment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-9"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>The vast wealth generated by oil revenues was beginning to have an even greater impact on Saudi society. It led to rapid technological (but not cultural) modernization, urbanization, mass public education, and the creation of new media. This and the presence of increasingly large numbers of foreign workers greatly affected traditional Saudi norms and values. Although there was a dramatic change in the social and economic life of the country, political power continued to be monopolized by the royal family<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-10"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup> leading to discontent among many Saudis who began to look for wider participation in government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbir1993114_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbir1993114-124">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1980s, Saudi Arabia spent $25 billion in support of <a href="/wiki/Saddam_Hussein" title="Saddam Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War" title="Iran–Iraq War">Iran–Iraq War</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[120]</a></sup> however, Saudi Arabia condemned the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Kuwait" title="Invasion of Kuwait">Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990</a> and asked the US to intervene.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-11"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup> King Fahd allowed American and coalition troops to be stationed in Saudi Arabia. He invited the Kuwaiti government and many of its citizens to stay in Saudi Arabia, but expelled citizens of Yemen and Jordan because of their governments' support of Iraq. In 1991, Saudi Arabian forces were involved both in bombing raids on Iraq and in the land invasion that helped to liberate Kuwait.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia's relations with the West began to cause growing concern among some of the ulema and students of Sharia law and was one of the issues that led to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_militant_incidents_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="List of militant incidents in Saudi Arabia">an increase in Islamist terrorism</a> in Saudi Arabia, as well as Islamist terrorist attacks in Western countries by Saudi nationals. <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a> was a Saudi citizen (until stripped of his citizenship in 1994) and was responsible for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1998_U.S._embassy_bombings" title="1998 U.S. embassy bombings">1998 U.S. embassy bombings</a> in East Africa and the 2000 <a href="/wiki/USS_Cole_bombing" title="USS Cole bombing">USS Cole bombing</a> near the port of <a href="/wiki/Aden" title="Aden">Aden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>. 15 of the 19 terrorists involved in <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a> in New York City, Washington, D.C., and near Shanksville, Pennsylvania were Saudi nationals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[121]</a></sup> Many Saudis who did not support the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamist" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> terrorists were nevertheless deeply unhappy with the government's policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>Islamism was not the only source of hostility to the government. Although extremely wealthy by the 21st century, Saudi Arabia's economy was near stagnant. High taxes and a growth in unemployment have contributed to discontent and have been reflected in a rise in civil unrest, and discontent with the royal family. In response, a number of limited reforms were initiated by King Fahd. In March 1992, he introduced the "<a href="/wiki/Basic_Law_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Basic Law of Saudi Arabia">Basic Law</a>", which emphasized the duties and responsibilities of a ruler. In December 1993, the Consultative Council was inaugurated. It is composed of a chairman and 60 members—all chosen by the King. The King's intent was to respond to dissent while making as few actual changes in the <i>status quo</i> as possible.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Fahd made it clear that he did not have democracy in mind, saying: "A system based on elections is not consistent with our Islamic creed, which [approves of] government by consultation [shūrā]."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-12"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1995, Fahd suffered a debilitating stroke, and the Crown Prince, <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Abdullah of Saudi Arabia">Abdullah</a>, assumed the role of <i>de facto</i> regent, taking on the day-to-day running of the country; however, his authority was hindered by conflict with Fahd's full brothers (known, with Fahd, as the "<a href="/wiki/Sudairi_Seven" title="Sudairi Seven">Sudairi Seven</a>").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[123]</a></sup> From the 1990s, signs of discontent continued and included, in 2003 and 2004, a series of bombings and armed violence in Riyadh, Jeddah, Yanbu and Khobar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cordesman_2009_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cordesman_2009-129">[124]</a></sup> In February–April 2005, the first-ever nationwide municipal elections were held in Saudi Arabia. Women were not allowed to take part in the poll.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-13"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_(large).gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="844" data-file-width="959" decoding="async" height="194" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif/220px-Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif/330px-Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif/440px-Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_(large).gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">gas</a> pipelines in the Middle-East</div></div></div>
<p>In 2005, King Fahd died and was succeeded by Abdullah, who continued the policy of minimum reform and clamping down on protests. The king introduced a number of economic reforms aimed at reducing the country's reliance on oil revenue: limited deregulation, encouragement of foreign investment, and privatization. In February 2009, <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Abdullah of Saudi Arabia">Abdullah</a> announced a series of governmental changes to the judiciary, armed forces, and various ministries to modernize these institutions including the replacement of senior appointees in the judiciary and the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_religious_police" title="Islamic religious police">Mutaween</a> (religious police) with more moderate individuals and the appointment of the country's first female deputy minister.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-14"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 29 January 2011, hundreds of protesters gathered in the city of <a href="/wiki/Jeddah" title="Jeddah">Jeddah</a> in a rare display of criticism against the city's poor infrastructure after deadly floods swept through the city, killing 11 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Montreal_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-Montreal-130">[125]</a></sup> Police stopped the demonstration after about 15 minutes and arrested 30 to 50 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters_Dozens_detained_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters_Dozens_detained-131">[126]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2011, Saudi Arabia has been affected by its own <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9313_Saudi_Arabian_protests" title="2011–13 Saudi Arabian protests">Arab Spring protests</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fisk_troops_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fisk_troops-132">[127]</a></sup> In response, King Abdullah announced on 22 February 2011 a series of benefits for citizens amounting to $36 billion, of which $10.7 billion was earmarked for housing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[130]</a></sup> No political reforms were announced as part of the package, though some prisoners indicted for financial crimes were pardoned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlJazeeraEnglishBenefits_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-AlJazeeraEnglishBenefits-136">[131]</a></sup> On 18 March the same year, King Abdullah announced a package of $93 billion, which included 500,000 new homes to a cost of $67 billion, in addition to creating 60,000 new security jobs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theguardian1_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-theguardian1-137">[132]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[133]</a></sup> Although male-only <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_municipal_elections,_2011" title="Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011">municipal elections were held on 29 September 2011</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alawsat_details_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-alawsat_details-139">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bloom_women_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-bloom_women-140">[135]</a></sup> Abdullah allowed women to vote and be elected in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_municipal_elections,_2015" title="Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2015">2015 municipal elections</a>, and also to be nominated to the <a href="/wiki/Consultative_Assembly_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia">Shura Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oman_observer_electionday_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-oman_observer_electionday-141">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2001, Saudi Arabia has engaged in <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_Saudi_Arabia#The_Internet" title="Censorship in Saudi Arabia">widespread internet censorship</a>. Most online censorship generally falls into two categories: one based on censoring "immoral" (mostly pornographic and LGBT-supportive websites along with websites promoting any religious ideology other than Sunni Islam) and one based on a blacklist run by <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Media_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Ministry of Media (Saudi Arabia)">Saudi Arabia's Ministry of Media</a>, which primarily censors websites critical of the Saudi regime or associated with parties that are opposed to or opposed by Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Politics of Saudi Arabia">Politics of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:156px;max-width:156px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:157px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9,_2013.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1386" data-file-width="1360" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg/154px-Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg/231px-Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg/308px-Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg 2x" width="154"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salman_bin_Abdulaziz_Al_Saud" title="Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud">Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud</a> <br/><a href="/wiki/King_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="King of Saudi Arabia">King</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Prime Minister of Saudi Arabia">Prime Minister</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:132px;max-width:132px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:157px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_Pompeo_Meets_with_Saudi_Crowne_Prince_Salman_Al_Saud_(48119406442)_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2214" data-file-width="1825" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Secretary_Pompeo_Meets_with_Saudi_Crowne_Prince_Salman_Al_Saud_%2848119406442%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/130px-Secretary_Pompeo_Meets_with_Saudi_Crowne_Prince_Salman_Al_Saud_%2848119406442%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Secretary_Pompeo_Meets_with_Saudi_Crowne_Prince_Salman_Al_Saud_%2848119406442%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/195px-Secretary_Pompeo_Meets_with_Saudi_Crowne_Prince_Salman_Al_Saud_%2848119406442%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x,
