//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Secretary_Pompeo_Meets_with_Saudi_Crowne_Prince_Salman_Al_Saud_%2848119406442%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/260px-Secretary_Pompeo_Meets_with_Saudi_Crowne_Prince_Salman_Al_Saud_%2848119406442%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="130"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mohammad_bin_Salman" title="Mohammad bin Salman">Mohammad bin Salman</a><br/><a href="/wiki/Crown_Prince_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia">Crown Prince</a> and First Deputy Prime Minister</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Saudi Arabia is an <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy" title="Absolute monarchy">absolute monarchy</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavendish78_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish78-145">[140]</a></sup> however, according to the <a href="/wiki/Basic_Law_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Basic Law of Saudi Arabia">Basic Law of Saudi Arabia</a> adopted by royal decree in 1992, the king must comply with <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> (Islamic law) and the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>, while the Quran and the <a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">Sunnah</a> (the traditions of Muhammad) are declared to be the country's constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gerhard_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gerhard-146">[141]</a></sup> No political parties or national elections are permitted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavendish78_145-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish78-145">[140]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authoritarian" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[144]</a></sup> and some critics regard it as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Totalitarian" title="Totalitarian">totalitarian</a> state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[147]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> rated the Saudi government as the fifth most authoritarian government out of 167 rated in its 2012 <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[148]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> gave it its lowest "Not Free" rating, 7.0 ("1=best, 7=worst") for 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FH2019_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FH2019-154">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the absence of national elections and political parties,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavendish78_145-2"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish78-145">[140]</a></sup> politics in Saudi Arabia takes place in two distinct arenas: within the royal family, the Al Saud, and between the royal family and the rest of Saudi society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Noreng97_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-Noreng97-155">[150]</a></sup> Outside of the Al-Saud, participation in the political process is limited to a relatively small segment of the population and takes the form of the royal family consulting with the ulema, tribal sheikhs, and members of important commercial families on major decisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup> This process is not reported by the Saudi media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>By custom, all males of full age have a right to petition the king directly through the traditional tribal meeting known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Majlis" title="Majlis">majlis</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavendish92_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish92-158">[153]</a></sup> In many ways the approach to government differs little from the traditional system of tribal rule. Tribal identity remains strong and, outside of the royal family, political influence is frequently determined by tribal affiliation, with tribal sheikhs maintaining a considerable degree of influence over local and national events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-1"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup> As mentioned earlier, in recent years there have been limited steps to widen political participation such as the establishment of the Consultative Council in the early 1990s and the National Dialogue Forum in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Al-Rasheed242_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Rasheed242-159">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>The rule of the Al Saud faces political opposition from four sources: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunni" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamist" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> activism; liberal critics; the <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Shia Islam in Saudi Arabia">Shi'ite minority</a>—particularly in the Eastern Province; and long-standing tribal and <a href="/wiki/Regionalism_(politics)" title="Regionalism (politics)">regionalist</a> particularistic opponents (for example in the Hejaz).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[155]</a></sup> Of these, the minority activists have been the most prominent threat to the government and have in recent years perpetrated a number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_militant_incidents_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="List of militant incidents in Saudi Arabia">violent incidents in the country</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cordesman_2009_129-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cordesman_2009-129">[124]</a></sup> However, open protest against the government, even if peaceful, is not tolerated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monarchy_and_royal_family">Monarchy and royal family</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">House of Saud</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2885" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/220px-Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/330px-Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/440px-Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>King <a href="/wiki/Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Fahd of Saudi Arabia">Fahd</a> with US President <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> and future US President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> in 1985. The US and Saudi Arabia <a href="/wiki/Operation_Cyclone" title="Operation Cyclone">supplied money and arms</a> to the anti-Soviet <i><a href="/wiki/Mujahideen" title="Mujahideen">mujahideen</a></i> fighters in Afghanistan.</div></div></div>
<p>The king combines legislative, executive, and judicial functions<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-2"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup> and royal decrees form the basis of the country's legislation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Campbell_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell-162">[157]</a></sup> The king is also the prime minister, and presides over the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia">Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Consultative_Assembly_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia">Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia</a>. The royal family dominates the political system. The family's vast numbers allow it to control most of the kingdom's important posts and to have an involvement and presence at all levels of government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[158]</a></sup> The number of princes is estimated to be at least 7,000, with most power and influence being wielded by the 200 or so male descendants of Ibn Saud.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FT_Saud_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FT_Saud-164">[159]</a></sup> The key ministries are generally reserved for the royal family,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavendish78_145-3"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish78-145">[140]</a></sup> as are the 13 regional governorships.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBowen200715_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBowen200715-165">[160]</a></sup>
</p><p>Long-term political and government appointments have resulted in the creation of "power fiefdoms" for senior princes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[161]</a></sup> such as those of King Abdullah, who had been Commander of the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_National_Guard" title="Saudi Arabian National Guard">National Guard</a> since 1963 (until 2010, when he appointed his son to replace him),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[162]</a></sup> former Crown <a href="/wiki/Sultan_bin_Abdulaziz" title="Sultan bin Abdulaziz">Prince Sultan</a>, Minister of Defence and Aviation from 1962 to his death in 2011, former crown prince <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nayef_bin_Abdul_Aziz" title="Nayef bin Abdul Aziz">Prince Nayef</a> who was the Minister of Interior from 1975 to his death in 2012, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saud_bin_Faisal_bin_Abdulaziz_Al_Saud" title="Saud bin Faisal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud">Prince Saud</a> who had been Minister of Foreign Affairs since 1975<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bio_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-bio-168">[163]</a></sup> and current <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salman_bin_Abdulaziz_Al_Saud" title="Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud">King Salman</a>, who was Minister of Defense and Aviation before he was crown prince and Governor of the <a href="/wiki/Riyadh_Province" title="Riyadh Province">Riyadh Province</a> from 1962 to 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[164]</a></sup> The current Minister of Defense is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mohammad_bin_Salman_Al_Saud" title="Mohammad bin Salman Al Saud">Prince Mohammad bin Salman</a>, the son of King Salman and Crown Prince.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>The royal family is politically divided by factions based on clan loyalties, personal ambitions and ideological differences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Noreng97_155-1"><a href="#cite_note-Noreng97-155">[150]</a></sup> The most powerful clan faction is known as the '<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sudairi" title="Sudairi">Sudairi</a> Seven', comprising the late King Fahd and his full brothers and their descendants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist_Succession_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_Succession-171">[166]</a></sup> Ideological divisions include issues over the speed and direction of reform,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kostiner236_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kostiner236-172">[167]</a></sup> and whether the role of the ulema should be increased or reduced. There were divisions within the family over who should succeed to the throne after the accession or earlier death of Prince Sultan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist_Succession_171-1"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_Succession-171">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-David33_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-David33-173">[168]</a></sup> When prince Sultan died before ascending to the throne on 21 October 2011, King Abdullah appointed Prince Nayef as crown prince.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[169]</a></sup> The following year, Prince Nayef also died before ascending to the throne.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh,_Saudi_Arabia,_on_April_24,_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2590" data-file-width="3891" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_on_April_24%2C_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_on_April_24%2C_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_on_April_24%2C_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh,_Saudi_Arabia,_on_April_24,_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>As many as 500 princes, government ministers, and business people, including Prince <a href="/wiki/Fahd_bin_Abdullah_bin_Mohammed_Al_Saud" title="Fahd bin Abdullah bin Mohammed Al Saud">Fahd bin Abdullah</a>, were arrested by Saudi Arabian authorities as part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017_Saudi_Arabian_purge" title="2017 Saudi Arabian purge">2017 Saudi Arabian purge</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Saudi government<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[173]</a></sup> and the royal family<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[176]</a></sup> have often been accused of corruption over many years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbir199373Bowen2007108_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbir199373Bowen2007108-182">[177]</a></sup> and this continues into the 21st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[178]</a></sup> In a country that is said to "belong" to the royal family and is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Etymology_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Etymology of Saudi Arabia">named for them</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kamrava_49-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kamrava-49">[44]</a></sup> the lines between state assets and the personal wealth of senior princes are blurred.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FT_Saud_164-1"><a href="#cite_note-FT_Saud-164">[159]</a></sup> The extent of corruption has been described as systemic<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[179]</a></sup> and endemic,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[180]</a></sup> and its existence was acknowledged<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[181]</a></sup> and defended<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[182]</a></sup> by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bandar_bin_Sultan" title="Bandar bin Sultan">Prince Bandar bin Sultan</a> (a senior member of the royal family)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[183]</a></sup> in an interview in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBS_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-PBS-189">[184]</a></sup> Although corruption allegations have often been limited to broad undocumented accusations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[185]</a></sup> specific allegations were made in 2007, when it was claimed that the British defence contractor <a href="/wiki/BAE_Systems" title="BAE Systems">BAE Systems</a> had paid Prince Bandar US$2 billion in bribes relating to the <a href="/wiki/Al-Yamamah_arms_deal" title="Al-Yamamah arms deal">Al-Yamamah arms deal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[187]</a></sup> Prince Bandar denied the allegations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[188]</a></sup> In 2010, investigations by both US and UK authorities resulted in <a href="/wiki/Plea_bargain" title="Plea bargain">plea bargain</a> agreements with the company, by which it paid $447 million in fines but did not admit to bribery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>In its <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a> for 2010, <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a> gave Saudi Arabia a score of 4.7 (on a scale from 0 to 10 where 0 is "highly corrupt" and 10 is "highly clean").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[190]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia has undergone a process of political and social reform, such as to increase public transparency and good governance, but nepotism and patronage are widespread when doing business in the country; the enforcement of the anti-corruption laws is selective and public officials engage in corruption with impunity. A number of prominent Saudi Arabian princes, government ministers, and businesspeople, including Prince <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Waleed_bin_Talal" title="Al-Waleed bin Talal">Al-Waleed bin Talal</a>, were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017_Saudi_Arabian_anti-corruption_arrests" title="2017 Saudi Arabian anti-corruption arrests">arrested in Saudi Arabia</a> in November 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>There has been mounting pressure to reform and modernize the royal family's rule, an agenda championed by King Abdullah both before and after his accession in 2005. The creation of the Consultative Council in the early 1990s did not satisfy demands for political participation, and, in 2003, an annual <i>National Dialogue Forum</i> was announced that would allow selected professionals and intellectuals to publicly debate current national issues, within certain prescribed parameters. In 2005, the first municipal elections were held. In 2007, the <a href="/wiki/Allegiance_Council" title="Allegiance Council">Allegiance Council</a> was created to regulate the succession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Al-Rasheed242_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Rasheed242-159">[154]</a></sup> In 2009, the king made significant personnel changes to the government by appointing reformers to key positions and the first woman to a ministerial post;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[193]</a></sup> however, these changes have been criticized as being too slow or merely cosmetic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[194]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Al_ash-Sheikh_and_role_of_the_ulema">Al ash-Sheikh and role of the ulema</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3212" data-file-width="5124" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG/220px-Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG/330px-Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG/440px-Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh" title="Abdullah ibn Muhammad Al ash-Sheikh">Abdullah ibn Muhammad Al ash-Sheikh</a> with <a href="/wiki/Bogdan_Borusewicz" title="Bogdan Borusewicz">Bogdan Borusewicz</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish_Senate" title="Polish Senate">Polish Senate</a>, 26 May 2014</div></div></div>
<p>Saudi Arabia is almost unique in giving the <a href="/wiki/Ulama" title="Ulama">ulema</a> (the body of Islamic religious leaders and jurists) a direct role in government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Goldstein118_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-Goldstein118-200">[195]</a></sup> The preferred ulema are of the <a href="/wiki/Salafi_movement" title="Salafi movement">Salafi</a> persuasion. The ulema have also been a key influence in major government decisions, for example the imposition of the <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">oil embargo in 1973</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">invitation to foreign troops to Saudi Arabia in 1990</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-meforum.org_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-meforum.org-201">[196]</a></sup> In addition, they have had a major role in the judicial and education systems<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[197]</a></sup> and a monopoly of authority in the sphere of religious and social morals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hassner_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hassner-203">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the 1970s, as a result of oil wealth and the modernization of the country initiated by King Faisal, important changes to Saudi society were underway and the power of the ulema was in decline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[199]</a></sup> However, this changed following the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Mosque_Seizure" title="Grand Mosque Seizure">seizure of the Grand Mosque</a> in Mecca in 1979 by Islamist radicals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbir199321_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbir199321-205">[200]</a></sup> The government's response to the crisis included strengthening the ulema's powers and increasing their financial support:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hegghammer24_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hegghammer24-121">[116]</a></sup> in particular, they were given greater control over the education system<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbir199321_205-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbir199321-205">[200]</a></sup> and allowed to enforce the stricter observance of Wahhabi rules of moral and social behaviour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hegghammer24_121-2"><a href="#cite_note-Hegghammer24-121">[116]</a></sup> After his accession to the throne in 2005, King Abdullah took steps to reduce the powers of the ulema, for instance transferring control over girls' education to the Ministry of Education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Abdullah_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_Abdullah-206">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ulema have historically been led by the <a href="/wiki/Al_ash-Sheikh" title="Al ash-Sheikh">Al ash-Sheikh</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[202]</a></sup> the country's leading religious family.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hassner_203-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hassner-203">[198]</a></sup> The Al ash-Sheikh are the descendants of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Abd_al-Wahhab" title="Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab">Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab</a>, the 18th-century founder of the Wahhabi form of Sunni Islam which is today dominant in Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[203]</a></sup> The family is second in prestige only to the Al Saud (the royal family)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Long11_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-Long11-209">[204]</a></sup> with whom they formed a "mutual support pact"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IBP_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-IBP-210">[205]</a></sup> and power-sharing arrangement nearly 300 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-meforum.org_201-1"><a href="#cite_note-meforum.org-201">[196]</a></sup> The pact, which persists to this day,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IBP_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-IBP-210">[205]</a></sup> is based on the Al Saud maintaining the Al ash-Sheikh's authority in religious matters and upholding and propagating Wahhabi doctrine. In return, the Al ash-Sheikh support the Al Saud's political authority<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[206]</a></sup> thereby using its religious-<a href="/wiki/Moral_authority" title="Moral authority">moral authority</a> to legitimize the royal family's rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[207]</a></sup> Although the Al ash-Sheikh's domination of the ulema has diminished in recent decades,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mattar_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mattar-213">[208]</a></sup> they still hold the most important religious posts and are closely linked to the Al Saud by a high degree of intermarriage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hassner_203-2"><a href="#cite_note-Hassner-203">[198]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_system">Legal system</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Legal_system_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Legal system of Saudi Arabia">Legal system of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iqra.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="416" data-file-width="550" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Iqra.jpg/220px-Iqra.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Iqra.jpg/330px-Iqra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Iqra.jpg/440px-Iqra.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iqra.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Verses from the Quran. The Quran is the official constitution of the country and a primary source of law. Saudi Arabia is unique in enshrining a religious text as a political document.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBowen200713_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBowen200713-214">[209]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The primary source of law is the Islamic <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> derived from the teachings of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qur%27an" title="Qur'an">Qur'an</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">Sunnah</a> (the traditions of the Prophet).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Campbell_162-1"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell-162">[157]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia is unique among modern Muslim states in that Sharia is not codified and there is no system of judicial precedent, giving judges the power to use independent legal reasoning to make a decision. Because the judge is empowered to disregard previous judgments (either his own or of other judges) and may apply his personal interpretation of Sharia to any particular case, divergent judgments arise even in apparently identical cases,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sharia_Inc_Courts_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sharia_Inc_Courts-215">[210]</a></sup> making predictability of legal interpretation difficult.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[211]</a></sup> Saudi judges tend to follow the principles of the <a href="/wiki/Hanbali" title="Hanbali">Hanbali</a> school of jurisprudence (<i><a href="/wiki/Fiqh" title="Fiqh">fiqh</a></i>) found in pre-modern texts<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Haffner58_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-Haffner58-217">[212]</a></sup> and noted for its literalist interpretation of the Qur'an and <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">hadith</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[213]</a></sup> However, in 2021, Saudi Arabia has announced new judicial reforms which will lead to an entirely codified law that eliminates discrepancies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>Royal decrees are the other main source of law; but are referred to as <i>regulations</i> rather than <i>laws</i> because they are subordinate to the Sharia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Campbell_162-2"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell-162">[157]</a></sup> Royal decrees supplement Sharia in areas such as labour, commercial and corporate law. Additionally, traditional tribal law and custom remain significant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[215]</a></sup> Extra-Sharia government tribunals usually handle disputes relating to specific royal decrees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[216]</a></sup> Final appeal from both Sharia courts and government tribunals is to the King and all courts and tribunals follow Sharia rules of evidence and procedure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Campbell268_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell268-222">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>Retaliatory punishments, or <a href="/wiki/Qisas" title="Qisas">Qisas</a>, are practised: for instance, an eye can be surgically removed at the insistence of a victim who lost his own eye.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist_Cruel_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_Cruel-223">[218]</a></sup> Families of someone unlawfully killed can choose between demanding the death penalty or granting clemency in return for a payment of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diyya" title="Diyya">diyya</a> (blood money), by the perpetrator.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[219]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Foreign relations of Saudi Arabia">Foreign relations of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi,_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia,_Melania_Trump,_and_Donald_Trump,_May_2017.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg/220px-Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg/330px-Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg/440px-Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi,_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia,_Melania_Trump,_and_Donald_Trump,_May_2017.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> and First Lady <a href="/wiki/Melania_Trump" title="Melania Trump">Melania Trump</a> with King <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salman_bin_Abdulaziz_Al_Saud" title="Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud">Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud</a> and the President of Egypt, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_Al_Sisi" title="Abdel Fattah Al Sisi">Abdel Fattah Al Sisi</a>, 21 May 2017</div></div></div>
<p>Saudi Arabia joined the UN in 1945<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia-45">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[220]</a></sup> and is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cooperation_Council_for_the_Arab_States_of_the_Gulf" title="Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf">Gulf Cooperation Council</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_World_League" title="Muslim World League">Muslim World League</a>, and the Organisation of the Islamic Conference (now the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Saudi_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-Saudi_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs-226">[221]</a></sup> It plays a prominent role in the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_World_Bank" title="The World Bank">the World Bank</a>, and in 2005 joined the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia_45-2"><a href="#cite_note-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia-45">[40]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia supports the intended formation of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Customs_Union" title="Arab Customs Union">Arab Customs Union</a> in 2015 and an Arab <a href="/wiki/Single_market" title="Single market">common market</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[222]</a></sup> by 2020, as announced at the 2009 Arab League summit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1960, as a founding member of <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>, its oil pricing policy has been generally to stabilize the world oil market and try to moderate sharp price movements so as to not jeopardize the Western economies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia_45-3"><a href="#cite_note-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia-45">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[224]</a></sup> In 1973, Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations imposed an <a href="/wiki/Oil_embargo" title="Oil embargo">oil embargo</a> against the United States, United Kingdom, Japan and other Western nations which supported <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a> of October 1973.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[225]</a></sup> The embargo caused an <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">oil crisis</a> with many short- and long-term effects on global politics and the global economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between the mid-1970s and 2002, Saudi Arabia expended over $70 billion in "overseas development aid". However, there is evidence that the vast majority was, in fact, spent on propagating and extending the influence of <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a> at the expense of other forms of Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[227]</a></sup> There has been an intense debate over whether Saudi aid and Wahhabism has fomented extremism in recipient countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[228]</a></sup> The two main allegations are that, by its nature, Wahhabism encourages intolerance and promotes terrorism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[229]</a></sup> Counting only the non-Muslim-majority countries, Saudi Arabia has paid for the construction of 1359 mosques, 210 Islamic centres, 202 colleges, and 2000 schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[230]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="839" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg/220px-Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg/330px-Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg/440px-Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> meets King <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Abdullah of Saudi Arabia">Abdullah of Saudi Arabia</a>, July 2014</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Saudi Arabia–United States relations">Saudi Arabia and the United States</a> are strategic allies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_News_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News-236">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[232]</a></sup> and since President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> took office in 2009, the US has sold $110 billion in arms to Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Salon_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Salon-238">[233]</a></sup> However, the relationship between Saudi Arabia and the United States became strained and have witnessed major decline during the last years of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Obama_administration" title="Obama administration">Obama administration</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-act_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-act-240">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isis_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-isis-241">[236]</a></sup> although Obama had authorized US forces to provide logistical and intelligence support to the Saudis in their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen" title="Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen">military intervention in Yemen</a>, establishing a <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_Yemen#United_States's_role" title="Blockade of Yemen">joint coordination planning cell</a> with the Saudi military that is helping manage the war,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[238]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA" title="CIA">CIA</a> used Saudi bases for <a href="/wiki/Disposition_Matrix" title="Disposition Matrix">drone assassinations</a> in Yemen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[242]</a></sup> In the first decade of the 21st century the Saudi Arabia paid approximately $100 million to <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Agents_Registration_Act" title="Foreign Agents Registration Act">American firms</a> to <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_lobby_in_the_United_States" title="Saudi Arabia lobby in the United States">lobby</a> the U.S. government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[243]</a></sup> On 20 May 2017, President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> and King Salman signed a series of letters of intent for Saudi Arabia to <a href="/wiki/2017_United_States%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_arms_deal" title="2017 United States–Saudi Arabia arms deal">purchase arms from the United States</a> totalling US$110 billion immediately and $350 billion over 10 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnbc-20170520_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-cnbc-20170520-249">[244]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[245]</a></sup> In December 2021, the US Senate voted against a proposal to stop a $650 million sales of advanced medium range air-to-air missiles to Saudi Arabia to discourage it from its military intervention in Yemen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[247]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="746" data-file-width="959" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG/220px-A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG/330px-A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG/440px-A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Faisal_Mosque" title="Faisal Mosque">Faisal Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a> is named after a Saudi king. The kingdom is a strong ally of <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>. <a href="/wiki/WikiLeaks" title="WikiLeaks">WikiLeaks</a> claimed that Saudis are "long accustomed to having a significant role in Pakistan's affairs".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-time.com_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-time.com-253">[248]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In the Arab and Muslim worlds, Saudi Arabia is considered to be pro-Western and pro-American,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[249]</a></sup> and it is certainly a long-term ally of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[250]</a></sup> However, this<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[251]</a></sup> and Saudi Arabia's role in the 1991 <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a>, particularly the stationing of US troops on Saudi soil from 1991, prompted the development of a hostile Islamist response internally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[252]</a></sup> As a result, Saudi Arabia has, to some extent, distanced itself from the US and, for example, refused to support or to participate in the US-led <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">invasion of Iraq</a> in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-3"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_relations" title="China–Saudi Arabia relations">China and Saudi Arabia</a> are major allies, with relationship between the two countries growing significantly in recent decades. A significant number of Saudi Arabians have also expressed a positive view of <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[255]</a></sup> In February 2019, Crown Prince Mohammad defended China's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xinjiang_re-education_camps" title="Xinjiang re-education camps">Xinjiang re-education camps</a> for <a href="/wiki/Uyghurs" title="Uyghurs">Uyghur</a> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">Muslims</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[256]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[257]</a></sup> saying "China has the right to carry out anti-terrorism and de-extremisation work for its national security."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[259]</a></sup> In July 2019, UN ambassadors of 37 countries, including Saudi Arabia, have signed a joint letter to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNHRC" title="UNHRC">UNHRC</a> defending China's treatment of Uyghurs and other Muslim minority groups in the <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a> region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>The consequences of the 2003 invasion and the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a> led to increasing alarm within the Saudi monarchy over the rise of <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>'s influence in the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[261]</a></sup> These fears were reflected in comments of King Abdullah,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Abdullah_206-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_Abdullah-206">[201]</a></sup> who privately urged the United States to attack Iran and "cut off the head of the snake".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[262]</a></sup> The tentative rapprochement between the US and Iran that began in secret in 2011<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[263]</a></sup> was said to be feared by the Saudis,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[264]</a></sup> and, during the run up to the widely welcomed deal on Iran's nuclear programme that capped the first stage of US–Iranian détente, Robert Jordan, who was US ambassador to Riyadh from 2001 to 2003, said "[t]he Saudis' worst nightmare would be the [Obama] administration striking a grand bargain with Iran."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[265]</a></sup> A trip to Saudi by US President Barack Obama in 2014 included discussions of US–Iran relations, though these failed to resolve Riyadh's concerns.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[266]</a></sup>
</p><p>In order to protect the house of Khalifa, the monarchs of Bahrain, <a href="/wiki/Saudi-led_intervention_in_Bahrain" title="Saudi-led intervention in Bahrain">Saudi Arabia invaded Bahrain</a> by sending military troops to quell the uprising of Bahraini people on 14 March 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-272">[267]</a></sup> The Saudi government considered the two-month uprising as a "security threat" posed by the <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a> who represent the majority of Bahrain population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_272-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-272">[267]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:International_Syria_meeting_(29734397483).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2023" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg/220px-International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg/330px-International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg/440px-International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:International_Syria_meeting_(29734397483).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Foreign Minister <a href="/wiki/Adel_al-Jubeir" title="Adel al-Jubeir">Adel al-Jubeir</a> with then British Foreign Secretary <a href="/wiki/Boris_Johnson" title="Boris Johnson">Boris Johnson</a> in London, 16 October 2016</div></div></div>
<p>On 25 March 2015, Saudi Arabia, spearheading a coalition of Sunni Muslim states,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[268]</a></sup> started a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen" title="Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen">military intervention in Yemen</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Houthis" title="Houthis">Houthis</a> and forces loyal to former President <a href="/wiki/Ali_Abdullah_Saleh" title="Ali Abdullah Saleh">Ali Abdullah Saleh</a>, who was deposed in the 2011 <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a> uprisings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[269]</a></sup> At least 56,000 people have been killed in armed violence in Yemen between January 2016 and October 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[270]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia, together with Qatar and Turkey, openly supported the <a href="/wiki/Army_of_Conquest" title="Army of Conquest">Army of Conquest</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[272]</a></sup> an umbrella group of anti-government forces fighting in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrian_Civil_War" title="Syrian Civil War">Syrian Civil War</a> that reportedly included an <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">al-Qaeda</a> linked <a href="/wiki/Al-Nusra_Front" title="Al-Nusra Front">al-Nusra Front</a> and another <a href="/wiki/Salafi_jihadism" title="Salafi jihadism">Salafi</a> coalition known as <a href="/wiki/Ahrar_al-Sham" title="Ahrar al-Sham">Ahrar al-Sham</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[273]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia was also involved in the CIA-led <a href="/wiki/Timber_Sycamore" title="Timber Sycamore">Timber Sycamore</a> covert operation to train and arm <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_armed_groups_in_the_Syrian_Civil_War" title="List of armed groups in the Syrian Civil War">Syrian rebels</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[274]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following a number of <a href="/wiki/Incidents_during_the_Hajj" title="Incidents during the Hajj">incidents during the Hajj</a> season, the deadliest<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[275]</a></sup> of which killed at least 2,070 pilgrim<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[276]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/2015_Mina_stampede" title="2015 Mina stampede">2015 Mina stampede</a>, Saudi Arabia has been accused of mismanagement and focusing on increasing money revenues while neglecting pilgrims' welfare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[277]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2015, Sweden scrapped an arms deal with Saudi Arabia, marking an end to a decade-old defence agreement with the kingdom. The decision came after Swedish Foreign Minister <a href="/wiki/Margot_Wallstr%C3%B6m" title="Margot Wallström">Margot Wallstrom</a> was blocked by the Saudis while speaking about democracy and women's rights at the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>. This also led to Saudi Arabia recalling its ambassador to Sweden.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[278]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia has been seen as a moderating influence in the <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict" title="Arab–Israeli conflict">Arab–Israeli conflict</a>, periodically putting forward a peace plan between Israel and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" title="Palestinian people">Palestinians</a> and condemning <a href="/wiki/Hezbollah" title="Hezbollah">Hezbollah</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[279]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a> Saudi Arabia offered asylum to deposed President <a href="/wiki/Zine_El_Abidine_Ben_Ali" title="Zine El Abidine Ben Ali">Zine El Abidine Ben Ali</a> of Tunisia and King Abdullah telephoned President <a href="/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak" title="Hosni Mubarak">Hosni Mubarak</a> of Egypt (prior to his deposition) to offer his support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guardian.co.uk_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-guardian.co.uk-285">[280]</a></sup> In early 2014 relations with <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a> became strained over its support for the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood" title="Muslim Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a>, and Saudi Arabia's belief that Qatar was interfering in its affairs. In August 2014 both countries appeared to be exploring ways of ending the rift.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QatarSaudi_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-QatarSaudi-286">[281]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia and its allies have criticized Qatar-based TV channel <a href="/wiki/Al_Jazeera" title="Al Jazeera">Al Jazeera</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Qatar_relations" title="Iran–Qatar relations">Qatar's relations with Iran</a>. In 2017, Saudi Arabia imposed a land, naval and air <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Qatar_diplomatic_crisis" title="2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis">blockade on Qatar</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[282]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="872" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png/220px-Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png/330px-Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png/440px-Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Major <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict" title="Iran–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict">Iran–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict</a> locations</div></div></div>
<p>Saudi Arabia halted new trade and investment dealings with Canada and <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_relations" title="Canada–Saudi Arabia relations">suspended diplomatic ties</a> in a dramatic escalation of a dispute over the kingdom's arrest of women's rights activist <a href="/wiki/Samar_Badawi" title="Samar Badawi">Samar Badawi</a> on 6 August 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[284]</a></sup>
</p><p>Tensions have escalated between Saudi Arabia and its allies after the <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Assassination of Jamal Khashoggi">assassination of Jamal Khashoggi</a> at the Saudi consulate in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>. This has strained the already problematic <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="Saudi Arabia–Turkey relations">Saudi Arabia–Turkey relations</a>. As stated by Ozgur Unluhisarcikli, director of the German Marshall Fund's Ankara office "Turkey is maintaining a very delicate balance in its relations with Saudi Arabia. The relations have the potential of evolving into a crisis at any moment."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[285]</a></sup>
</p><p>The pressure on Saudi Arabia to reveal the truth about the assassination of Jamal Khashoggi from the US and European countries has increased. <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Saudi Arabia–United States relations">Saudi-US relations</a> took an ugly turn on 14 October 2018, when Trump promised "severe punishment" if the royal court was responsible for Khashoggis' death. The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Saudi Arabia)">Saudi Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a> retaliated with an equal statement saying, "it will respond with greater action," indicating the kingdom's "influential and vital role in the global economy." A joint statement was issued by Britain, France, and Germany also demanding a "credible investigation to establish the truth about what happened, and — if relevant — to identify those bearing responsibility for the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi, and ensure that they are held to account."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>The US expects its Gulf allies involved in the coalition in <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> to put in more efforts and address the rising concerns about the millions that have been pushed to the <a href="/wiki/Famine_in_Yemen_(2016%E2%80%93present)" title="Famine in Yemen (2016–present)">brink of famine</a>. According to the United Nations, the Arabian peninsula nation is home to the world's worst humanitarian crisis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[287]</a></sup> More than 50,000 children in Yemen died from <a href="/wiki/Starvation" title="Starvation">starvation</a> in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[288]</a></sup> The famine in Yemen is the direct result of the Saudi-led intervention and blockade of the rebel-held area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[289]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[290]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the wake of Jamal Khashoggi's murder in October 2018, the US secretary of state <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pompeo" title="Mike Pompeo">Mike Pompeo</a> and the US defence secretary <a href="/wiki/Jim_Mattis" title="Jim Mattis">Jim Mattis</a> called for a ceasefire in Yemen within 30 days followed by UN-initiated peace talks. Pompeo has asked Saudi Arabia and the UAE to stop their airstrikes on populated areas in Yemen. <a href="/wiki/Theresa_May" title="Theresa May">Theresa May</a> backed the US call to end the coalition. President of the <a href="/wiki/International_Rescue_Committee" title="International Rescue Committee">International Rescue Committee</a> <a href="/wiki/David_Miliband" title="David Miliband">David Miliband</a> called the US announcement as "the most significant breakthrough in the war in Yemen for four years".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[291]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2020, <a href="/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)" title="Showtime (TV network)">Showtime</a> announced that it will premiere its original documentary, <i>Kingdom of Silence</i>, on 2 October that year. The film was based on the 2018 murder of <a href="/wiki/Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Jamal Khashoggi">Jamal Khashoggi</a> by Saudi authorities. Directed by filmmaker Rick Rowley, the documentary examines the relationship between the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">US</a> and Saudi Arabia, as a backdrop to the murder of Khashoggi, along with the interactions between the Trump administration and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[292]</a></sup> Another documentary by <a href="/wiki/Bryan_Fogel" title="Bryan Fogel">Bryan Fogel</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dissident" title="The Dissident">The Dissident</a></i>, which excavated a web of deceit behind the murder, was to be released on the same day that marked the second death anniversary of Khashoggi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[293]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Hunt" title="Jeremy Hunt">Jeremy Hunt</a>, the UK Foreign Secretary, on his visit to Saudi Arabia and the UAE on 12 November 2018, is expected to raise the need for a ceasefire from all sides in the four-year-long Yemen civil war. The US called for a ceasefire within 30 days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[294]</a></sup> Andrew Smith, of <a href="/wiki/Campaign_Against_Arms_Trade" title="Campaign Against Arms Trade">Campaign Against Arms Trade</a> (CAAT), said that Hunt and <a href="/wiki/Boris_Johnson" title="Boris Johnson">Boris Johnson</a> "played an utterly central and complicit role in arming and supporting the Saudi-led destruction of Yemen."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[296]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017, as part of its nuclear power program, Saudi Arabia planned to extract uranium domestically, taking a step towards self-sufficiency in producing <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fuel" title="Nuclear fuel">nuclear fuel</a>. On 24 August 2017, the kingdom signed a memorandum of understanding with <a href="/wiki/China_National_Nuclear_Corporation" title="China National Nuclear Corporation">China National Nuclear Corporation</a> (CNNC) to explore and assess uranium<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[297]</a></sup> On 4 August 2020, a report claimed that Saudi Arabia has constructed a facility in the desert near Al-'Ula for extracting uranium yellowcake from <a href="/wiki/Uranium_ore" title="Uranium ore">uranium ore</a> with the help of <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>. The facility raised concerns among the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">US</a> and allied officials about Saudi nuclear energy plans and the country's option of developing <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[298]</a></sup> On 19 August 2020, Congressional Democrats asked the US secretary of state, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pompeo" title="Mike Pompeo">Mike Pompeo</a>, to provide information about China's alleged role in building a uranium processing facility in Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[299]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 17 September 2020, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> released an exclusive report revealing that Saudi Arabia was paving the way for domestic production of nuclear fuel. The confidential report obtained by the media house stated that the kingdom was assisted by Chinese geologists to produce over 90,000 tonnes of <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a> from three major deposits in the centre and northwest of Saudi, near the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NEOM" title="NEOM">NEOM</a> megacity development. The disclosure raised concerns regarding Riyadh's aggressive interest in developing atomic weapons program.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[300]</a></sup> Apart from China, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN" title="UN">UN</a> nuclear watchdog, <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> (IAEA) was also assisting Saudi's nuclear ambition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[301]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Allegations of sponsoring global terrorism</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_and_state-sponsored_terrorism" title="Saudi Arabia and state-sponsored terrorism">Saudi Arabia and state-sponsored terrorism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Jihad.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="110" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Flag_of_Jihad.svg/220px-Flag_of_Jihad.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Flag_of_Jihad.svg/330px-Flag_of_Jihad.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Flag_of_Jihad.svg/440px-Flag_of_Jihad.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Jihad.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Flag of <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">Al-Qaeda</a>, a transnational terrorist group formed by <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a>, a Saudi Arabian national of Yemeni and Syrian extraction who was stripped of his Saudi passport in 1994.</div></div></div>
<p>According to the Iraqi prime minister <a href="/wiki/Nouri_al-Maliki" title="Nouri al-Maliki">Nouri al-Maliki</a> in March 2014, Saudi Arabia along with Qatar provided political, financial, and media support to terrorists against the Iraqi government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[302]</a></sup> Similarly, President of Syria <a href="/wiki/Bashar_al-Assad" title="Bashar al-Assad">Bashar al-Assad</a> noted that the sources of the extreme ideology of the terrorist organization <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">ISIS</a> and other such <a href="/wiki/Salafi_jihadism" title="Salafi jihadism">salafist extremist</a> groups are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wahabbism" title="Wahabbism">Wahabbism</a> that has been supported by the royal family of Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p>Relations with the U.S. became strained following <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">9/11 terror attacks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[304]</a></sup> American politicians and media accused the Saudi government of supporting terrorism and tolerating a <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jihadist" title="Jihadist">jihadist</a></i> culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[305]</a></sup> Indeed, <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a> and 15 out of the 19 9/11 hijackers were from Saudi Arabia;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[306]</a></sup> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">ISIL</a>-occupied <a href="/wiki/Raqqa" title="Raqqa">Raqqa</a>, in mid-2014, all 12 judges were Saudi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[307]</a></sup> The leaked US Department of State memo, dated 17 August 2014, says that "governments of Qatar and Saudi Arabia...are providing clandestine financial and logistic support to ISIS and other radical groups in the region."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isis_241-1"><a href="#cite_note-isis-241">[236]</a></sup> According to former US Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Hillary_Clinton" title="Hillary Clinton">Hillary Clinton</a>, "Saudi Arabia remains a critical financial support base for al-Qaida, the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LeT" title="LeT">LeT</a> and other terrorist groups... Donors in Saudi Arabia constitute the most significant source of funding to Sunni terrorist groups worldwide."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guardian_05122010_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian_05122010-313">[308]</a></sup> Former CIA director <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_Woolsey" title="James Woolsey">James Woolsey</a> described it as "the soil in which <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">Al-Qaeda</a> and its sister terrorist organizations are flourishing."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iags.org_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-iags.org-314">[309]</a></sup> The Saudi government denies these claims or that it exports religious or cultural extremism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[310]</a></sup> In April 2016, Saudi Arabia has threatened to sell off $750 billion in <a href="/wiki/United_States_Treasury_security" title="United States Treasury security">Treasury securities</a> and other US assets if <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">Congress</a> passes a bill that would allow the Saudi government to be sued over 9/11.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_News_236-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News-236">[231]</a></sup> In September 2016, the Congress passed the <a href="/wiki/Justice_Against_Sponsors_of_Terrorism_Act" title="Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act">Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act</a> that would allow relatives of victims of the 11 September attacks to sue Saudi Arabia for its government's alleged role in the attacks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[311]</a></sup> Congress overwhelmingly rejected President <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_vetoes" title="List of United States presidential vetoes">Barack Obama's veto</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-act_240-1"><a href="#cite_note-act-240">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isis_241-2"><a href="#cite_note-isis-241">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/William_Patey" title="William Patey">Sir William Patey</a>, former British ambassador to Saudi Arabia, the kingdom funds mosques throughout Europe that have become hotbeds of extremism. "They are not funding terrorism. They are funding something else, which may down the road lead to individuals being radicalised and becoming fodder for terrorism," Patey said. He said that Saudi has been funding an ideology that leads to extremism and the leaders of the kingdom are not aware of the consequences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[312]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, since 2016 the kingdom began backing away from Islamist ideologies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[313]</a></sup> Several reforms took place including curbing the powers of <a href="/wiki/Committee_for_the_Promotion_of_Virtue_and_the_Prevention_of_Vice_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice (Saudi Arabia)">religious police</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-:4-319">[314]</a></sup> stopping funding mosques in foreign countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[315]</a></sup> and first mixed-gender concert performed by woman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[316]</a></sup> In 2017, Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman declared a return to “moderate Islam”.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[317]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Armed Forces of Saudi Arabia">Armed Forces of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_(1935).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="278" data-file-width="493" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg/220px-%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg/330px-%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg/440px-%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_(1935).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"The Saudi pilots training in Italy 1935"—a scene from 'Our Eagles', one of four <a href="/wiki/Video_wall" title="Video wall">video wall</a> shows made for the Royal Saudi Air Force Museum</div></div></div>
<p>The Saudi military consists of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Saudi_Land_Forces" title="Royal Saudi Land Forces">Royal Saudi Land Forces</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Saudi_Air_Force" title="Royal Saudi Air Force">Royal Saudi Air Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Saudi_Navy" title="Royal Saudi Navy">Royal Saudi Navy</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Saudi_Air_Defense" title="Royal Saudi Air Defense">Royal Saudi Air Defense</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_National_Guard" title="Saudi Arabian National Guard">Saudi Arabian National Guard</a> (SANG, an independent military force), and paramilitary forces, totalling nearly 200,000 active-duty personnel. In 2005 the armed forces had the following personnel: the army, 75,000; the air force, 18,000; air defence, 16,000; the navy, 15,500 (including 3,000 marines); and the SANG had 75,000 active soldiers and 25,000 tribal levies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Library_of_Congress_2006_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-Library_of_Congress_2006-323">[318]</a></sup> In addition, there is an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al_Mukhabarat_Al_A%27amah" title="Al Mukhabarat Al A'amah">Al Mukhabarat Al A'amah</a> military intelligence service.
</p><p>The kingdom has a long-standing military relationship with Pakistan, it has long been speculated that Saudi Arabia secretly funded Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction">atomic bomb programme</a> and seeks to purchase atomic weapons from Pakistan, in near future.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QV_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-QV-324">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SPO_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-SPO-325">[320]</a></sup> The SANG is not a reserve but a fully operational front-line force, and originated out of Ibn Saud's tribal military-religious force, the <a href="/wiki/Ikhwan" title="Ikhwan">Ikhwan</a>. Its modern existence, however, is attributable to it being effectively <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Abdullah of Saudi Arabia">Abdullah's</a> private army since the 1960s and, unlike the rest of the armed forces, is independent of the Ministry of Defense and Aviation. The SANG has been a counterbalance to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sudairi" title="Sudairi">Sudairi</a> faction in the royal family: The late prince Sultan, former Minister of Defense and Aviation, was one of the so-called 'Sudairi Seven' and controlled the remainder of the armed forces until his death in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[321]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_soldier_from_the_First_Brigade_Airborne_in_Al_Khubah.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="531" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Saudi_soldier_from_the_First_Brigade_Airborne_in_Al_Khubah.jpg/220px-Saudi_soldier_from_the_First_Brigade_Airborne_in_Al_Khubah.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Saudi_soldier_from_the_First_Brigade_Airborne_in_Al_Khubah.jpg/330px-Saudi_soldier_from_the_First_Brigade_Airborne_in_Al_Khubah.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Saudi_soldier_from_the_First_Brigade_Airborne_in_Al_Khubah.jpg/440px-Saudi_soldier_from_the_First_Brigade_Airborne_in_Al_Khubah.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_soldier_from_the_First_Brigade_Airborne_in_Al_Khubah.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Saudi soldiers from the First Airborne Brigade.</div></div></div>
<p>Spending on defence and security has increased significantly since the mid-1990s and was about US$78.4 billion, as of 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-327">[322]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia has one of the highest percentages of military expenditure in the world, spending around 8% of its GDP in its military, according to the 2020 <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">SIPRI</a> estimate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[323]</a></sup> Its modern high-technology arsenal makes Saudi Arabia among the world's most densely armed nations, with its military equipment being supplied primarily by the US, France, and Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Library_of_Congress_2006_323-1"><a href="#cite_note-Library_of_Congress_2006-323">[318]</a></sup>
</p><p>The United States sold more than $80 billion in military hardware between 1951 and 2006 to the Saudi military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[324]</a></sup> On 20 October 2010, the US State Department notified Congress of its intention to make the biggest arms sale in American history—an estimated $60.5 billion purchase by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.
