The package represents a considerable improvement in the offensive capability of the Saudi armed forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[325]</a></sup> 2013 saw Saudi military spending climb to $67bn, overtaking that of the UK, France and Japan to place fourth globally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AJE_2013_spending_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-AJE_2013_spending-331">[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>The United Kingdom has also been a major supplier of military equipment to Saudi Arabia since 1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[327]</a></sup> Since 1985, the UK has supplied military aircraft—notably the <a href="/wiki/Panavia_Tornado" title="Panavia Tornado">Tornado</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eurofighter_Typhoon" title="Eurofighter Typhoon">Eurofighter Typhoon</a> combat aircraft—and other equipment as part of the long-term <a href="/wiki/Al-Yamamah_arms_deal" title="Al-Yamamah arms deal">Al-Yamamah arms deal</a> estimated to have been worth £43 billion by 2006 and thought to be worth a further £40 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[328]</a></sup> In May 2012, British defence giant BAE signed a £1.9bn ($3bn) deal to supply Hawk trainer jets to Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[329]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a>, SIPRI, in 2010–14 Saudi Arabia became the world's second-largest arms importer, receiving four times more major arms than in 2005–2009. Major imports in 2010–14 included 45 combat aircraft from the UK, 38 combat helicopters from the US, four tanker aircraft from <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, and over 600 armoured vehicles from Canada. Saudi Arabia has a long list of outstanding orders for arms, including 27 more combat aircraft from the UK, 154 combat aircraft from the US, and a large number of armoured vehicles from Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.sipri.org_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.sipri.org-335">[330]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia received 41 per cent of UK arms exports in 2010–14.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[331]</a></sup> France authorized $18 billion in weapons sales to Saudi Arabia in 2015 alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Salon_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-Salon-238">[233]</a></sup> The $15 billion arms deal with Saudi Arabia is believed to be the largest arms sale in Canadian history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[332]</a></sup> In 2016, the European Parliament decided to temporarily impose an arms embargo against Saudi Arabia, as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> civilian population's suffering from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen" title="Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen">conflict with Saudi Arabia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[333]</a></sup> In 2017, Saudi Arabia signed a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017_United_States-Saudi_Arabia_Arms_Deal" title="2017 United States-Saudi Arabia Arms Deal">110 billion dollar arms deal with the United States</a>.
</p><p>Saudi Arabia is Britain's largest arms customer, with more than £4.6 billion worth of arms bought since the start of Saudi-led coalition in Yemen. A recent poll conducted by <a href="/wiki/YouGov" title="YouGov">YouGov</a> for Save the Children and <a href="/wiki/Avaaz" title="Avaaz">Avaaz</a> stated that 63 per cent of British people oppose the sale of weapons to Saudi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[334]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Killing_of_Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Killing of Jamal Khashoggi">killing of Jamal Khashoggi</a>, a nonbinding resolution was passed in the European Parliament on 25 October 2018, urging EU countries to impose an EU-wide arms embargo on Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[335]</a></sup> Germany became the first Western government to suspend future arms deal with the kingdom after <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> stated that "arms exports can't take place in the current circumstances."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[336]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the new report from the <a href="/wiki/Global_Affairs_Canada" title="Global Affairs Canada">Department of Global Affairs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> sold record-breaking amount of military hardware to Saudi Arabia in 2019, despite its poor human rights record.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[337]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Human rights in Saudi Arabia">Human rights in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia">Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_executions_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Public executions in Saudi Arabia">Public executions in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<p>The Saudi government, which mandates Muslim and non-Muslim observance of <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> law under the <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy" title="Absolute monarchy">absolute rule</a> of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">House of Saud</a>, has been denounced by various international organizations and governments for violating human rights within the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[338]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authoritarian" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a> regime ruling the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is consistently ranked among the "worst of the worst" in <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">annual survey of political and civil rights</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[339]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a>, security forces continue to torture and ill- treat detainees to extract confessions to be used as evidence against them at trial.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[340]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia abstained from the United Nations vote adopting the <a href="/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights" title="Universal Declaration of Human Rights">Universal Declaration of Human Rights</a>, saying it contradicted <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sharia_law" title="Sharia law">sharia law</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[341]</a></sup> Mass executions, such as those carried out <a href="/wiki/2016_Saudi_Arabia_mass_execution" title="2016 Saudi Arabia mass execution">in 2016</a>, <a href="/wiki/2019_Saudi_Arabia_mass_execution" title="2019 Saudi Arabia mass execution">in 2019</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2022_Saudi_Arabia_mass_execution" title="2022 Saudi Arabia mass execution">in 2022</a>, have been condemned by international rights groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anishchenkova2020_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-Anishchenkova2020-347">[342]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dira_Square.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="461" data-file-width="691" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Dira_Square.JPG/220px-Dira_Square.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Dira_Square.JPG/330px-Dira_Square.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Dira_Square.JPG/440px-Dira_Square.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dira_Square.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Deera_Square" title="Deera Square">Deera Square</a>, central Riyadh. It is a former site of public be-headings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[344]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Saudi Arabian law does not recognize sexual orientations or religious freedom, and the public practice of non-Muslim religions is actively prohibited.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[345]</a></sup> The justice system regularly engages in <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment" title="Capital punishment">capital punishment</a>, including public executions by <a href="/wiki/Decapitation" title="Decapitation">beheading</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[346]</a></sup> The death penalty can be imposed for a wide range of offenses,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[347]</a></sup> including murder, rape, armed robbery, repeated drug use, <a href="/wiki/Apostasy" title="Apostasy">apostasy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCexecutioner_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBCexecutioner-353">[348]</a></sup> adultery,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FRD306_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-FRD306-354">[349]</a></sup> witchcraft and sorcery,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Miethe_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-Miethe-355">[350]</a></sup> and can be carried out by beheading with a sword,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCexecutioner_353-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBCexecutioner-353">[348]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Stoning" title="Stoning">stoning</a> or firing squad,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FRD306_354-1"><a href="#cite_note-FRD306-354">[349]</a></sup> followed by crucifixion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Miethe_355-1"><a href="#cite_note-Miethe-355">[350]</a></sup> In April 2020, Saudi Supreme Court issued a directive to eliminate the punishment of flogging from the Saudi court system, and it is to be replaced by imprisonment or fines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[351]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[352]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi women face <a href="/wiki/Discrimination" title="Discrimination">discrimination</a> in many aspects of their lives, and under the <a href="/wiki/Wali_(Islamic_legal_guardian)" title="Wali (Islamic legal guardian)">male guardianship system</a> are effectively treated as <a href="/wiki/Minor_(law)" title="Minor (law)">legal minors</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HRW2016_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-HRW2016-358">[353]</a></sup> Although they make up 70% of those enrolled in universities, for social reasons, women make up 5% of the workforce in Saudi Arabia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[354]</a></sup> the lowest proportion in the world.
The treatment of women has been referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Sex_segregation" title="Sex segregation">sex segregation</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[356]</a></sup> and "gender <a href="/wiki/Apartheid" title="Apartheid">apartheid</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Handrahan_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-Handrahan-362">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[358]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia is a notable destination country for men and women trafficked for the purposes of <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">slave labour</a> and commercial sexual exploitation. Men and women from Central Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and many other countries voluntarily travel to Saudi Arabia as domestic servants or other low-skilled labourers, but some subsequently face conditions indicative of involuntary servitude.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-364">[359]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Geography of Saudi Arabia">Geography of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1266" data-file-width="1432" decoding="async" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png/290px-Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png/435px-Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png/580px-Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Saudi Arabia topography</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2005" data-file-width="3032" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg/220px-Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg/330px-Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg/440px-Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Harrat_Khaybar" title="Harrat Khaybar">Harrat Khaybar</a> seen from the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>. Saudi Arabia is home to more than 2000 dormant volcanoes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-365">[360]</a></sup> Lava fields in Hejaz, known locally by their Arabic name of harrat (the singular is harrah), form one of Earth's largest <a href="/wiki/Alkali_basalt" title="Alkali basalt">alkali basalt</a> regions, covering some 180,000 square kilometres (69,000 sq mi), an area greater than the state of <a href="/wiki/Missouri" title="Missouri">Missouri</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-366">[361]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Saudi Arabia occupies about 80 per cent of the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> (the world's largest peninsula),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stokes605_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-Stokes605-367">[362]</a></sup> lying between latitudes <a href="/wiki/16th_parallel_north" title="16th parallel north">16°</a> and <a href="/wiki/33rd_parallel_north" title="33rd parallel north">33° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/34th_meridian_east" title="34th meridian east">34°</a> and <a href="/wiki/56th_meridian_east" title="56th meridian east">56° E</a>. Because the country's southern borders with the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a> are not precisely marked, the exact size of the country is undefined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stokes605_367-1"><a href="#cite_note-Stokes605-367">[362]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Statistics_Division" title="United Nations Statistics Division">United Nations Statistics Division</a> estimates 2,149,690 km<sup>2</sup> (830,000 sq mi) and lists Saudi Arabia as the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">12th</a> largest state. It is geographically the largest country in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Plate" title="Arabian Plate">Arabian Plate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia's diverse geography is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Desert" title="Arabian Desert">Arabian Desert</a>, associated semi-desert, shrubland, steppes, several mountain ranges, volcanic lava fields and highlands. The 647,500 km<sup>2</sup> (250,001 sq mi) <a href="/wiki/Rub%27_al_Khali" title="Rub' al Khali">Rub' al Khali</a> ("Empty Quarter") in the southeastern part of the country is the world's largest contiguous sand desert.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-4"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[364]</a></sup> Though there are lakes in the country, Saudi Arabia is the largest country in the world by area with no permanent rivers. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wadis" title="Wadis">Wadis</a>, non-permanent rivers, however, are very numerous. The fertile areas are to be found in the alluvial deposits in wadis, basins, and oases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-5"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup> The main topographical feature is the central plateau which rises abruptly from the Red Sea and gradually descends into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nejd" title="Nejd">Nejd</a> and toward the Persian Gulf. On the Red Sea coast, there is a narrow coastal plain, known as the <a href="/wiki/Tihamah" title="Tihamah">Tihamah</a> parallel to which runs an imposing escarpment. The southwest province of <a href="/wiki/%27Asir_Province" title="'Asir Province">Asir</a> is mountainous, and contains the 3,133 m (10,279 ft) <a href="/wiki/Jabal_Sawda" title="Jabal Sawda">Mount Sawda</a>, which is the highest point in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-6"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia is home to more than 2000 dormant volcanoes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_365-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-365">[360]</a></sup> Lava fields in Hejaz, known locally by their Arabic name of harrat (the singular is harrah), form one of Earth's largest <a href="/wiki/Alkali_basalt" title="Alkali basalt">alkali basalt</a> regions, covering some 180,000 square kilometres (69,000 sq mi), an area greater than the state of <a href="/wiki/Missouri" title="Missouri">Missouri</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_366-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-366">[361]</a></sup>
</p><p>Except for the southwestern regions such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%27Asir_Region" title="'Asir Region">Asir</a>, Saudi Arabia has a <a href="/wiki/Desert_climate" title="Desert climate">desert climate</a> with very high day-time temperatures during the summer and a sharp temperature drop at night. Average summer temperatures are around 45 °C (113 °F), but can be as high as 54 °C (129 °F) at its most extreme. In the winter the temperature rarely drops below 0 °C (32 °F) with the exception of mostly the northern regions of the country where annual snowfall, in particular in the mountainous regions of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tabuk_province" title="Tabuk province">Tabuk province</a>, is not uncommon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[365]</a></sup> The lowest recorded temperature to date, −12.0 °C (10.4 °F), was measured in <a href="/wiki/Turaif" title="Turaif">Turaif</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SaudiCC_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-SaudiCC-371">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the spring and autumn the heat is temperate, temperatures average around 29 °C (84 °F). Annual rainfall is very low. The Southern regions differ in that they are influenced by the Indian Ocean <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monsoons" title="Monsoons">monsoons</a>, usually occurring between October and March. An average of 300 mm (12 in) of rainfall occurs during this period, which is about 60 per cent of the annual precipitation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weather_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-weather-372">[367]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia is home to approximately 1300 islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[368]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Wildlife of Saudi Arabia">Wildlife of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_(8454247265).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg/200px-Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg/300px-Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg/400px-Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The highly endangered <a href="/wiki/Arabian_leopard" title="Arabian leopard">Arabian leopard</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg/200px-Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg/300px-Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg/400px-Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Arabian_horse" title="Arabian horse">Arabian horse</a> is native to Arabia, and an important element of traditional Arabian folklore</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Saudi Arabia is home to five terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula_coastal_fog_desert" title="Arabian Peninsula coastal fog desert">Arabian Peninsula coastal fog desert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Arabian_foothills_savanna" title="Southwestern Arabian foothills savanna">Southwestern Arabian foothills savanna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Arabian_montane_woodlands" title="Southwestern Arabian montane woodlands">Southwestern Arabian montane woodlands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Desert" title="Arabian Desert">Arabian Desert</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_Sea_Nubo-Sindian_tropical_desert_and_semi-desert" title="Red Sea Nubo-Sindian tropical desert and semi-desert">Red Sea Nubo-Sindian tropical desert and semi-desert</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-374">[369]</a></sup>
Wildlife includes the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_leopard" title="Arabian leopard">Arabian leopard</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Judas_et_al.,_2006_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-Judas_et_al.,_2006-375">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spalton_et_al.,_2006_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-Spalton_et_al.,_2006-376">[371]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arabian_wolf" title="Arabian wolf">wolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Striped_hyena" title="Striped hyena">striped hyena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongoose" title="Mongoose">mongoose</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baboon" title="Baboon">baboon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cape_hare" title="Cape hare">hare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sand_cat" title="Sand cat">sand cat</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jerboa" title="Jerboa">jerboa</a>. Animals such as gazelles, <a href="/wiki/Oryx" title="Oryx">oryx</a>, leopards and <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_cheetah" title="Asiatic cheetah">cheetahs</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nowell1996_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nowell1996-377">[372]</a></sup> were relatively numerous until the 19th century, when extensive hunting reduced these animals almost to extinction. The culturally important <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_lion" title="Asiatic lion">Asiatic lion</a> occurred in Saudi Arabia until the late 19th century before it was hunted to extinction in the wild.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nader_al1989_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nader_al1989-378">[373]</a></sup> Birds include falcons (which are caught and trained for hunting), eagles, hawks, vultures, <a href="/wiki/Sandgrouse" title="Sandgrouse">sandgrouse</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bulbul" title="Bulbul">bulbuls</a>. There are several species of snakes, many of which are venomous. Saudi Arabia is home to a rich marine life. The Red Sea in particular is a rich and diverse <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystem</a>. More than <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fish_of_the_Red_Sea" title="Fish of the Red Sea">1200 species of fish</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fishbase_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-fishbase-379">[374]</a></sup> have been recorded in the Red Sea, and around 10 per cent of these are found nowhere else.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[375]</a></sup> This also includes 42 species of <a href="/wiki/List_of_deep_water_fish_of_the_Red_Sea" title="List of deep water fish of the Red Sea">deepwater fish</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fishbase_379-1"><a href="#cite_note-fishbase-379">[374]</a></sup>
</p><p>The rich diversity is in part due to the 2,000 km (1,240 mi) of coral reef extending along its coastline; these <a href="/wiki/Fringing_reef" title="Fringing reef">fringing reefs</a> are 5000–7000 years old and are largely formed of stony <a href="/wiki/Acropora" title="Acropora">acropora</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porites" title="Porites">porites</a> corals. The reefs form platforms and sometimes lagoons along the coast and occasional other features such as cylinders (such as the <a href="/wiki/Blue_Hole_(Red_Sea)" title="Blue Hole (Red Sea)">Blue Hole (Red Sea)</a> at <a href="/wiki/Dahab" title="Dahab">Dahab</a>). These coastal reefs are also visited by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pelagic" title="Pelagic">pelagic</a> species of Red Sea fish, including some of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sharks_in_the_Red_Sea" title="List of sharks in the Red Sea">44 species of shark</a>.
The Red Sea also contains many offshore reefs including several true atolls. Many of the unusual offshore reef formations defy classic (i.e., Darwinian) coral reef classification schemes, and are generally attributed to the high levels of tectonic activity that characterize the area.
Domesticated animals include the legendary <a href="/wiki/Arabian_horse" title="Arabian horse">Arabian horse</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabian_camel" title="Arabian camel">Arabian camel</a>, sheep, goats, cows, donkeys, chickens, etc. Reflecting the country's dominant desert conditions, Saudi Arabia's plant life mostly consists of herbs, plants, and shrubs that require little water. The date palm (<i>Phoenix dactylifera</i>) is widespread.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-7"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regions_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Regions of Saudi Arabia">Regions of Saudi Arabia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Governorates_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Governorates of Saudi Arabia">Governorates of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<p>Saudi Arabia is divided into 13 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regions" title="Regions">regions</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[376]</a></sup> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">مناطق إدارية</span>; <i>manatiq idāriyya</i>, sing. منطقة إدارية; <i><a href="/wiki/Mintaqah" title="Mintaqah">mintaqah</a> idariyya</i>). The regions are further divided into 118 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Governorates_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Governorates of Saudi Arabia">governorates</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">محافظات</span>; <i>muhafazat</i>, sing. محافظة; <i><a href="/wiki/Muhafazah" title="Muhafazah">muhafazah</a></i>). This number includes the 13 regional capitals, which have a different status as municipalities (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">أمانة</span>; <i>amanah</i>) headed by mayors (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">أمين</span>; <i>amin</i>). The governorates are further subdivided into sub-governorates (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">مراكز</span>; <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Markaz_(country_subdivision)" title="Markaz (country subdivision)">marakiz</a></i>, sing. مركز; <i>markaz</i>).
</p>
<div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><div class="noresize" role="img" style="width: 400px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1501" data-file-width="1802" decoding="async" height="333" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg/400px-Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg/600px-Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg/800px-Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg.png 2x" width="400"/></a>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:30px; top:84px"><a href="/wiki/Tabuk_Province" title="Tabuk Province">Tabuk</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:66px; top:256px"><a href="/wiki/Al-Bahah_Province" title="Al-Bahah Province">Bahah</a> —–</div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:70px; top:48px"><a href="/wiki/Al-Jawf_Province" title="Al-Jawf Province">Jawf</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:74px; top:156px"><a href="/wiki/Medina_Province_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Medina Province (Saudi Arabia)">Madinah</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:102px; top:216px"><a href="/wiki/Mecca_Province" title="Mecca Province">Makkah</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:106px; top:312px"><a href="/wiki/Jazan_Province" title="Jazan Province">Jizan</a> —</div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:118px; top:96px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%E1%B8%A4a%CA%BCil_Province" title="Ḥaʼil Province">Ha'il</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:134px; top:52px"><a href="/wiki/Northern_Borders_Province" title="Northern Borders Province">Northern<br/>Borders</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:142px; top:268px"><a href="/wiki/%27Asir_Province" title="'Asir Province">Asir</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:146px; top:128px"><a href="/wiki/Al-Qassim_Province" title="Al-Qassim Province">Qasim</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:186px; top:196px"><a href="/wiki/Riyadh_Province" title="Riyadh Province">Riyadh</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:190px; top:288px"><a href="/wiki/Najran_Province" title="Najran Province">Najran</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:274px; top:224px"><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Province,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia">Eastern Province</a></div>
</div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Economy of Saudi Arabia">Economy of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Saudi_Arabia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/260px-Saudi_Arabia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Saudi_Arabia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/390px-Saudi_Arabia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Saudi_Arabia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/520px-Saudi_Arabia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Saudi Arabia exports, 2019</div></div></div>
<p>As of October 2018, Saudi Arabia is the largest economy in the Middle East and the 18th largest in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf2_16-4"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-16">[13]</a></sup>
Saudi Arabia has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">second-largest proven petroleum reserves</a> and the country is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_exports" title="List of countries by oil exports">largest exporter of petroleum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1995_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1995-382">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[378]</a></sup> It also has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">fifth-largest proven natural gas reserves</a>. Saudi Arabia is considered an "<a href="/wiki/Energy_superpower" title="Energy superpower">energy superpower</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-undp_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-undp-384">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[380]</a></sup> It has the second highest total estimated value of natural resources, valued at US$34.4 trillion in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[381]</a></sup>
Saudi Arabia's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Command_economy" title="Command economy">command economy</a> is petroleum-based; roughly 63%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[382]</a></sup> of budget revenues and 67%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[383]</a></sup> of export earnings come from the oil industry. It is strongly dependent on foreign workers with about 80% of those employed in the private sector being non-Saudi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coy-employ_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-coy-employ-389">[384]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McDowall_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-McDowall-390">[385]</a></sup>
Challenges to the Saudi economy include halting or reversing the decline in per-capita income, improving education to prepare youth for the workforce and providing them with employment, diversifying the economy, stimulating the private sector and housing construction, and diminishing corruption and inequality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HT2009:_150_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-HT2009:_150-391">[386]</a></sup>
</p><p>The oil industry constitutes about 45% of Saudi Arabia's nominal gross domestic product, compared with 40% from the private sector (see below). Saudi Arabia officially has about 260 billion barrels (4.1<span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">×</span>10<sup>10</sup> m<sup>3</sup>) of oil reserves, comprising about one-fifth of the world's proven total petroleum reserves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[387]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1990s, Saudi Arabia experienced a significant contraction of oil revenues combined with a high rate of population growth. Per capita income fell from a high of $11,700 at the height of the oil boom in 1981 to $6,300 in 1998.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[388]</a></sup> Taking into account the impact of the real oil price changes on the kingdom's real gross domestic income, the real command-basis GDP was computed to be 330.381 billion 1999 USD in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[389]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_oil_market_chronology_from_2003" title="World oil market chronology from 2003">Increases in oil prices in the early 2000s</a> helped boost per capita GDP to $17,000 in 2007 dollars (about $7,400 adjusted for inflation),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[390]</a></sup> but have declined since oil price drop in mid-2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wti_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-wti-396">[391]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AramcoCoreArea.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="427" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/AramcoCoreArea.jpg/220px-AramcoCoreArea.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/AramcoCoreArea.jpg/330px-AramcoCoreArea.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/AramcoCoreArea.jpg/440px-AramcoCoreArea.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AramcoCoreArea.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Office of <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Aramco" title="Saudi Aramco">Saudi Aramco</a>, the world's most valuable company and the main source of revenue for the state</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a> (the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries) limits its members' oil production based on their "proven reserves." Saudi Arabia's published reserves have shown little change since 1980, with the main exception being an increase of about 100 billion barrels (1.6<span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">×</span>10<sup>10</sup> m<sup>3</sup>) between 1987 and 1988.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[392]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Matthew_Simmons" title="Matthew Simmons">Matthew Simmons</a> has suggested that Saudi Arabia is greatly exaggerating its reserves and may soon show production declines (see <a href="/wiki/Peak_oil" title="Peak oil">peak oil</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[393]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 2003 to 2013, "several key services" were privatized—municipal water supply, electricity, telecommunications—and parts of education and health care, traffic control and car accident reporting were also privatized. According to Arab News columnist Abdel Aziz Aluwaisheg, "in almost every one of these areas, consumers have raised serious concerns about the performance of these privatized entities."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aluwaisheg_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-Aluwaisheg-399">[394]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tadawul" title="Tadawul">Tadawul</a> All Share Index (TASI) of the Saudi stock exchange peaked at 16,712.64 in 2005, and closed at 8,535.60, at the end of 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MV2013_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-MV2013-400">[395]</a></sup> In November 2005, Saudi Arabia was approved as a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>. Negotiations to join had focused on the degree to which Saudi Arabia is willing to increase market access to foreign goods and in 2000, the government established the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_General_Investment_Authority" title="Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority">Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority</a> to encourage foreign direct investment in the kingdom. Saudi Arabia maintains a list of sectors in which foreign investment is prohibited, but the government plans to open some closed sectors such as telecommunications, insurance, and power transmission/distribution over time. The government has also made an attempt at "<a href="/wiki/Saudization" title="Saudization">Saudizing</a>" the economy, replacing foreign workers with Saudi nationals with limited success.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-house-161_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-house-161-401">[396]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:As_pilgrims_prepare_to_return_to_their_homes,_Saudi_authorities_begin_to_prep_for_next_year%27s_Hajj_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3216" data-file-width="2136" decoding="async" height="301" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/As_pilgrims_prepare_to_return_to_their_homes%2C_Saudi_authorities_begin_to_prep_for_next_year%27s_Hajj_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg/200px-As_pilgrims_prepare_to_return_to_their_homes%2C_Saudi_authorities_begin_to_prep_for_next_year%27s_Hajj_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/As_pilgrims_prepare_to_return_to_their_homes%2C_Saudi_authorities_begin_to_prep_for_next_year%27s_Hajj_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg/300px-As_pilgrims_prepare_to_return_to_their_homes%2C_Saudi_authorities_begin_to_prep_for_next_year%27s_Hajj_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/As_pilgrims_prepare_to_return_to_their_homes%2C_Saudi_authorities_begin_to_prep_for_next_year%27s_Hajj_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg/400px-As_pilgrims_prepare_to_return_to_their_homes%2C_Saudi_authorities_begin_to_prep_for_next_year%27s_Hajj_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:As_pilgrims_prepare_to_return_to_their_homes,_Saudi_authorities_begin_to_prep_for_next_year%27s_Hajj_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <i><a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">hajj</a></i> is an annual <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islamic</a> <a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage" title="Pilgrimage">pilgrimage</a> to <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Holiest_sites_in_Islam" title="Holiest sites in Islam">holiest city</a> for Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Modarresi_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-Modarresi-402">[397]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In addition to petroleum and gas, Saudi also has a significant gold mining sector in the ancient <a href="/wiki/Mahd_adh_Dhahab" title="Mahd adh Dhahab">Mahd adh Dhahab</a> region and significant other mineral industries, an agricultural sector (especially in the southwest but not only) based on vegetables, fruits, dates etc. and livestock, and large number of temporary jobs created by the roughly two million annual <i><a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">hajj</a></i> pilgrims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HT2009:_150_391-1"><a href="#cite_note-HT2009:_150-391">[386]</a></sup>
Saudi Arabia has had five-year "Development Plans" since 1970. Among its plans were to launch "economic cities" (e.g. <a href="/wiki/King_Abdullah_Economic_City" title="King Abdullah Economic City">King Abdullah Economic City</a>) to be completed by 2020, in an effort to diversify the economy and provide jobs. As of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> four cities were planned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MCC_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-MCC-403">[398]</a></sup> The King has announced that the per capita income is forecast to rise from $15,000 in 2006 to $33,500 in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[399]</a></sup> The cities will be spread around Saudi Arabia to promote diversification for each region and their economy, and the cities are projected to contribute $150 billion to the GDP.
</p><p>Saudi Arabia is increasingly activating its ports in order to participate in trade between Europe and China in addition to oil transport. To this end, ports such as Jeddah Islamic Port or King Abdullah Economic City are being rapidly expanded and investments are being made in logistics. The country is historically and currently part of the Maritime Silk Road that runs from the Chinese coast to the south via the southern tip of India to Mombasa, from there through the Red Sea via the Suez Canal to the Mediterranean, there to the Upper Adriatic region to the northern Italian hub of <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a> with its rail connections to <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a>, Eastern Europe and the North Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[401]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[403]</a></sup>
</p><p>Statistics on poverty in the kingdom are not available through the UN resources because the Saudi government does not issue any.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[404]</a></sup> The Saudi state discourages calling attention to or complaining about poverty. In December 2011, the Saudi interior ministry arrested three reporters and held them for almost two weeks for questioning after they uploaded a video on the topic to YouTube.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[407]</a></sup> Authors of the video claim that 22 per cent of Saudis may be considered poor (2009).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[408]</a></sup> Observers researching the issue prefer to stay anonymous<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[409]</a></sup> because of the risk of being arrested.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2666" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg/220px-KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg/330px-KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg/440px-KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>King Abdullah Financial Center is one of the largest investment centres in the Middle East, located in Riyadh</div></div></div>
<p>In September 2018, the Public Investment Fund completed a deal with a group of global lenders for a loan of $11 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[410]</a></sup> The deal raised more than initially planned and was the first time the PIF had incorporated loans and debt instruments into its funding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blooms_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-blooms-416">[411]</a></sup> According to data from Fitch Ratings, over two years starting from May 2016 Saudi Arabia went from having zero debt to raising $68 billion in dollar-denominated bonds and syndicated loans—one of the fastest rates among emerging economies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[412]</a></sup>
</p><p>Each year, about a quarter-million young Saudis enter the job market. With the first phase of Saudization into effect, 70% of sales jobs are expected to be filled by Saudis. However, the private sector still remains hugely dominated by foreigners. The rate of local unemployment is 12.9%, its highest in more than a decade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blooms_416-1"><a href="#cite_note-blooms-416">[411]</a></sup> According to a report published by Bloomberg Economics in 2018, the government needs to produce 700,000 jobs by 2020 to meet its 9% unemployment target.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blooms_416-2"><a href="#cite_note-blooms-416">[411]</a></sup>
</p><p>The unexpected impact of <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> on the economy, along with Saudi Arabia's poor human rights records, laid unforeseen challenges before the development plans of the kingdom, where some of the programs under '<a href="/wiki/Saudi_Vision_2030" title="Saudi Vision 2030">Vision 2030</a>' were also expected to be affected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[413]</a></sup> On 2 May, the Finance Minister of Saudi Arabia admitted that the country's economy was facing a severe economical crisis for the first time in decades, due to the pandemic as well as declining global oil markets. <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Al-Jadaan" title="Mohammed Al-Jadaan">Mohammed Al-Jadaan</a> said that the country will take "painful" measures and keep all options open to deal with the impact.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[414]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Agriculture in Saudi Arabia">Agriculture in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa,_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9,_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8,_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG/220px-Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG/330px-Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG/440px-Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa,_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9,_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8,_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Al-Ahsa_Oasis" title="Al-Ahsa Oasis">Al-Hasa</a> is known for its palm trees and dates. Al-Hasa has over 30 million palm trees which produce over 100 thousand tons of dates every year.</div></div></div>
<p>Serious large-scale agricultural development began in the 1970s. The government launched an extensive program to promote modern farming technology; to establish rural roads, irrigation networks and storage and export facilities; and to encourage agricultural research and training institutions.
As a result, there has been a phenomenal growth in the production of all basic foods. Saudi Arabia is now completely self-sufficient in a number of foodstuffs, including meat, milk, and eggs.
The country exports wheat, dates, dairy products, eggs, fish, poultry, fruits, vegetables, and flowers to markets around the world. Dates, once a staple of the Saudi diet, are now mainly grown for global humanitarian aid.
In addition, Saudi farmers grow substantial amounts of other grains such as barley, sorghum, and millet. As of 2016, in the interest of preserving precious water resources, domestic production of wheat has ended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[415]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Kingdom likewise has some of the most modern and largest dairy farms in the Middle East. Milk production boasts a remarkably productive annual rate of 6,800 litres (1,800 US gallons) per cow, one of the highest in the world. The local dairy manufacturing company <a href="/wiki/Almarai" title="Almarai">Almarai</a> is the largest vertically integrated dairy company in the Middle East.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[416]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Kingdom's most dramatic agricultural accomplishment, noted worldwide, was its rapid transformation from importer to exporter of wheat. In 1978, the country built its first grain silos. By 1984, it had become self-sufficient in wheat. Shortly thereafter, Saudi Arabia began exporting wheat to some 30 countries, including China and the former Soviet Union, and in the major producing areas of Tabuk, Hail, and Qasim, average yields reached 8.1 tonnes per hectare (3.6 short ton/acre).
The Kingdom has, however, stepped up fruit and vegetable production, by improving both agricultural techniques and the roads that link farmers with urban consumers. Saudi Arabia is a major exporter of fruits and vegetables to its neighbours. Among its most productive crops are watermelon, grapes, citrus fruits, onions, squash, and tomatoes. At Jizan in the country's well-watered southwest, the Al-Hikmah Research Station is producing tropical fruits including pineapples, paw-paws, bananas, mangoes, and guavas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[417]</a></sup>
</p><p>The olive tree is indigenous to Saudi Arabia. In 2018, the Al Jouf Agricultural Development Company received a certificate of merit from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Guinness_World_Records" title="The Guinness World Records">The Guinness World Records</a> for the largest modern olive plantation in the world. The farm covers 7730 hectares and has 5 million olive trees. Also, the Guinness World Records took their production capacity of 15000 tonnes of high-quality olive oil into consideration, while the kingdom consumes double that.
The Al Jouf farms are located in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sakaka" title="Sakaka">Sakaka</a>, a city in the north-western part of Saudi Arabia, which is a deeply-rooted in history. Sakaka dates back more than 4,000 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[418]</a></sup> The Al Jouf region has millions of olive trees and the expected number is expected to go up to 20 million trees soon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[419]</a></sup> Consuming non-renewable groundwater resulted in the loss of an estimated four-fifths of the total groundwater reserves by 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[420]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Water supply and sanitation in Saudi Arabia">Water supply and sanitation in Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Irrigation_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Irrigation in Saudi Arabia">Irrigation in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Water supply and sanitation in Saudi Arabia">Water supply and sanitation in Saudi Arabia</a> is characterized by challenges and achievements. One of the main challenges is <a href="/wiki/Water_scarcity" title="Water scarcity">water scarcity</a>. In order to overcome water scarcity, substantial investments have been undertaken in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Water_desalination" title="Water desalination">seawater desalination</a>, water distribution, sewerage and <a href="/wiki/Wastewater_treatment" title="Wastewater treatment">wastewater treatment</a>. Today about 50% of drinking water comes from desalination, 40% from the mining of non-renewable groundwater and only 10% from surface water in the mountainous southwest of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[421]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia is suffering from a major depletion of the water in its underground aquifers and a resultant break down and disintegration of its agriculture as a consequence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[422]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[423]</a></sup> As a result of the catastrophe, Saudi Arabia has bought agricultural land in the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[424]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[425]</a></sup> Argentina,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[426]</a></sup> and Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[427]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[428]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[429]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[430]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia ranked as a major buyer of agricultural land in foreign countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[432]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the Joint Monitoring Program (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WHO" title="WHO">WHO</a> and <a href="/wiki/UNICEF" title="UNICEF">UNICEF</a>, the latest reliable source on access to water and sanitation in Saudi Arabia is the 2004 census. It indicates that 97% of the population had access to an improved source of drinking water and 99% had access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">improved sanitation</a>. For 2015, the JMP estimates that access to sanitation increased to 100%. Sanitation was primarily through on-site solutions and only about 40% of the population was connected to sewers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JMP_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-JMP-438">[433]</a></sup> In 2015, still 886 thousand people lacked access to "improved" water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[434]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[435]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Tourism in Saudi Arabia">Tourism in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<p>Although most tourism in Saudi Arabia still largely involves religious pilgrimages, there is growth in the leisure tourism sector. According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, approximately 14.3 million people visited Saudi Arabia in 2012, making it the world's 19th-most-visited country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[436]</a></sup> Tourism is an important component of the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Vision_2030" title="Saudi Vision 2030">Saudi Vision 2030</a> and according to a report conducted by BMI Research in 2018, both religious and non-religious tourism have significant potential for expansion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[437]</a></sup>
</p><p>
Starting December 2018, the kingdom offers an electronic visa for foreign visitors to attend sports events and concerts. The "sharek" visa process started on 15 December 2018 when the Saudi Ad Diriyah E Prix race started.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[438]</a></sup> In September 2019, the kingdom announced its plans to open visa applications for visitors, where people from about 50 countries would be able to get tourist visas to Saudi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[439]</a></sup> In January 2020, it was announced that holders of a <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">US</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">UK</a> or <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen</a> visa are eligible for a Saudi electronic visa upon arrival.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[440]</a></sup></p><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px"><div style="width: 182px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_old_city_of_Adummatu.jpg" title="The 3000-year-old ancient historical city of Dumat al-Jandal in Al Jawf Province"><img alt="The 3000-year-old ancient historical city of Dumat al-Jandal in Al Jawf Province" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/The_old_city_of_Adummatu.jpg/270px-The_old_city_of_Adummatu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/The_old_city_of_Adummatu.jpg/405px-The_old_city_of_Adummatu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/The_old_city_of_Adummatu.jpg/540px-The_old_city_of_Adummatu.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>

</p>

</p>

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"><div style="width: 162px">

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"><div style="width: 162px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rub_al_khalid_sunset_nov_07.JPG" title="The desert of Al-Rub' Al-Khali (The Empty Quarter)"><img alt="The desert of Al-Rub' Al-Khali (The Empty Quarter)" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Rub_al_khalid_sunset_nov_07.JPG/240px-Rub_al_khalid_sunset_nov_07.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Rub_al_khalid_sunset_nov_07.JPG/360px-Rub_al_khalid_sunset_nov_07.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Rub_al_khalid_sunset_nov_07.JPG/480px-Rub_al_khalid_sunset_nov_07.JPG 2x" width="160"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The desert of <a href="/wiki/Rub%27_al_Khali" title="Rub' al Khali"><i>Al-Rub' Al-Khali</i> (The Empty Quarter)</a>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_people" title="Saudi Arabian people">Saudi Arabian people</a> and <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Demographics of Saudi Arabia">Demographics of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="930" data-file-width="1001" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png/220px-Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png/330px-Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png/440px-Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Saudi Arabia population density (people per km<sup>2</sup>)</div></div></div>
<p>The population of Saudi Arabia as of July 2013 is estimated to be 26.9 million, including between 5.5 million<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_7-2"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-7">[5]</a></sup> and 10 million non-nationalized immigrants,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McDowall_390-1"><a href="#cite_note-McDowall-390">[385]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[441]</a></sup> though the Saudi population has long proved difficult to accurately estimate due to Saudi leaders' historical tendency to inflate census results.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[442]</a></sup> Saudi population has grown rapidly since 1950 when it was estimated to be 3 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[443]</a></sup> and for many years had one of the highest population growth rates in the world at around 3 per cent a year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-long-27_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-long-27-449">[444]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ethnic composition of Saudi citizens is 90% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab" title="Arab">Arab</a> and 10% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afro-Arab" title="Afro-Arab">Afro-Arab</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[445]</a></sup> Most Saudis live in the Hejaz (35%), Najd (28%), and the Eastern Province (15%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[446]</a></sup> Hejaz is the most populated region in Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[447]</a></sup>
</p><p>As late as 1970, most Saudis lived a subsistence life in the rural provinces, but in the last half of the 20th century, the kingdom has urbanized rapidly. As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> about 80% of Saudis live in urban metropolitan areas—specifically Riyadh, Jeddah, or Dammam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[448]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[449]</a></sup>
</p><p>Its population is also quite young with over half the population under 25 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[450]</a></sup> A large fraction are foreign nationals. (The CIA Factbook estimated that as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> foreign nationals living in Saudi Arabia made up about 21% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_7-3"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-7">[5]</a></sup> Other estimates are 30%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[451]</a></sup> or 33%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alriyadh.com_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-alriyadh.com-457">[452]</a></sup>) Immigrants make up 38.3% of the total population, according to UN data (2019), mostly coming from the Middle East, Asia, and Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[453]</a></sup> As recently as the early 1960s, Saudi Arabia's slave population was estimated at 300,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[454]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/History_of_slavery_in_the_Muslim_world" title="History of slavery in the Muslim world">Slavery</a> was officially abolished in 1962.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-460">[455]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-461">[456]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">

</tbody></table></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<p>The official language of Saudi Arabia is <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>. The three main regional variants spoken by Saudis are <a href="/wiki/Najdi_Arabic" title="Najdi Arabic">Najdi Arabic</a> (about 14.6 million speakers<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[467]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Hejazi_Arabic" title="Hejazi Arabic">Hejazi Arabic</a> (about 10.3 million speakers<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[468]</a></sup>), and <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Arabic" title="Gulf Arabic">Gulf Arabic</a> (about 0.96 million speakers<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[469]</a></sup>). <a href="/wiki/Faifi_language" title="Faifi language">Faifi</a> is spoken by about 50,000. The <a href="/wiki/Mehri_language" title="Mehri language">Mehri language</a> is also spoken by around 20,000 <a href="/wiki/Mehri_people" title="Mehri people">Mehri</a> citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[470]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Sign_Language" title="Saudi Sign Language">Saudi Sign Language</a> is the principal language of the deaf community, amounting to around 100,000 speakers. The large expatriate communities also speak their own languages, the most numerous of which, according to 2018 data, are <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a> (~1,500,000), <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a> (~900,000), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Punjabi_language" title="Eastern Punjabi language">Eastern Punjabi</a> (~800,000), <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> (~740,000), <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Arabic" title="Egyptian Arabic">Egyptian Arabic</a> (~600,000), <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_language" title="Rohingya language">Rohingya</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Levantine_Arabic" title="North Levantine Arabic">North Levantine Arabic</a> (both ~500,000)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[471]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Malayalam" title="Malayalam">Malayalam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[472]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religions">Religions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Religion in Saudi Arabia">Religion in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<p>Virtually all Saudi citizens are Muslim<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[473]</a></sup> (officially, all are), and almost all Saudi residents are Muslim.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewForump.17_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-PewForump.17-479">[474]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[475]</a></sup> Estimates of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunni" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> population of Saudi Arabia range between 85% and 90%, with the remaining 10–15% being <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shia" title="Shia">Shia</a> Muslim,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[476]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PF2009_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-PF2009-482">[477]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-shia_483-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-shia-483">[478]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cfr-shiite_484-0"><a href="#cite_note-cfr-shiite-484">[479]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nasr2006_p._236_485-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nasr2006_p._236-485">[480]</a></sup> practicing either <a href="/wiki/Twelver_Shi%27ism" title="Twelver Shi'ism">Twelver Shi'ism</a> or <a href="/wiki/Sulaymani" title="Sulaymani">Sulaymani Ismailism</a>. The official and dominant form of Sunni Islam in Saudi Arabia is commonly known as <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[481]</a></sup> (proponents prefer the name <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salafism" title="Salafism">Salafism</a>, considering <i>Wahhabi</i> derogatory<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Daily_Star_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Daily_Star-487">[482]</a></sup>), which was founded in the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Abd_al-Wahhab" title="Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab">Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab</a> in the 18th century. Other denominations, such as the minority <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia Islam</a>, are systematically suppressed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[483]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to estimates there are about 1,500,000 <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Christianity in Saudi Arabia">Christians</a> in Saudi Arabia, almost all foreign workers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[484]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia allows Christians to enter the country as foreign workers for temporary work, but does not allow them to practice their faith openly. The percentage of Saudi Arabian citizens who are Christians is officially zero,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[485]</a></sup> as Saudi Arabia forbids religious conversion from Islam (apostasy) and punishes it by death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[486]</a></sup> According to Pew Research Center there are 390,000 <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus">Hindus</a> in Saudi Arabia, almost all foreign workers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[487]</a></sup> There may be a significant fraction of <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostics</a> in Saudi Arabia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gallup_493-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gallup-493">[488]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[489]</a></sup> although they are officially called "terrorists".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[490]</a></sup> In its 2017 religious freedom report, the US State Department named Saudi Arabia a Country of Particular Concern (CPC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[491]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Education in Saudi Arabia">Education in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="867" data-file-width="1384" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg/220px-KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg/330px-KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg/440px-KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Laboratory buildings at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/KAUST" title="KAUST">KAUST</a></div></div></div>
