<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="599" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG/220px-Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG/330px-Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG/440px-Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Yamamah_Private_University" title="Al-Yamamah Private University">Al-Yamamah Private University</a> in Riyadh</div></div></div>
<p>Education is free at all levels, although higher education is restricted to citizens only.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[492]</a></sup> The school system is composed of elementary, intermediate, and secondary schools. Classes are segregated by sex. At secondary level, students are able to choose from 3 types of schools: general education, vocational and technical, or religious.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[493]</a></sup> The rate of literacy is 99% among males and 96% among females in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[494]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[495]</a></sup> For the youth, literacy rate rose up to approximately 99.5% for both sexes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[496]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[497]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the educational plan for secondary (high school) education 1435–1438 <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Hijri</a>, students enrolling in the "natural sciences" path are required to take five religion subjects which are: <a href="/wiki/Tawhid" title="Tawhid">Tawhid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fiqh" title="Fiqh">Fiqh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tafsir" title="Tafsir">Tafseer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">Hadith</a> and Islamic Education and Quran. However, in 2021 the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Ministry of Education (Saudi Arabia)">Saudi Ministry of Education</a> merged the multiple Islamic subjects into one single book as part of a series of reforms to revamp the school education system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[498]</a></sup> In addition, students are required to take six science subjects which are Maths, Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Geology and Computer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[499]</a></sup>
</p><p>Higher education has expanded rapidly, with large numbers of <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_colleges_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="List of universities and colleges in Saudi Arabia">universities and colleges being founded particularly since 2000</a>. Institutions of higher education include the country's first university, <a href="/wiki/King_Saud_University" title="King Saud University">King Saud University</a> founded in 1957, the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_University_of_Madinah" title="Islamic University of Madinah">Islamic University</a> at <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a> founded in 1961, and the <a href="/wiki/King_Abdulaziz_University" title="King Abdulaziz University">King Abdulaziz University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jeddah" title="Jeddah">Jeddah</a> founded in 1967. <a href="/wiki/Princess_Nora_bint_Abdul_Rahman_University" title="Princess Nora bint Abdul Rahman University">Princess Norah University</a>, the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Women%27s_university" title="Women's university">women's university</a> in the world, was founded in 1970. <a href="/wiki/King_Abdullah_University_of_Science_and_Technology" title="King Abdullah University of Science and Technology">King Abdullah University of Science and Technology</a>, known as KAUST, is the first mixed-gender university campus in Saudi Arabia and was founded in 2009. Other colleges and universities emphasize curricula in sciences and technology, military studies, religion, and medicine. Institutes devoted to Islamic studies, in particular, abound. Women typically receive college instruction in segregated institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-8"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="318" data-file-width="403" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png/220px-UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png/330px-UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/85/UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Institute_for_Statistics" title="UNESCO Institute for Statistics">UIS</a> literacy rate Saudi Arabia population, 15 plus, 1990–2015</div></div></div>
<p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">Academic Ranking of World Universities</a></i>, known as Shanghai Ranking, ranked 4 Saudi institutions among its 2021 list of the 500 top universities in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[500]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a> lists 14 Saudi universities among the 2022 world’s top universities and 23 universities among the top 100 in the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[501]</a></sup> The 2022 list of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report_Best_Global_University_Ranking" title="U.S. News &amp; World Report Best Global University Ranking">U.S. News &amp; World Report Best Global University Ranking</a> ranked King Abdulaziz University among the top 50 universities in the world and King Abdullah University of Science and Technology among the top 100 universities in the world.
</p><p>In 2018, Saudi Arabia ranked 28th worldwide in terms of high-quality research output according to the scientific journal <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a>.</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[502]</a></sup>
This makes Saudi Arabia the best performing Middle Eastern, Arab, and Muslim country.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Saudi Arabia spends 8.8% of its gross domestic product on education, compared with the global average of 4.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[503]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia was ranked 66th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021, up from 68th in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[504]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[505]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[507]</a></sup>
</p><p>Memorization by rote of large parts of the Qur'an, its interpretation and understanding (<a href="/wiki/Tafsir" title="Tafsir">Tafsir</a>) and the application of Islamic tradition to everyday life is at the core of the curriculum. Religion taught in this manner is also a compulsory subject for all University students.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[508]</a></sup> As a consequence, Saudi youth "generally lacks the education and technical skills the private sector needs" according to the CIA.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_7-4"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-7">[5]</a></sup> Similarly, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Chronicle_of_Higher_Education" title="The Chronicle of Higher Education">The Chronicle of Higher Education</a></i> wrote in 2010 that "the country needs educated young Saudis with marketable skills and a capacity for innovation and entrepreneurship. That's not generally what Saudi Arabia's educational system delivers, steeped as it is in rote learning and religious instruction."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chronicle.com_514-0"><a href="#cite_note-chronicle.com-514">[509]</a></sup>
</p><p>The religious sector of the Saudi national curriculum was examined in a 2006 report by <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> which concluded that "the Saudi public school religious curriculum continues to propagate an ideology of hate toward the 'unbeliever', that is, Christians, Jews, Shiites, Sufis, Sunni Muslims who do not follow Wahhabi doctrine, Hindus, atheists and others".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FH-education_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-FH-education-515">[510]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[511]</a></sup> The Saudi religious studies curriculum is taught outside the kingdom via Saudi-linked <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madrasah" title="Madrasah">madrasah</a>, schools, and clubs throughout the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Panorama_2010_517-0"><a href="#cite_note-Panorama_2010-517">[512]</a></sup> Critics have described the education system as "medieval" and that its primary goal "is to maintain the rule of absolute monarchy by casting it as the ordained protector of the faith, and that Islam is at war with other faiths and cultures".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[513]</a></sup> This radical teaching takes place in Saudi funded mosques and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madrasas" title="Madrasas">madrasas</a> across the Islamic world from Morocco to Pakistan to Indonesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[514]</a></sup>
</p><p>The approach taken in the Saudi education system has been accused of encouraging <a href="/wiki/Islamic_terrorism" title="Islamic terrorism">Islamic terrorism</a>, leading to reform efforts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reforming_Saudi_Education_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reforming_Saudi_Education-520">[515]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[516]</a></sup> Following the 9/11 attacks, the government aimed to tackle the twin problems of encouraging extremism and the inadequacy of the country's university education for a modern economy, by slowly modernising the education system through the "Tatweer" reform program.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reforming_Saudi_Education_520-1"><a href="#cite_note-Reforming_Saudi_Education-520">[515]</a></sup> The Tatweer program is reported to have a budget of approximately US$2 billion and focuses on moving teaching away from the traditional Saudi methods of memorization and rote learning towards encouraging students to analyse and problem-solve. It also aims to create an education system which will provide a more secular and vocationally based training.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chronicle.com_514-1"><a href="#cite_note-chronicle.com-514">[509]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[517]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2021, the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Washington_Post" title="Washington Post">Washington Post</a></i> newspaper published a report on the measures taken by Saudi Arabia to clean textbooks from paragraphs considered <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism" title="Antisemitism">antisemitic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sexism" title="Sexism">sexist</a>. The paragraphs dealing with the punishment of <a href="/wiki/Homosexuality" title="Homosexuality">homosexuality</a> or same-sex relations have been deleted, and expressions of admiration for the extremist martyrdom. Antisemitic expressions and calls to fight the Jews became fewer. David Weinberg, director of international affairs for the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Defamation_League" title="Anti-Defamation League">Anti-Defamation League</a>, said that references to demonizing Jews, Christians, and Shiites have been removed from some places or have toned down, noting the deletion of paragraphs that talk about killing gays, <a href="/wiki/Infidel" title="Infidel">infidels</a> and <a href="/wiki/Witchcraft" title="Witchcraft">witches</a>. The US State Department expressed in an email that it welcomed the changes to the materials affecting Saudi educational curricula. The Saudi Ministry of Foreign Affairs supports a training program for Saudi teachers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[518]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care">Health care</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Health in Saudi Arabia">Health in Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Health care in Saudi Arabia">Health care in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Life_expectancy_in_Saudi_Arabia.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="850" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Life_expectancy_in_Saudi_Arabia.svg/220px-Life_expectancy_in_Saudi_Arabia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Life_expectancy_in_Saudi_Arabia.svg/330px-Life_expectancy_in_Saudi_Arabia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Life_expectancy_in_Saudi_Arabia.svg/440px-Life_expectancy_in_Saudi_Arabia.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Life_expectancy_in_Saudi_Arabia.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Historical development of life expectancy in Saudi Arabia</div></div></div>
<p>Health care in Saudi Arabia is a national health care system in which the government provides free health care services through a number of government agencies. Saudi Arabia has been ranked among the 26 best countries in providing high quality healthcare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[519]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Saudi <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Ministry of Health (Saudi Arabia)">Ministry of Health</a> (MOH) is the major <a href="/wiki/Government" title="Government">government</a> agency entrusted with the provision of preventive, curative, and rehabilitative health care for the kingdom's population. The Ministry's origins can be traced to 1925, when a number of regional health departments were established, with the first in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Makkah" title="Makkah">Makkah</a>, Saudi Arabia. The various healthcare institutions were merged to become a ministerial body in 1950.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[520]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abdullah_bin_Faisal_Al_Saud" title="Abdullah bin Faisal Al Saud">Abdullah bin Faisal Al Saud</a> was the first health minister and served in the position for three years, with his main role to set up the newly formed Ministry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[521]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Health Ministry created a friendly <a href="/wiki/Competition" title="Competition">competition</a> between each of the districts, and between different medical services and hospitals. This idea resulted in the creation of the "Ada'a" project launched in 2016. The new system is a nationwide performance indicator, for services and hospitals. Following the implementation of the new KPI tables, waiting times and other major measurements improved dramatically across the Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[522]</a></sup>
</p><p>A new strategy has been developed by the Ministry, known as Diet and Physical Activity Strategy or DPAS for short.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[523]</a></sup> Many lifestyle issues in the country were causing bad lifestyle choices. This led to the Ministry advising that there should be a <a href="/wiki/Tax" title="Tax">tax</a> increase on unhealthy food, drink and also cigarettes in the region. This additional tax could be utilized to improve healthcare offerings. The tax was implemented in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[524]</a></sup> As part of the same strategy, calorie labels were added in 2019 to a number of food and drink products. Ingredients were also listed, not as an aim to reduce obesity, but also for citizens with health issues, to manage their diet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[525]</a></sup> As part of the ongoing focus on tackling obesity, women-only gyms were allowed to open in 2017. A number of sports were offered in each of these gyms, including <a href="/wiki/Bodybuilding" title="Bodybuilding">bodybuilding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Running" title="Running">running</a> and <a href="/wiki/Swimming" title="Swimming">swimming</a> to maintain higher standards of health.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[526]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[527]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Smoking_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Smoking in Saudi Arabia">Smoking in Saudi-Arabia</a> in all age groups was widespread. In 2009 the lowest median percentage of smokers was university students (~13.5%) while the highest was elderly people (~25%). The study also found the median percentage of male smokers to be much higher than that of females (~26.5% for males, ~9% for females). Before 2010, Saudi Arabia had no policies banning or restricting smoking.
</p><p>The MOH has been awarded "Healthy City" certificates by the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) for the cities of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unayzah" title="Unayzah">Unayzah</a> and <a href="/wiki/Riyadh_Al_Khabra" title="Riyadh Al Khabra">Riyadh Al Khabra</a> as 4th and 5th Healthy Cities in Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[528]</a></sup>
The WHO had earlier classified three Saudi Arabian cities, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ad_Diriyah" title="Ad Diriyah">Ad Diriyah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jalajil" title="Jalajil">Jalajil</a>, and Al-Jamoom as "Healthy city", as part of the WHO Healthy Cities Program. Recently <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al-Baha" title="Al-Baha">Al-Baha</a> has also been classified as a healthy city to join the list of global healthy cities approved by the World Health Organization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[529]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2019, the then Saudi Minister of Health <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tawfig_AlRabiah" title="Tawfig AlRabiah">Dr. Tawfiq bin Fawzan AlRabiah</a> received a global award on behalf of the Kingdom for combatting smoking through social awareness, treatment, and application of regulations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-smokingaward_535-0"><a href="#cite_note-smokingaward-535">[530]</a></sup> The award was presented as part of the 72nd session of the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Assembly" title="World Health Assembly">World Health Assembly</a>, held in Geneva in May 2019. After becoming one of the first nations to ratify the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control in 2005, it plans to reduce tobacco use from 12.7% in 2017, to 5% in 2030.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-smokingaward_535-1"><a href="#cite_note-smokingaward-535">[530]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia has a life expectancy of 74.99 years (73.79 for males and 76.61 for females) according to the latest data for the year 2018 from the World Bank.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_536-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-536">[531]</a></sup> Infant mortality in 2019 was 5.7 per 1,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_536-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-536">[531]</a></sup> In 2016, 69.7% of the adult population was overweight and 35.5% was obese.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[532]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreigners">Foreigners</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_workers_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Foreign workers in Saudi Arabia">Foreign workers in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Migrant_workers_in_the_Gulf_region" title="Migrant workers in the Gulf region">Migrant workers in the Gulf region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kafala_system" title="Kafala system">Kafala system</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Foreign_worker" title="Foreign worker">Foreign worker</a></div>
<p>Saudi Arabia's Central Department of Statistics &amp; Information estimated the foreign population at the end of 2014 at 33% (10.1 million).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CDSI_538-0"><a href="#cite_note-CDSI-538">[533]</a></sup> The CIA Factbook estimated that as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> foreign nationals living in Saudi Arabia made up about 21% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_7-5"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-7">[5]</a></sup> Other sources report differing estimates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alriyadh.com_457-1"><a href="#cite_note-alriyadh.com-457">[452]</a></sup> Indian: 1.5 million, Pakistani: 1.3 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[534]</a></sup> Egyptian: 900,000, Yemeni: 800,000, Bangladeshi: 400,000, Filipino: 500,000, Jordanian/Palestinian: 260,000, Indonesian: 250,000, Sri Lankan: 350,000, Sudanese: 250,000, Syrian: 100,000 and Turkish: 80,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540"><a href="#cite_note-540">[535]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>, as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were more than half a million <a href="/wiki/Migrant_domestic_workers" title="Migrant domestic workers">foreign-born domestic workers</a> in Saudi Arabia. Most have backgrounds in poverty and come from Africa, the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-the_guardian1_541-0"><a href="#cite_note-the_guardian1-541">[536]</a></sup> To go to work in Saudi Arabia, they must often pay large sums to recruitment agencies in their home countries. The agencies then handle the necessary legal paperwork.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-humanrightswatch1_542-0"><a href="#cite_note-humanrightswatch1-542">[537]</a></sup>
</p><p>As the Saudi population grows and oil export revenues stagnate, pressure for "Saudization" (the replacement of foreign workers with Saudis) has grown, and the Saudi government hopes to decrease the number of foreign nationals in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[538]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia expelled 800,000 Yemenis in 1990 and 1991<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[539]</a></sup> and has built a <a href="/wiki/Saudi%E2%80%93Yemen_barrier" title="Saudi–Yemen barrier">Saudi–Yemen barrier</a> against an influx of illegal immigrants and against the smuggling of drugs and weapons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[540]</a></sup> In November 2013, Saudi Arabia expelled thousands of illegal Ethiopian residents from the kingdom. Various Human Rights entities have criticized Saudi Arabia's handling of the issue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[541]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over 500,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Illegal immigration in Saudi Arabia">undocumented migrant workers</a> — mostly from Somalia, Ethiopia, and Yemen — have been detained and deported since 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[542]</a></sup> An investigation led by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sunday_Telegraph" title="The Sunday Telegraph">The Sunday Telegraph</a></i>, exposed the condition of African migrants who were detained in Saudi Arabia allegedly for containing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019" title="Coronavirus disease 2019">COVID-19</a> in the kingdom. They were beaten, tortured, and electrocuted. Many of the migrants died due to heatstroke or by attempting suicide, after being severely beaten and tortured. The migrants lack proper living conditions, provision of food and water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[543]</a></sup>
</p><p>Foreigners cannot apply for <a href="/wiki/Permanent_residency" title="Permanent residency">permanent residency</a>, though a specialized <a href="/wiki/Premium_Residency" title="Premium Residency">Premium Residency</a> visa became available in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[544]</a></sup> Only Muslims can become Saudi citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[545]</a></sup> Foreigners who have resided in the kingdom and hold degrees in various scientific fields may apply for Saudi citizenship,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[546]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[547]</a></sup> and exception made for Palestinians who are excluded unless married to a male Saudi national, because of <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> instructions barring the Arab states from granting them citizenship. Saudi Arabia is not a signatory to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Convention_relating_to_the_Status_of_Refugees" title="Convention relating to the Status of Refugees">1951 UN Refugee Convention</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[548]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Culture of Saudi Arabia">Culture of Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<p>Saudi Arabia has centuries-old attitudes and traditions, often derived from Arab civilization. The main factors that influence the culture of Saudi Arabia are Islamic heritage and Bedouin traditions as well as its historical role as an ancient trade centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[549]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion_in_society">Religion in society</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Religion in Saudi Arabia">Religion in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Islam in Saudi Arabia">Islam in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Freedom of religion in Saudi Arabia">Freedom of religion in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salafism" title="Salafism">Salafism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca,_Saudi_Arabia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/220px-Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/330px-Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/440px-Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca,_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Supplicating <a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage#Islam" title="Pilgrimage">pilgrim</a> at <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Mecca" title="Great Mosque of Mecca">Al-Masjid Al-Ḥarām</a></i> (The Sacred Mosque) in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Kaaba" title="Kaaba">Kaaba</a> is the cubic building in front of the pilgrim.</div></div></div>
<p>Religion is a core aspect of everyday life in Saudi Arabia. It plays a dominant role in the country's governance and legal system, deeply influences culture and daily life, although the power of the religious establishment has been significantly eroded in the 2010s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_29-1"><a href="#cite_note-:3-29">[24]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> region, where the <a href="/wiki/Holiest_sites_in_Islam" title="Holiest sites in Islam">Islamic holy cities</a> of Mecca and Medina are located, is the destination of the <a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">Ḥajj</a> pilgrimage, and often deemed to be the cradle of Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Arabia:_the_Cradle_of_Islam_555-0"><a href="#cite_note-Arabia:_the_Cradle_of_Islam-555">[550]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-566"><a href="#cite_note-566">[f]</a></sup>
</p><p>Islam is the state religion of Saudi Arabia. There is no law that requires all citizens to be Muslim, but non-Muslims and many foreign and Saudi Muslims whose beliefs are deemed not to conform with the government's interpretation of Islam must practice their religion in private and are vulnerable to discrimination, harassment, detention, and, for foreigners, deportation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-567"><a href="#cite_note-567">[561]</a></sup> Neither Saudi citizens nor guest workers have the right of <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-depstate_568-0"><a href="#cite_note-depstate-568">[562]</a></sup> The dominant form of Islam in the kingdom—<a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a>—arose in the central region of Najd, in the 18th century. Proponents call the movement "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salafism" title="Salafism">Salafism</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Daily_Star_487-1"><a href="#cite_note-The_Daily_Star-487">[482]</a></sup> and believe that its teachings purify the practice of Islam of innovations or practices that deviate from the seventh-century teachings of Muhammad and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sahaba" title="Sahaba">his companions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-569"><a href="#cite_note-569">[563]</a></sup> The Saudi government has often been viewed as an active oppressor of <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia Muslims</a> because of the funding of the Wahhabi ideology which denounces the Shia faith.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-570"><a href="#cite_note-570">[564]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-syedjaffar_571-0"><a href="#cite_note-syedjaffar-571">[565]</a></sup> Prince <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bandar_bin_Sultan" title="Bandar bin Sultan">Bandar bin Sultan</a>, Saudi ambassador to the United States, stated: "The time is not far off in the Middle East when it will be literally 'God help the Shia'. More than a billion Sunnis have simply had enough of them."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[566]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia is one of the few countries that have "<a href="/wiki/Committee_for_the_Promotion_of_Virtue_and_the_Prevention_of_Vice_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice (Saudi Arabia)">religious police</a>" (known as <i>Haia</i> or <i>Mutaween</i>), who patrol the streets "<a href="/wiki/Enjoining_good_and_forbidding_wrong" title="Enjoining good and forbidding wrong">enjoining good and forbidding wrong</a>" by enforcing <a href="/wiki/Clothing_laws_by_country" title="Clothing laws by country">dress codes</a>, strict <a href="/wiki/Sex_segregation" title="Sex segregation">separation of men and women</a>, attendance at prayer (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salat" title="Salat">salat</a></i>) five times each day, the ban on alcohol, and other aspects of <i><a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a></i> (Islamic law). However, since 2016 the power of <a href="/wiki/Committee_for_the_Promotion_of_Virtue_and_the_Prevention_of_Vice_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice (Saudi Arabia)">religious police</a> was curbed, which barred them from pursuing, questioning, requesting identification or arresting suspects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-france24.com_573-0"><a href="#cite_note-france24.com-573">[567]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_319-1"><a href="#cite_note-:4-319">[314]</a></sup> In the privacy of homes, behaviour can be far looser, and reports from <a href="/wiki/WikiLeaks" title="WikiLeaks">WikiLeaks</a> indicate that low ranked members of the ruling Saudi Royal family indulge in parties with alcohol, drugs, and prostitutes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-574"><a href="#cite_note-574">[568]</a></sup>
</p><p>Until 2016, the kingdom only used the lunar <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Islamic calendar</a>, not the international <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian calendar</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-575"><a href="#cite_note-575">[569]</a></sup> but in 2016 the kingdom announced its switch to the Gregorian calendar for civil purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-576"><a href="#cite_note-576">[570]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[571]</a></sup> Daily life is influenced by Islamic observance. Some businesses decide to close three or four times a day<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-578"><a href="#cite_note-578">[572]</a></sup> for 30 to 45 minutes during business hours while employees and customers are sent off to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salat" title="Salat">pray</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-579"><a href="#cite_note-579">[573]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HT2009:_214_580-0"><a href="#cite_note-HT2009:_214-580">[574]</a></sup> The weekend is Friday-Saturday, not Saturday-Sunday because Friday is the holiest day for Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-9"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581"><a href="#cite_note-581">[575]</a></sup> For many years only two religious holidays were publicly recognized – <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%CA%BF%C4%AAd_al-Fi%E1%B9%ADr" title="ʿĪd al-Fiṭr">ʿĪd al-Fiṭr</a></i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%CA%BF%C4%AAd_al-A%E1%B8%8D%E1%B8%A5%C4%81" title="ʿĪd al-Aḍḥā">ʿĪd al-Aḍḥā</a></i>. (<i>ʿĪd al-Fiṭr</i> is "the biggest" holiday, a three-day period of "feasting, gift-giving and general letting go").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HT2009:35_582-0"><a href="#cite_note-HT2009:35-582">[576]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2004, approximately half of the broadcast airtime of Saudi <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Saudi_Arabia#State-managed_stations" title="Television in Saudi Arabia">state television</a> was devoted to religious issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyrob-relig-educ_583-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyrob-relig-educ-583">[577]</a></sup> 90 per cent of books published in the kingdom were on religious subjects, and most of the doctorates awarded by its universities were in Islamic studies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyrob-relig-books_584-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyrob-relig-books-584">[578]</a></sup> In the state school system, about half of the material taught is religious. In contrast, assigned readings over 12 years of primary and secondary schooling devoted to covering the history, literature, and cultures of the non-Muslim world come to a total of about 40 pages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyrob-relig-educ_583-1"><a href="#cite_note-nyrob-relig-educ-583">[577]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Not_for_us_(3975139168).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg/220px-Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg/330px-Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg/440px-Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Not_for_us_(3975139168).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Non-Muslims are prohibited from entering the Islamic holy city of Mecca</div></div></div>
<p>"Fierce religious resistance" had to be overcome to permit such innovations as paper money (in 1951), female education (1964), and television (1965) and the abolition of slavery (1962).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[579]</a></sup> Public support for the traditional political/religious structure of the kingdom is so strong that one researcher interviewing Saudis found virtually no support for reforms to secularize the state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[580]</a></sup>
</p><p>Celebration of other (non-Wahhabi) Islamic holidays, such as the <a href="/wiki/Mawlid" title="Mawlid">Muhammad's birthday</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Day_of_Ashura" title="Day of Ashura">Day of Ashura</a>, (an important holiday for the 10–25 per cent of the population<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PF2009_482-1"><a href="#cite_note-PF2009-482">[477]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-shia_483-1"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-shia-483">[478]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cfr-shiite_484-1"><a href="#cite_note-cfr-shiite-484">[479]</a></sup> that is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shia" title="Shia">Shīʿa</a> Muslim), are tolerated only when celebrated locally and on a small scale.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statsKSA_587-0"><a href="#cite_note-statsKSA-587">[581]</a></sup> Shias also face systematic discrimination in employment, education, the justice system according to Human Rights Watch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[582]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589"><a href="#cite_note-589">[583]</a></sup> Non-Muslim festivals like Christmas, Easter, Halloween, and New Year were not tolerated until recently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-590"><a href="#cite_note-590">[584]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-591"><a href="#cite_note-591">[585]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[586]</a></sup> No churches, temples or other non-Muslim houses of worship are permitted in the country. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proselytizing" title="Proselytizing">Proselytizing</a> by non-Muslims and <a href="/wiki/Apostasy_in_Islam" title="Apostasy in Islam">conversion by Muslims to another religion</a> is illegal,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irf2010_593-0"><a href="#cite_note-irf2010-593">[587]</a></sup> and as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the distribution of "publications that have prejudice to any other religious belief other than Islam" (such as <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bibles</a>), was reportedly punishable by death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-594"><a href="#cite_note-594">[588]</a></sup> In legal compensation court cases (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diyya" title="Diyya">Diyya</a></i>) non-Muslim are awarded less than Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Times_595-0"><a href="#cite_note-Times-595">[589]</a></sup> Atheists are legally designated as terrorists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-596"><a href="#cite_note-596">[590]</a></sup> At least one religious minority, the <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">Ahmadiyya</a> Muslims, had its adherents deported,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-597"><a href="#cite_note-597">[591]</a></sup> as they are legally banned from entering the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-598"><a href="#cite_note-598">[592]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a recent move to promote a modern image, Saudi Arabia banned the religious group known as 'Tablighi Jamaat'. The announcement was made on social media by the country's <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Islamic_Affairs" title="Ministry of Islamic Affairs">Minister of Islamic Affairs</a> who warned people against association during the Friday sermon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-599"><a href="#cite_note-599">[593]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Women_in_society">Women in society</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Women's rights in Saudi Arabia">Women's rights in Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_education_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Women's education in Saudi Arabia">Women's education in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sarah_Attar_Rio2016.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1438" data-file-width="620" decoding="async" height="394" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Sarah_Attar_Rio2016.jpg/170px-Sarah_Attar_Rio2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Sarah_Attar_Rio2016.jpg/255px-Sarah_Attar_Rio2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Sarah_Attar_Rio2016.jpg/340px-Sarah_Attar_Rio2016.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sarah_Attar_Rio2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sarah_Attar" title="Sarah Attar">Sarah Attar</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Track_and_field" title="Track and field">track and field</a> athlete who competed at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a> as one of the first two female Olympians representing Saudi Arabia.</div></div></div>
<p>Throughout history, women did not have equal rights to men in the kingdom; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._State_Department" title="U.S. State Department">U.S. State Department</a> considers Saudi Arabian government's discrimination against women a "significant problem" in Saudi Arabia and notes that women have few political rights due to the government's discriminatory policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-State2010_600-0"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-600">[594]</a></sup> However, since <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mohammed_bin_Salman,_Crown_Prince_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Mohammed bin Salman, Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia">Mohammed bin Salman</a> was appointed <a href="/wiki/Crown_Prince_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia">Crown Prince</a> in 2017, a series of social reforms have been witnessed regarding women's rights.
</p><p>Under previous Saudi law, all females were required to have a male guardian (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Wali_(Islamic_legal_guardian)" title="Wali (Islamic legal guardian)">wali</a></i></span>), typically a father, brother, husband, or uncle (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">mahram</i></span>). In 2019, this law was partially amended to exclude women over 21 years old from the requirement of a male guardian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:22_601-0"><a href="#cite_note-:22-601">[595]</a></sup> The new amendment also granted women rights in relation to the guardianship of minor children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:22_601-1"><a href="#cite_note-:22-601">[595]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:32_602-0"><a href="#cite_note-:32-602">[596]</a></sup> Previously, girls and women were forbidden from traveling, conducting official business, or undergoing certain medical procedures without permission from their male guardians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hrw-permission_603-0"><a href="#cite_note-hrw-permission-603">[597]</a></sup> In 2019, Saudi Arabia allowed women to travel abroad, register for divorce or marriage, and apply for official documents without the permission of a male guardian.
</p><p>In 2006, <a href="/wiki/Wajeha_al-Huwaider" title="Wajeha al-Huwaider">Wajeha al-Huwaider</a>, a leading Saudi feminist and journalist said "Saudi women are weak, no matter how high their status, even the 'pampered' ones among them, because they have no law to protect them from attack by anyone."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-604"><a href="#cite_note-604">[598]</a></sup> Following this, Saudi Arabia implemented the anti-<a href="/wiki/Domestic_violence_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Domestic violence in Saudi Arabia">domestic violence</a> law in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-605"><a href="#cite_note-605">[599]</a></sup> Furthermore, between 2017 and 2020, the country addressed issues of mobility, sexual harassment, pensions, and employment-discrimination protections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[600]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-607"><a href="#cite_note-607">[601]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-608"><a href="#cite_note-608">[602]</a></sup>  al-Huwaider and other female activists have applauded the general direction in which the country was headed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-609"><a href="#cite_note-609">[603]</a></sup>
</p><p>Women face discrimination in the courts, where the testimony of one man equals that of two women <a href="/wiki/Legal_system_of_Saudi_Arabia#Family_law" title="Legal system of Saudi Arabia">in family and inheritance law</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-State2010_600-1"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-600">[594]</a></sup> Polygamy is permitted for men,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-610"><a href="#cite_note-610">[604]</a></sup> and men have a unilateral right to divorce their wives (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Divorce_(Islamic)" title="Divorce (Islamic)">talaq</a>) without needing any legal justification.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Otto164_611-0"><a href="#cite_note-Otto164-611">[605]</a></sup> A woman can only obtain a divorce with the consent of her husband or judicially if her husband has harmed her.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Otto163_612-0"><a href="#cite_note-Otto163-612">[606]</a></sup> However, in 2022, women were granted the right to divorce and without the approval of a legal guardian under the new Personal Status Law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-613"><a href="#cite_note-613">[607]</a></sup> With regard to the law of inheritance, the Quran specifies that fixed portions of the deceased's estate must be left to the <i>Qur'anic heirs</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Otto165_614-0"><a href="#cite_note-Otto165-614">[608]</a></sup> and generally, female heirs receive half the portion of male heirs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Otto165_614-1"><a href="#cite_note-Otto165-614">[608]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obesity is a problem among middle and upper-class Saudis who have domestic servants to do traditional work but, until 2018, women were forbidden to drive and so they were limited in their ability to leave their home.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-beliefs_615-0"><a href="#cite_note-beliefs-615">[609]</a></sup> As of April 2014, Saudi authorities in the education ministry have been asked by the Shoura Council to consider lifting a state school ban on sports for girls with the proviso that any sports conform to Sharia rules on dress and gender segregation, according to the official SPA news agency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McDowall_390-2"><a href="#cite_note-McDowall-390">[385]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Islamic_religious_police" title="Islamic religious police">religious police</a>, known as the <i>mutawa</i>, imposed many restrictions on women in public in Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-State2010_600-2"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-600">[594]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dammer_616-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dammer-616">[610]</a></sup> The restrictions include forcing women to sit in separate specially designated family sections in restaurants, to wear an <a href="/wiki/Abaya" title="Abaya">abaya</a> and to cover their hair.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-State2010_600-3"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-600">[594]</a></sup> However, in 2016, the <a href="/wiki/Consultative_Assembly_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia">Saudi cabinet</a> has drastically reduced the power of the religious police and barred it "from pursuing, questioning, asking for identification, arresting and detaining anyone suspected of a crime", making them effectively "non-existent" in the public sphere anymore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-france24.com_573-1"><a href="#cite_note-france24.com-573">[567]</a></sup>
</p><p>A few Saudi women have risen to the top of the medical profession; for example, Dr. <a href="/wiki/Adah_Almutairi" title="Adah Almutairi">Ghada Al-Mutairi</a> heads a medical research centre in California<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alarabiya.net_617-0"><a href="#cite_note-alarabiya.net-617">[611]</a></sup> and Dr. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salwa_Al-Hazzaa" title="Salwa Al-Hazzaa">Salwa Al-Hazzaa</a> is head of the ophthalmology department at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_Faisal_Specialist_Hospital" title="King Faisal Specialist Hospital">King Faisal Specialist Hospital</a> in Riyadh and was the late King Fahad's personal ophthalmologist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-618"><a href="#cite_note-618">[612]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Heritage_sites">Heritage sites</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_early_Islamic_heritage_sites_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Destruction of early Islamic heritage sites in Saudi Arabia">Destruction of early Islamic heritage sites in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Tourism in Saudi Arabia">Tourism in Saudi Arabia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Heritage_Preservation_Society" title="Saudi Heritage Preservation Society">Saudi Heritage Preservation Society</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mecca_2012.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1832" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Mecca_2012.jpg/220px-Mecca_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Mecca_2012.jpg/330px-Mecca_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Mecca_2012.jpg/440px-Mecca_2012.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mecca_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Masjid_al-Haram" title="Masjid al-Haram">Masjid al-Haram</a> is the holiest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic" title="Islamic">Islamic</a> site, located in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a></div></div></div>
<p>Saudi <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a> is hostile to any reverence given to historical or religious places of significance for fear that it may give rise to <a href="/wiki/Shirk_(Islam)" title="Shirk (Islam)">'shirk'</a> (idolatry), and the most significant historic Muslim sites (in Mecca and Medina) are located in the western Saudi region of the Hejaz.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Arabia:_the_Cradle_of_Islam_555-1"><a href="#cite_note-Arabia:_the_Cradle_of_Islam-555">[550]</a></sup> As a consequence, under Saudi rule, an estimated 95% of Mecca's historic buildings, most over a thousand years old, <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_early_Islamic_heritage_sites_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Destruction of early Islamic heritage sites in Saudi Arabia">have been demolished</a> for religious reasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-619"><a href="#cite_note-619">[613]</a></sup> Critics claim that over the last 50 years, 300 historic sites linked to Muhammad, his family or companions have been lost,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-620"><a href="#cite_note-620">[614]</a></sup> leaving fewer than 20 structures remaining in Mecca that date back to the time of Muhammad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-independent.co.uk_621-0"><a href="#cite_note-independent.co.uk-621">[615]</a></sup> Demolished structures include the mosque originally built by Muhammad's daughter <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fatima_bint_Muhammad" title="Fatima bint Muhammad">Fatima</a>, and other mosques founded by <a href="/wiki/Abu_Bakr" title="Abu Bakr">Abu Bakr</a> (Muhammad's father-in-law and the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caliph" title="Caliph">Caliph</a>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Umar_ibn_al-Khattab" title="Umar ibn al-Khattab">Umar</a> (the second Caliph), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ali_ibn_Abi_Talib" title="Ali ibn Abi Talib">Ali</a> (Muhammad's son-in-law and the fourth Caliph), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salman_al-Farsi" title="Salman al-Farsi">Salman al-Farsi</a> (another of Muhammad's companions).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-622"><a href="#cite_note-622">[616]</a></sup>
</p><p>Six cultural sites in Saudi Arabia are designated as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites" title="UNESCO World Heritage Sites">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>: Al-Hijr Archaeological Site (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mada%27in_Saleh" title="Mada'in Saleh">Madâin Sâlih</a>);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-623"><a href="#cite_note-623">[617]</a></sup> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turaif_district" title="Turaif district">Turaif district</a> in the city of Diriyah;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-624"><a href="#cite_note-624">[618]</a></sup> Historic Jeddah, the Gate to Mecca;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-625"><a href="#cite_note-625">[619]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al-Ahsa_Oasis" title="Al-Ahsa Oasis">Al-Ahsa Oasis</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-626"><a href="#cite_note-626">[620]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rock_Art_in_the_Ha%27il_Region" title="Rock Art in the Ha'il Region">Rock Art in the Hail Region</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-627"><a href="#cite_note-627">[621]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Bir_Hima_Rock_Petroglyphs_and_Inscriptions" title="Bir Hima Rock Petroglyphs and Inscriptions">Ḥimā Cultural Area</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-628"><a href="#cite_note-628">[622]</a></sup> Ten other sites submitted requests for recognition to UNESCO in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-629"><a href="#cite_note-629">[623]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MasjidNabawi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="4320" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/MasjidNabawi.jpg/220px-MasjidNabawi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/MasjidNabawi.jpg/330px-MasjidNabawi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/MasjidNabawi.jpg/440px-MasjidNabawi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MasjidNabawi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mosque_of_the_Prophet" title="Mosque of the Prophet">Mosque of the Prophet</a> in <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a> containing the tomb of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a></div></div></div>
<p>There are six elements inscribed on <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">UNESCO's Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity list</a>:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-630"><a href="#cite_note-630">[624]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al-Qatt_Al-Asiri" title="Al-Qatt Al-Asiri">Al-Qatt Al-Asiri</a>, female traditional interior wall decoration in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%27Asir_Region" title="'Asir Region">Asir</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Almezmar_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Almezmar in Saudi Arabia">Almezmar</a>, drumming and dancing with sticks; <a href="/wiki/Falconry" title="Falconry">Falconry</a>, a living human heritage; <a href="/wiki/Arabic_coffee" title="Arabic coffee">Arabic coffee</a>, a symbol of generosity; <a href="/wiki/Majlis" title="Majlis">Majlis</a>, a cultural and social space; Alardah Alnajdiyah, dance, drumming and poetry in Saudi Arabia.
</p><p>In June 2014, the Council of Ministers approved a law that gives the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Commission_for_Tourism_and_National_Heritage" title="Saudi Commission for Tourism and National Heritage">Saudi Commission for Tourism and National Heritage</a> the means to protect Saudi Arabia's ancient relics and historic sites. Within the framework of the 2016 National Transformation Program, also known as <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Vision_2030" title="Saudi Vision 2030">Saudi Vision 2030</a>, the kingdom allocated 900 million euros to preserve its historical and cultural heritage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-631"><a href="#cite_note-631">[625]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia also participates in the International Alliance for the Protection of Heritage in Conflict Areas (ALIPH), created in March 2017, with a contribution of 18.5 million euros.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-632"><a href="#cite_note-632">[626]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017, Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman promised to return Saudi Arabia to the "moderate Islam" of the era before the 1979 Iranian revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-633"><a href="#cite_note-633">[627]</a></sup> A new centre, the King Salman Complex for the Prophet's Hadith, was established that year to monitor interpretations of the Prophet Mohammed's hadiths to prevent them being used to justifying terrorism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-634"><a href="#cite_note-634">[628]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2018, the Crown Prince met the Archbishop of Canterbury during a visit to the UK, pledging to promote interfaith dialogue. In Riyadh the following month King Salman met the head of the Vatican's Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-635"><a href="#cite_note-635">[629]</a></sup> In July 2019, UNESCO signed a letter with the Saudi Minister of Culture in which Saudi Arabia contributed US$25 million to UNESCO for the preservation of heritage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-636"><a href="#cite_note-636">[630]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dress">Dress</span></h3>
<p>Saudi Arabian dress strictly follows the principles of <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">hijab</a> (the Islamic principle of modesty, especially in dress). The predominantly loose and flowing, but covering, garments are suited to Saudi Arabia's desert climate. Traditionally, men usually wear a white ankle-length garment woven from wool or cotton (known as a <a href="/wiki/Thawb" title="Thawb">thawb</a>), with a <a href="/wiki/Keffiyeh" title="Keffiyeh">keffiyeh</a> (a large checkered square of cotton held in place by an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agal" title="Agal">agal</a>) or a <a href="/wiki/Keffiyeh" title="Keffiyeh">ghutra</a> (a plain white square made of a finer cotton, also held in place by an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agal" title="Agal">agal</a>) worn on the head. For rare chilly days, Saudi men wear a camel-hair cloak (<a href="/wiki/Bisht_(clothing)" title="Bisht (clothing)">bisht</a>) over the top. In public women are required to wear a black <a href="/wiki/Abaya" title="Abaya">abaya</a> or other black clothing that covers everything under the neck with the exception of their hands and feet, although most women cover their head in respect of their religion. This requirement applies to non-Muslim women too and failure to abide can result in police action, particularly in more conservative areas of the country. Women's clothes are often decorated with tribal motifs, coins, sequins, metallic thread, and appliques.
</p>
<ul><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghutrah" title="Ghutrah">Ghutrah</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">غتره</span>) is a traditional <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Headdress" title="Headdress">headdress</a> typically worn by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab" title="Arab">Arab</a> men. It is made of a square of cloth ("scarf"), usually cotton, folded and wrapped in various styles around the head. It is commonly worn in areas with an <a href="/wiki/Arid" title="Arid">arid</a> climate, to provide protection from direct <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sun_exposure" title="Sun exposure">sun exposure</a>, and also protection of the mouth and eyes from blown dust and <a href="/wiki/Sand" title="Sand">sand</a>.</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agal" title="Agal">Agal</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">عقال</span>) is an item of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab" title="Arab">Arab</a> headgear constructed of cord which is fastened around the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghutrah" title="Ghutrah">Ghutrah</a> to hold it in place. The <i>agal</i> is usually black in colour.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Thawb" title="Thawb">Thawb</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ثوب</span>) is the standard Arabic word for garment. It is ankle-length, usually with long sleeves, similar to a <a href="/wiki/Robe" title="Robe">robe</a>.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bisht_(clothing)" title="Bisht (clothing)">Bisht</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">بشت</span>) is a traditional Arabic men's <a href="/wiki/Cloak" title="Cloak">cloak</a> usually only worn for prestige on special occasions such as weddings.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Abaya" title="Abaya">Abaya</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">عبائة</span>) is a woman's garment. It is a black cloak that loosely covers the entire body except for the head. Some women choose to cover their faces with a niqāb and some do not. Some abayas cover the top of the head as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-637"><a href="#cite_note-637">[631]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts_and_entertainment">Arts and entertainment</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_art" title="Saudi Arabian art">Saudi Arabian art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Cinema of Saudi Arabia">Cinema of Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Music of Saudi Arabia">Music of Saudi Arabia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Theatre_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Theatre in Saudi Arabia">Theatre in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="606" data-file-width="481" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg/180px-King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg/270px-King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg/360px-King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>King Abdullah practising <a href="/wiki/Falconry" title="Falconry">falconry</a>, a traditional pursuit in the country</div></div></div>
<p>During the 1970s, cinemas were numerous in the kingdom although they were seen as contrary to Wahhabi norms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Return_of_cinema_in_Saudi_Arabia_provokes_critics_638-0"><a href="#cite_note-Return_of_cinema_in_Saudi_Arabia_provokes_critics-638">[632]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_revival" title="Islamic revival">Islamic revival</a> movement in the 1980s, and as a political response to an increase in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamist" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> activism including the 1979 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Mosque_Seizure" title="Grand Mosque Seizure">seizure of the Grand Mosque in Mecca</a>, the government closed all cinemas and theatres. However, with King Abdullah and King Salman's reforms, cinemas re-opened,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-639"><a href="#cite_note-639">[633]</a></sup> including one in <a href="/wiki/King_Abdullah_University_of_Science_and_Technology" title="King Abdullah University of Science and Technology">KAUST</a>.
</p><p>From the 18th century onward, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wahhabi" title="Wahhabi">Wahhabi</a> fundamentalism discouraged artistic development inconsistent with its teaching. In addition, Sunni Islamic prohibition of creating representations of people have limited the visual arts, which tend to be dominated by <a href="/wiki/Islamic_geometric_patterns" title="Islamic geometric patterns">geometric</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabesque_(Islamic_art)" title="Arabesque (Islamic art)">floral</a>, and abstract designs and by <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calligraphy" title="Islamic calligraphy">calligraphy</a>. With the advent of the oil-wealth in the 20th century came exposure to outside influences, such as Western housing styles, furnishings, and clothes. Music and dance have always been part of Saudi life. Traditional music is generally associated with poetry and is sung collectively. Instruments include the <a href="/wiki/Rebab" title="Rebab">rabābah</a>, an instrument not unlike a three-string fiddle, and various types of percussion instruments, such as the ṭabl (drum) and the ṭār (tambourine). Of the native dances, the most popular is a martial line dance known as the <a href="/wiki/Ardah" title="Ardah">arḍah</a>, which includes lines of men, frequently armed with swords or rifles, dancing to the beat of drums and tambourines. Bedouin poetry, known as nabaṭī, is still very popular.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-10"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Censorship has limited the development of Saudi literature, although several <a href="/wiki/List_of_Saudi_Arabian_writers" title="List of Saudi Arabian writers">Saudi novelists and poets</a> have achieved critical and popular acclaim in the Arab world—albeit generating official hostility in their home country. These include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghazi_Algosaibi" title="Ghazi Algosaibi">Ghazi Algosaibi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mansour_al-Nogaidan" title="Mansour al-Nogaidan">Mansour al-Nogaidan</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abdelrahman_Munif" title="Abdelrahman Munif">Abdelrahman Munif</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turki_al-Hamad" title="Turki al-Hamad">Turki al-Hamad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rajaa_al-Sanea" title="Rajaa al-Sanea">Rajaa al-Sanea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guardian2410_640-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian2410-640">[634]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-641"><a href="#cite_note-641">[635]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-642"><a href="#cite_note-642">[636]</a></sup> In 2016, the General Entertainment Authority was formed to oversee the expansion of the Saudi entertainment sector.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-643"><a href="#cite_note-643">[637]</a></sup>
The first concerts in Riyadh for 25 years took place the following year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-644"><a href="#cite_note-644">[638]</a></sup> Other events since the GEA's creation have included comedy shows, professional wrestling events and monster truck rallies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-645"><a href="#cite_note-645">[639]</a></sup> In 2018 the first public cinema opened after a ban of 35 years, with plans to have more than 2,000 screens running by 2030.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-646"><a href="#cite_note-646">[640]</a></sup>
</p><p>Developments in the arts in 2018 included Saudi Arabia's debut appearances at the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Biennale" title="Venice Biennale">Venice Biennale</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-647"><a href="#cite_note-647">[641]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-648"><a href="#cite_note-648">[642]</a></sup> Guetta's comments come as Saudi Arabia increasingly attracts big name western music acts to perform in the kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-649"><a href="#cite_note-649">[643]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_cuisine" title="Saudi Arabian cuisine">Saudi Arabian cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ArabicCoffee.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="753" data-file-width="576" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/ArabicCoffee.jpg/150px-ArabicCoffee.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/ArabicCoffee.jpg/225px-ArabicCoffee.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/ArabicCoffee.jpg/300px-ArabicCoffee.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ArabicCoffee.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Arabic_coffee" title="Arabic coffee">Arabic coffee</a> is a traditional beverage in Arabian cuisine</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_cuisine" title="Saudi Arabian cuisine">Saudi Arabian cuisine</a> is similar to that of the surrounding countries in the Arabian Peninsula and the wider Arab world, and has influenced and been influenced by Turkish, Indian, Persian, and African food. <a href="/wiki/Islamic_dietary_laws" title="Islamic dietary laws">Islamic dietary laws</a> are enforced: pork is not allowed and other animals are slaughtered in accordance with <a href="/wiki/Halal" title="Halal">halal</a>. Kebabs and falafel are popular, as is <i>shāwarmā</i> (<a href="/wiki/Shawarma" title="Shawarma">shawarma</a>), a marinated grilled meat dish of lamb, mutton, or chicken. As in other Arab countries of the Arabian Peninsula, <i>machbūs</i> (<a href="/wiki/Kabsa" title="Kabsa">kabsa</a>), a rice dish with lamb, chicken, fish or shrimp, is among the national dishes as well as the dish <a href="/wiki/Mandi_(food)" title="Mandi (food)">mandi</a>. Flat, unleavened <a href="/wiki/Taboon_bread" title="Taboon bread">taboon bread</a> is a staple of virtually every meal, as are dates, fresh fruit, yoghurt, and hummus. Coffee, served in the <a href="/wiki/Arabic_coffee" title="Arabic coffee">Arabic style</a>, is the traditional beverage but tea and various fruit juices are popular as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-11"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup> Arabic coffee is a traditional beverage in Arabian cuisine. The earliest substantiated evidence of either <a href="/wiki/History_of_coffee" title="History of coffee">coffee drinking</a> or knowledge of the coffee tree is from the 15th century, in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sufi" title="Sufi">Sufi</a> monasteries of Arabia.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Sport in Saudi Arabia">Sport in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_sport_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Women's sport in Saudi Arabia">Women's sport in Saudi Arabia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_at_the_Olympics" title="Saudi Arabia at the Olympics">Saudi Arabia at the Olympics</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A_march_URU-KSA_-_Anthems.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2752" data-file-width="4896" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A_march_URU-KSA_-_Anthems.jpg/220px-2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A_march_URU-KSA_-_Anthems.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A_march_URU-KSA_-_Anthems.jpg/330px-2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A_march_URU-KSA_-_Anthems.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A_march_URU-KSA_-_Anthems.jpg/440px-2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A_march_URU-KSA_-_Anthems.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A_march_URU-KSA_-_Anthems.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Uruguay – Saudi Arabia match at the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a> in Russia</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Football_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Football in Saudi Arabia">Football</a> is the national sport in Saudi Arabia. The <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_national_football_team" title="Saudi Arabia national football team">Saudi Arabia national football team</a> is considered one of Asia's most successful national teams, having reached a joint record 6 <a href="/wiki/AFC_Asian_Cup" title="AFC Asian Cup">AFC Asian Cup</a> finals, winning three of those finals (1984, 1988, and 1996) and having qualified for the World Cup four consecutive times ever since debuting at the 1994 tournament.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1994 FIFA World Cup">1994 FIFA World Cup</a> under the leadership of Jorge Solari, Saudi Arabia beat both Belgium and Morocco in the group stage before falling to defeat Sweden in the round of 16. During the <a href="/wiki/1992_King_Fahd_Cup" title="1992 King Fahd Cup">1992 FIFA Confederations Cup</a>, which was played in Saudi Arabia, the country reached the <a href="/wiki/1992_King_Fahd_Cup_Final" title="1992 King Fahd Cup Final">final</a>, losing 1–3 to Argentina.
<a href="/wiki/Scuba_diving" title="Scuba diving">Scuba diving</a>, <a href="/wiki/Windsurfing" title="Windsurfing">windsurfing</a>, sailing and basketball (which is played by both men and women) are also popular with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_national_basketball_team" title="Saudi Arabia national basketball team">Saudi Arabian national basketball team</a> winning bronze at the <a href="/wiki/1999_ABC_Championship" title="1999 ABC Championship">1999 Asian Championship</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-650"><a href="#cite_note-650">[644]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-651"><a href="#cite_note-651">[645]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-652"><a href="#cite_note-652">[646]</a></sup> More traditional sports such as <a href="/wiki/Horse_racing" title="Horse racing">horse racing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Camel_racing" title="Camel racing">camel racing</a> are also popular. A stadium in Riyadh holds races in the winter. The annual King's Camel Race, begun in 1974, is one of the sport's most important contests and attracts animals and riders from throughout the region. <a href="/wiki/Falconry" title="Falconry">Falconry</a>, another traditional pursuit, is still practised.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_156-12"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-156">[151]</a></sup>
