</p><p>Women's sport is controversial due to the suppression of female participation in sport by conservative Islamic religious authorities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-653"><a href="#cite_note-653">[647]</a></sup> however this restriction has eased slightly in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-654"><a href="#cite_note-654">[648]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-655"><a href="#cite_note-655">[649]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-656"><a href="#cite_note-656">[650]</a></sup> Until 2018 women were not permitted in sport stadiums. Segregated seating, allowing women to enter, has been developed in three stadiums across major cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-657"><a href="#cite_note-657">[651]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia, in its vision for modernization, introduced the nation to a number of international sporting events, bringing sports stars to the kingdom. However, in August 2019, the kingdom's strategy received criticism for appearing as a method of <a href="/wiki/Sportswashing" title="Sportswashing">sportswashing</a> soon after Saudi's US-based 2018 lobbying campaign foreign registration documentations got published online. The documents showed Saudi Arabia as allegedly implementing a 'sportswashing' strategy, inclusive of meetings and official calls with supreme authorities of associations like the Major League Soccer (MLS), World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE), National Basketball Association (NBA). The strategy is being viewed as a method of sportswashing following the chaos spread across Yemen for 6 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-658"><a href="#cite_note-658">[652]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="TV_and_Media">TV and Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Mass_media_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Mass media in Saudi Arabia">Mass media in Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Television in Saudi Arabia">Television in Saudi Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:199px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saad_Khadr_from_left_and_right_Mohammad_Al-Ali_in_1979_in_Saudi_Arabia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="161" data-file-width="197" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/92/Saad_Khadr_from_left_and_right_Mohammad_Al-Ali_in_1979_in_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" width="197"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saad_Khadr_from_left_and_right_Mohammad_Al-Ali_in_1979_in_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Saad_Khader" title="Saad Khader">Saad Khader</a> from left and right <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Al-Ali" title="Mohammad Al-Ali">Mohammad Al-Ali</a> in 1979</div></div></div>
<p>Television was introduced in Saudi Arabia in 1954. Saudi Arabia is a major market for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pan-Arab_States" title="Pan-Arab States">pan-Arab</a> satellite and <a href="/wiki/Pay_television" title="Pay television">pay-TV</a>. It controls the largest share of the pan-Arab broadcasting market; among the major Saudi-owned broadcasting companies are the <a href="/wiki/MBC_Group" title="MBC Group">Middle East Broadcasting Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rotana_Group" title="Rotana Group">Rotana</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Broadcasting_Authority" title="Saudi Broadcasting Authority">Saudi Broadcasting Authority</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-obg_659-0"><a href="#cite_note-obg-659">[653]</a></sup> The Saudi government closely monitors media and restricts it under official state law. Changes have been made to lessen these restrictions; however, some government-led efforts to control information have also drawn international attention. As of 2022, <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> rates the kingdom's press "Very Serious" situation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-660"><a href="#cite_note-660">[654]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of the early <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Newspapers" title="Newspapers">newspapers</a> in the Persian Gulf region were established in Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aarti_661-0"><a href="#cite_note-aarti-661">[655]</a></sup> The first newspaper founded in the country and in the Persian Gulf area is <a href="/wiki/Al_Fallah" title="Al Fallah">Al Fallah</a>, which was launched in 1920,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aarti_661-1"><a href="#cite_note-aarti-661">[655]</a></sup> and the first English-language newspaper is <a href="/wiki/Arab_News" title="Arab News">Arab News</a>, which was launched in 1975.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-662"><a href="#cite_note-662">[656]</a></sup> All of the newspapers published in Saudi Arabia are privately owned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-663"><a href="#cite_note-663">[657]</a></sup>
</p><p>Saudi Arabia received access to the <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">Internet</a> in 1994.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-664"><a href="#cite_note-664">[658]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, as of 2020, 98% of the population of Saudi Arabia are Internet users which puts it in the 8th rank among countries with the highest percentage of internet users.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-665"><a href="#cite_note-665">[659]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia has one of the fastest <a href="/wiki/5G" title="5G">5G</a> internet speeds in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-666"><a href="#cite_note-666">[660]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-667"><a href="#cite_note-667">[661]</a></sup> The kingdom is also the 27th largest market for <a href="/wiki/E-commerce" title="E-commerce">e-commerce</a> with a revenue of US$8 billion in 2021, placing it ahead of <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a> and behind <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-668"><a href="#cite_note-668">[662]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Saudi Arabia has a flag variant, mostly seen in civil settings and sometimes seen in governmental settings.<br/><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg" title="Saudi Arabian flag variant, mostly seen in civil settings and sometimes seen in governmental settings"><img alt="Saudi Arabian flag variant, mostly seen in civil settings and sometimes seen in governmental settings" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="83" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg/125px-Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg/188px-Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg/250px-Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg.png 2x" width="125"/></a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <i><a href="/wiki/Shahada" title="Shahada">Shahādah</a></i> (Statement of faith) is sometimes translated into English as 'There is no god but Allah', using the <a href="/wiki/Romanization" title="Romanization">romanization</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> word <i><a href="/wiki/Allah" title="Allah">Allāh</a></i> instead of its translation. The word <i>Allāh</i> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>: ٱلله) literally translates as <i>the God</i>, as the prefix 'Al-' is the definite article.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[4]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There is a <a href="/wiki/Consultative_Assembly_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia">Consultative Assembly</a>, or Shura Council, which has no legislative power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[10]</a></sup> As its role is only consultative it is not considered to be a legislature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[11]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="/ɔː/: 'au' in 'fraud'">ɔː</span><span title="'d' in 'dye'">d</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span></span><span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Saudi_Arabia-2.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d7/En-us-Saudi_Arabia-2.ogg" title="En-us-Saudi Arabia-2.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>, <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="/aʊ/: 'ou' in 'mouth'">aʊ</span></span>-/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Saudi_Arabia-3.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b3/En-us-Saudi_Arabia-3.ogg" title="En-us-Saudi Arabia-3.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>; <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>: ٱلسُّعُوْدِيَّة <i><span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">As-Suʿūdīyah</i></span></i></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>: ٱلْمَمْلَكَة ٱلْعَرَبِيَّة ٱلسُّعُوْدِيَّة <i><span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">al-Mamlakah al-ʿArabīyah as-Suʿūdīyah</i></span></i>, <span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ar-Kingdom_Saudi_Arabia.oga" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/48/Ar-Kingdom_Saudi_Arabia.oga" title="Ar-Kingdom Saudi Arabia.oga">pronunciation</a></span> <small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">(<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help"><span style="cursor:help;">help</span></a>·<a href="/wiki/File:Ar-Kingdom_Saudi_Arabia.oga" title="File:Ar-Kingdom Saudi Arabia.oga"><span style="cursor:help;">info</span></a>)</small></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-566"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-566">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A number of Muslims, using justifications from the Quran,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cite_quran|2|7|e=286|s=ns_556-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|2|7|e=286|s=ns-556">[551]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cite_quran|3|96|t=y|s=ns_557-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|3|96|t=y|s=ns-557">[552]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cite_quran|22|25|e=37|s=ns_558-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|22|25|e=37|s=ns-558">[553]</a></sup> insist that Islam did not begin with <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_in_Islam" title="Muhammad in Islam">Muhammad</a>, but that it represents even previous <a href="/wiki/Prophet" title="Prophet">Prophets</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Abraham_in_Islam" title="Abraham in Islam">Abraham</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Esposito1998_559-0"><a href="#cite_note-Esposito1998-559">[554]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Esposito2002b_560-0"><a href="#cite_note-Esposito2002b-560">[555]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peters2003_561-0"><a href="#cite_note-Peters2003-561">[556]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alli2013_562-0"><a href="#cite_note-Alli2013-562">[557]</a></sup> who is credited with having established the sanctuary of Mecca.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Michigan_C_1986_563-0"><a href="#cite_note-Michigan_C_1986-563">[558]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abu_Sway_2011_564-0"><a href="#cite_note-Abu_Sway_2011-564">[559]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dyrness2013_565-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dyrness2013-565">[560]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/saudi-arabia/" rel="nofollow">"The World Factbook"</a>. <i>CIA.gov</i>. <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFCallaway2011">Callaway, Ewen (27 January 2011). <a class="external text" href="http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110127/full/news.2011.55.html" rel="nofollow">"Early human migration written in stone tools : Nature News"</a>. <i>Nature</i>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fnews.2011.55" rel="nofollow">10.1038/news.2011.55</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature&amp;rft.atitle=Early+human+migration+written+in+stone+tools+%3A+Nature+News&amp;rft.date=2011-01-27&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fnews.2011.55&amp;rft.aulast=Callaway&amp;rft.aufirst=Ewen&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nature.com%2Fnews%2F2011%2F110127%2Ffull%2Fnews.2011.55.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFArmitageJasimMarksParker2011">Armitage, S. J.; Jasim, S. A.; Marks, A. E.; Parker, A. G.; Usik, V. I.; Uerpmann, H.-P. (2011). "Hints Of Earlier Human Exit From Africa". <i>Science</i>. Science News. <b>331</b> (6016): 453–456. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2011Sci...331..453A" rel="nofollow">2011Sci...331..453A</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1126%2Fscience.1199113" rel="nofollow">10.1126/science.1199113</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21273486" rel="nofollow">21273486</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:20296624" rel="nofollow">20296624</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Science&amp;rft.atitle=Hints+Of+Earlier+Human+Exit+From+Africa&amp;rft.volume=331&amp;rft.issue=6016&amp;rft.pages=453-456&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1126%2Fscience.1199113&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A20296624%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F21273486&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2011Sci...331..453A&amp;rft.aulast=Armitage&amp;rft.aufirst=S.+J.&amp;rft.au=Jasim%2C+S.+A.&amp;rft.au=Marks%2C+A.+E.&amp;rft.au=Parker%2C+A.+G.&amp;rft.au=Usik%2C+V.+I.&amp;rft.au=Uerpmann%2C+H.-P.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-101"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-101">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.mofa.gov.sa/sites/mofaen/aboutKingDom/Pages/CountryDevelopment36143.aspx" rel="nofollow">"History of the Kingdom | kingdom of Saudi Arabia – Ministry of Foreign Affairs"</a>. <i>www.mofa.gov.sa</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-122"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-122">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCordesman2003">Cordesman, Anthony H. <li id="cite_note-Cavendish92-158"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cavendish92_158-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/worlditspeoplesm0000unse/page/92" rel="nofollow"><i>World and Its Peoples: the Arabian Peninsula</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-195"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-195">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20181226144223/https://www.transparency.org/" rel="nofollow">"Corruption Perceptions Index 2010"</a>. Transparency International. 15 December 2010. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 26 December 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 December</span> 2010</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Corruption+Perceptions+Index+2010&amp;rft.pub=Transparency+International&amp;rft.date=2010-12-15&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.transparency.org%2Fpolicy_research%2Fsurveys_indices%2Fcpi%2F2010%2Fresults&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Mattar-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Mattar_213-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMattar2004">Mattar, Philip (2004). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofmo00phil_0" rel="nofollow"><i>Encyclopedia of the Modern Middle East &amp; North Africa: Vol. 1 A–C</i></a></span>. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofmo00phil_0/page/101" rel="nofollow">101</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-02-865770-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-02-865770-7"><bdi>978-0-02-865770-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+the+Modern+Middle+East+%26+North+Africa%3A+Vol.+1+A%E2%80%93C&amp;rft.pages=101&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-02-865770-7&amp;rft.aulast=Mattar&amp;rft.aufirst=Philip&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fencyclopediaofmo00phil_0&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Sharia_Inc_Courts-215"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Sharia_Inc_Courts_215-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia#Otto" title="Saudi Arabia">Otto</a>, pp. 161–162</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-216"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-216">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFOxford_Business_Group2009">Oxford Business Group (2009). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=gMPjxHzG1xQC&amp;pg=PA202" rel="nofollow"><i>The Report: Saudi Arabia</i></a>. p. 202. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-902339-00-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-902339-00-9"><bdi>978-1-902339-00-9</bdi></a>. <q>it is not always possible to reach a conclusion on how a Saudi court or judicial committee would view a particular case [because] decisions of a court or a judicial committee have no binding authority with respect to another case, [and] in general there is also no system of court reporting in the Kingdom.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Report%3A+Saudi+Arabia&amp;rft.pages=202&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-902339-00-9&amp;rft.au=Oxford+Business+Group&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DgMPjxHzG1xQC%26pg%3DPA202&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Haffner58-217"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Haffner58_217-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHefner2011">Hefner, Robert W. <li id="cite_note-auto-366"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-auto_366-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-auto_366-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.aramcoworld.com/issue/200602/volcanic.arabia.htm" rel="nofollow">"VOLCANIC ARABIA: It started with tremors"</a>. <i>archive.aramcoworld.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-coy-employ-389"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-coy-employ_389-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFCoy,_Peter2014">Coy, Peter (16 July 2014). <a class="external text" href="http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-07-16/can-online-classes-fix-saudi-arabias-broken-labor-market" rel="nofollow">"Online Education Targets Saudi Arabia's Labor Problem, Starting With Women"</a>. <i>Bloomberg Businessweek</i>. <q>Saudi citizens account for two-thirds of employment in the high-paying, comfortable public sector, but only one-fifth of employment in the more dynamic private sector, according to the International Monetary Fund (PDF).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Bloomberg+Businessweek&amp;rft.atitle=Online+Education+Targets+Saudi+Arabia%27s+Labor+Problem%2C+Starting+With+Women&amp;rft.date=2014-07-16&amp;rft.au=Coy%2C+Peter&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.businessweek.com%2Farticles%2F2014-07-16%2Fcan-online-classes-fix-saudi-arabias-broken-labor-market&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-McDowall-390"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-McDowall_390-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-McDowall_390-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-McDowall_390-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Economists "estimate only 30–40 percent of working-age Saudis hold jobs or actively seek work," the official employment rate of around 12 percent notwithstanding: <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFMcDowall2014">McDowall, Angus (19 January 2014). <a class="external text" href="http://english.alarabiya.net/en/business/2014/01/20/Saudi-Arabiya-doubles-number-of-citizens-in-private-sector-jobs.html" rel="nofollow">"Saudi Arabia doubles private sector jobs in 30-month period"</a>. <li id="cite_note-Aluwaisheg-399"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Aluwaisheg_399-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFAbdel_Aziz_Aluwaisheg2014">Abdel Aziz Aluwaisheg (29 September 2014). <a class="external text" href="http://www.arabnews.com/news/464657" rel="nofollow">"When privatization goes wrong"</a>. <i>Arab News</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Arab+News&amp;rft.atitle=When+privatization+goes+wrong&amp;rft.date=2014-09-29&amp;rft.au=Abdel+Aziz+Aluwaisheg&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.arabnews.com%2Fnews%2F464657&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-MV2013-400"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-MV2013_400-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.mondovisione.com/media-and-resources/news/saudi-stock-exchange-tadawul-annual-statistical-report-2013/" rel="nofollow">"Saudi Stock Exchange, Annual Statistical Report 2013"</a>. <i>mondovisione.com</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=mondovisione.com&amp;rft.atitle=Saudi+Stock+Exchange%2C+Annual+Statistical+Report+2013&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mondovisione.com%2Fmedia-and-resources%2Fnews%2Fsaudi-stock-exchange-tadawul-annual-statistical-report-2013%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-house-161-401"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-house-161_401-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#House">House</a>, p. 161: "Over the past decade, the government has announced one plan after another to 'Saudize' the economy, but to no avail. The foreign workforce grows, and so does unemployment among Saudis. .... The previous plan called for slashing unemployment to 2.8% only to see it rise to 10.5% in 2009, the end of that plan period. Government plans in Saudi are like those in the old Soviet Union, grandiose but unmet. (Also, as in the old Soviet Union, nearly all Saudi official statistics are unreliable, so economists believe the real Saudi unemployment rate is closer to 40%)"</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-451"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-451">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131115051640/http://www.relooney.info/SI_Milken-Arabia/0-Important_14.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Saudi Arabia Population Statistics 2011 (Arabic)"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. p. 11. <li id="cite_note-452"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-452">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.opendemocracy.net/faith-europe_islam/mecca_3882.jsp" rel="nofollow">"Mecca: Islam's cosmopolitan heart"</a>. <q>The Hijaz is the largest, most populated, and most culturally and religiously diverse region of Saudi Arabia, in large part because it was the traditional host area of all the pilgrims to Mecca, many of whom settled and intermarried there.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Mecca%3A+Islam%27s+cosmopolitan+heart&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.opendemocracy.net%2Ffaith-europe_islam%2Fmecca_3882.jsp&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-453"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-453">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#House">House</a>, p. 69: "Most Saudis only two generations ago eked out a subsistence living in rural provinces, but ... urbanization over the past 40 years [so now] .... fully 80% of Saudis now live in one of the country's three major urban centers – Riyadh, Jeddah, and Dammam."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-454"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-454">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#HT2003">Tripp, <i>Culture Shock</i>, 2003</a>: p. 31</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-455"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-455">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">One journalist states that 51% of the Saudi population is under the age of 25: <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFCaryle_Murphy2012">Caryle Murphy (7 February 2012). <a class="external text" href="http://www.newsecuritybeat.org/2012/02/saudi-arabias-youth-and-the-kingdoms-future/" rel="nofollow">"Saudi Arabia's Youth and the Kingdom's Future"</a>. Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars' Environmental Change and Security Program.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Saudi+Arabia%27s+Youth+and+the+Kingdom%27s+Future&amp;rft.pub=Woodrow+Wilson+International+Center+for+Scholars%27+Environmental+Change+and+Security+Program&amp;rft.date=2012-02-07&amp;rft.au=Caryle+Murphy&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.newsecuritybeat.org%2F2012%2F02%2Fsaudi-arabias-youth-and-the-kingdoms-future%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span> Two other sources state that 60% is under the age of 21: <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/node/21548973" rel="nofollow">"Out of the comfort zone"</a>. <i>The Economist</i>. 3 March 2012.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft.atitle=Out+of+the+comfort+zone&amp;rft.date=2012-03-03&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.economist.com%2Fnode%2F21548973&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span>, <a href="#House">House</a>, p. 221</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-456"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-456">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Economist magazine lists an estimated nine million: <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21589871-saudi-edict-limit-reliance-foreign-workers-fraught" rel="nofollow">"Go home, but who will replace you?"</a>. <i>The Economist</i>. 16 November 2013.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft.atitle=Go+home%2C+but+who+will+replace+you%3F&amp;rft.date=2013-11-16&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.economist.com%2Fnews%2Fmiddle-east-and-africa%2F21589871-saudi-edict-limit-reliance-foreign-workers-fraught&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span> out of a population of 30 million: <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21595480-despite-their-immense-wealth-saudis-are-not-happy-no-satisfaction" rel="nofollow">"Saudi Arabia No satisfaction"</a>. <i>The Economist</i>. 1 February 2014.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft.atitle=Saudi+Arabia+No+satisfaction&amp;rft.date=2014-02-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.economist.com%2Fnews%2Fmiddle-east-and-africa%2F21595480-despite-their-immense-wealth-saudis-are-not-happy-no-satisfaction&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-alriyadh.com-457"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-alriyadh.com_457-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-alriyadh.com_457-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFجريدة_الرياض">جريدة الرياض. <a class="external text" href="http://www.alriyadh.com/2010/08/05/article549461.html" rel="nofollow">"جريدة الرياض : سكان المملكة 27 مليوناً بينهم 8 ملايين مقيم"</a>. Alriyadh.com.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%D8%AC%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%A9+%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B6+%3A+%D8%B3%D9%83%D8%A7%D9%86+%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%85%D9%84%D9%83%D8%A9+27+%D9%85%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%88%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%8B+%D8%A8%D9%8A%D9%86%D9%87%D9%85+8+%D9%85%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%8A%D9%8A%D9%86+%D9%85%D9%82%D9%8A%D9%85&amp;rft.pub=Alriyadh.com&amp;rft.au=%D8%AC%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%A9+%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B6&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.alriyadh.com%2F2010%2F08%2F05%2Farticle549461.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-458"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-458">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFThiollet2021">Thiollet, Hélène (2 August 2021). <a class="external text" href="https://halshs.archives-ouvertes.fr/halshs-03329591" rel="nofollow">"Migrants and monarchs: regime survival, state transformation and migration politics in Saudi Arabia"</a>. <i>Third World Quarterly</i>. <b>43</b> (7): 1645–1665. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F01436597.2021.1948325" rel="nofollow">10.1080/01436597.2021.1948325</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:238794883" rel="nofollow">238794883</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Third+World+Quarterly&amp;rft.atitle=Migrants+and+monarchs%3A+regime+survival%2C+state+transformation+and+migration+politics+in+Saudi+Arabia&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.pages=1645-1665&amp;rft.date=2021-08-02&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F01436597.2021.1948325&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A238794883%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.aulast=Thiollet&amp;rft.aufirst=H%C3%A9l%C3%A8ne&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fhalshs.archives-ouvertes.fr%2Fhalshs-03329591&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-476"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-476">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.ethnologue.com/country/SA/status" rel="nofollow">"Saudi Arabia"</a>. <i>Ethnologue</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-PewForump.17-479"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-PewForump.17_479-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.pewforum.org/files/2009/10/Muslimpopulation.pdf" rel="nofollow">Mapping the World Muslim Population</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180619214725/http://www.pewforum.org/files/2009/10/Muslimpopulation.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 19 June 2018 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>(October 2009), Pew Forum on Religion &amp; Public Life. p. 16 (p. 17 of the PDF).</span>

<li id="cite_note-480"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-480">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Data for Saudi Arabia comes primarily from general population surveys, which are less reliable than censuses or large-scale demographic and health surveys for estimating minority-majority ratios.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-539"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-539">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.arabnews.com/number-pakistani-expats-exceeds-15-m" rel="nofollow">"Number of Pakistani expats exceeds 1.5 m"</a>. <li id="cite_note-Esposito1998-559"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Esposito1998_559-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFEsposito1998">Esposito, John (1998). <i>Islam: The Straight Path (3rd ed.)</i>. <li id="cite_note-575"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-575">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">the start of each lunar month determined not ahead of time by astronomical calculation, but only after the crescent moon is sighted by the proper religious authorities. (source: <a href="#HT2009">Tripp, <i>Culture Shock</i>, 2009</a>: pp. 154–155)</span>

<li id="cite_note-579"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-579">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://arab.news/wzq7e" rel="nofollow">"Saudi businesses to remain open during prayer times"</a>. <i>Arab News</i>. 17 July 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-HT2009:_214-580"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-HT2009:_214_580-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#HT2009">Tripp, <i>Culture Shock</i>, 2009</a>: p. 214</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-581"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-581">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sulaiman, Tosin. <a class="external text" href="http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article697051.ece" rel="nofollow">Bahrain changes the weekend in efficiency drive</a>, <i>The Times</i>, 2 August 2006. Retrieved 25 June 2008. Turkey has a weekend on Saturday and Sunday. Prior to 29 June 2013, the weekend was Thursday-Friday, but was shifted to better serve the Saudi economy and its international commitments. See <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141029175552/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&amp;contentid=20130624171030" rel="nofollow">"Weekend shift: A welcome change"</a>. <i>SaudiGazette.com.sa</i>. 24 June 2013. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method%3Dhome.regcon%26contentid%3D20130624171030" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 29 October 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">28 October</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=SaudiGazette.com.sa&amp;rft.atitle=Weekend+shift%3A+A+welcome+change&amp;rft.date=2013-06-24&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.saudigazette.com.sa%2Findex.cfm%3Fmethod%253Dhome.regcon%2526contentid%253D20130624171030&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-HT2009:35-582"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-HT2009:35_582-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#HT2009">Tripp, <i>Culture Shock</i>, 2009</a>: p. 35</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-nyrob-relig-educ-583"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-nyrob-relig-educ_583-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-nyrob-relig-educ_583-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFRodenbeck2004">Rodenbeck, Max (21 October 2004). <a class="external text" href="http://www.nybooks.com/articles/17477" rel="nofollow">"Unloved in Arabia (Book Review)"</a>. <i>The New York Review of Books</i>. <b>51</b> (16). <q>Almost half of Saudi state television's airtime is devoted to religious issues, as is about half the material taught in state schools" (source: By the estimate of an elementary schoolteacher in Riyadh, Islamic studies make up 30 percent of the actual curriculum. But another 20 percent creeps into textbooks on history, science, Arabic, and so forth. In contrast, by one unofficial count the entire syllabus for 12 years of Saudi schooling contains a total of just 38 pages covering the history, literature, and cultures of the non-Muslim world.)</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Review+of+Books&amp;rft.atitle=Unloved+in+Arabia+%28Book+Review%29&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=16&amp;rft.date=2004-10-21&amp;rft.aulast=Rodenbeck&amp;rft.aufirst=Max&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nybooks.com%2Farticles%2F17477&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-nyrob-relig-books-584"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-nyrob-relig-books_584-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFRodenbeck2004">Rodenbeck, Max (21 October 2004). <a class="external text" href="http://www.nybooks.com/articles/17477" rel="nofollow">"Unloved in Arabia (Book Review)"</a>. <i>The New York Review of Books</i>. <b>51</b> (16). <q>Nine out of ten titles published in the kingdom are on religious subjects, and most of the doctorates its universities awards are in Islamic studies.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Review+of+Books&amp;rft.atitle=Unloved+in+Arabia+%28Book+Review%29&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=16&amp;rft.date=2004-10-21&amp;rft.aulast=Rodenbeck&amp;rft.aufirst=Max&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nybooks.com%2Farticles%2F17477&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-585"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-585">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.nybooks.com/articles/17477" rel="nofollow">Review. "Unloved in Arabia"</a> By Max Rodenbeck. <i>The New York Review of Books</i>, Volume 51, Number 16 · 21 October 2004.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-586"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-586">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">from p. 195 of a <a class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/4284264?seq=4" rel="nofollow">review</a> by Joshua Teitelbum, <i>Middle East Studies</i>, Vol. 38, No. 4, Oct. 2002, of <i>Changed Identities: The Challenge of the New Generation in Saudi Arabia</i> by anthropologist Mai Yamani, quoting p. 116 |quote=Saudis of all stripes interviewed expressed a desire for the kingdom to remain a Muslim society ruled by an overtly Muslim state. Secularists are simply not to be found. [Both traditional and somewhat westernized Saudis she talked to mediate their concerns] though the certainties of religion.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-statsKSA-587"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-statsKSA_587-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://country-stats.com/en/countries/asia/saudi-arabia/10599-saudi-arabia-culture.html" rel="nofollow">"Saudi Arabia – Culture"</a>. <i>Country Stats</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 August</span> 2019</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Nation&amp;rft.atitle=Saudi+Arabia+to+allow+adult+women+to+travel%2C+register+divorce&amp;rft.date=2019-08-02&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fnation.com.pk%2F02-Aug-2019%2Fsaudi-arabia-to-allow-adult-women-to-travel-register-divorce&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-618"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-618">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170928060016/http://selwaalhazzaa.com/index.html" rel="nofollow">"Professor Selwa Al-hazzaa"</a>. <li id="cite_note-619"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-619">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/the-destruction-of-mecca-saudi-hardliners-are-wiping-out-their-own-heritage-501647.html" rel="nofollow">'The destruction of Mecca: Saudi hardliners are wiping out their own heritage'</a>, <i>The Independent</i>, 6 August 2005. Retrieved 17 January 2011</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-620"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-620">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.islamicpluralism.org/764/islamic-heritage-lost-as-makkah-modernises" rel="nofollow">'Islamic heritage lost as Makkah modernises'</a> Center for Islamic Pluralism</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-independent.co.uk-621"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-independent.co.uk_621-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/shame-of-the-house-of-saud-shadows-over-mecca-474736.html" rel="nofollow">'Shame of the House of Saud: Shadows over Mecca'</a>, The Independent, 19 April 2006</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-622"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-622">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://theamericanmuslim.org/tam.php/features/articles/saudi_destruction_of_muslim_historical_sites/" rel="nofollow">Destruction of Islamic Architectural Heritage in Saudi Arabia: A Wake-up Call</a>, The American Muslim. Retrieved 17 January 2011
Other historic buildings that have been destroyed include the house of <a href="/wiki/Khadija_bint_Khuwaylid" title="Khadija bint Khuwaylid">Khadijah</a>, the wife of Muhammad, the house of <a href="/wiki/Abu_Bakr" title="Abu Bakr">Abu Bakr</a>, now the site of the local <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hilton_hotel" title="Hilton hotel">Hilton hotel</a>; the house of Ali-Oraid, the grandson of Muhammad, and the Mosque of Abu-Qubais, now the location of the King's palace in Mecca. (source: <a class="external text" href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/shame-of-the-house-of-saud-shadows-over-mecca-474736.html" rel="nofollow">'Shame of the House of Saud: Shadows over Mecca'</a>, <i>The Independent</i>, 19 April 2006)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-623"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-623">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1293/" rel="nofollow">"Al-Hijr Archaeological Site (Madâin Sâlih)"</a>. <i>UNESCO World Heritage Centre</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">24 April</span> 2019</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=UNESCO+World+Heritage+Centre&amp;rft.atitle=Al-Hijr+Archaeological+Site+%28Mad%C3%A2in+S%C3%A2lih%29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwhc.unesco.org%2Fen%2Flist%2F1293%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-624"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-624">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1329/" rel="nofollow">"At-Turaif District in ad-Dir'iyah"</a>. <i>UNESCO World Heritage Centre</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">24 April</span> 2019</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=UNESCO+World+Heritage+Centre&amp;rft.atitle=At-Turaif+District+in+ad-Dir%27iyah&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwhc.unesco.org%2Fen%2Flist%2F1329%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-625"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-625">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1361/" rel="nofollow">"Historic Jeddah, the Gate to Makkah"</a>. <i>UNESCO World Heritage Centre</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.
